COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - INNOVATIONS DEVELOPED BY EXISTING JOINT CIVILIAN-MILITARY MEDICAL TRAINING PROGRAMS ARE BEING APPLIED IN-THEATER  ACROSS THE ROLES OF CARE AND WITHIN THE PREHOSPITAL AND CRITICAL CARE CLINICAL FACILITIES WITHIN THE MILITARY  HEALTH SYSTEM. THESE SOLUTIONS NOT ONLY HELP TO MINIMIZE THE MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY OF COMBAT-RELATED INJURIES  SUSTAINED BY THE WARFIGHTER; THEY ARE ALSO OFTEN TRANSLATABLE TO CIVILIAN CARE.  BUILDING ON THESE EXISTING SUCCESSFUL PROGRAMS, ACADEMIC MEDICAL TRAINING CENTERS WITH ONGOING AND COMPREHENSIVE  INFRASTRUCTURE SHOULD BE ESTABLISHED FOR MILITARY MEDICAL PROVIDERS TO PRACTICE, EXPERIENCE AND DISCOVER NEW WAYS  TO PROVIDE CARE AND ADVANCE THE GOALS OF THE NDAA.  SPECIFICALLY, AREAS OF FOCUS BY THE ACADEMIC MEDICAL TRAINING CENTERS SHOULD INCLUDE:  - PROLONGED AND IN ROUTE CARE: THE PROLONGED AND IN ROUTE CARE PORTFOLIO SEEKS TO PROVIDE SOLUTIONS TO  ENABLE INCREASED LEVELS OF CARE CLOSER TO THE POINT OF INJURY, INCLUDING CARE PROVIDED DURING EVACUATION, TO  PROVIDE PATIENT CARE FOR LONGER TIME PERIODS WHEN DELAYED EVACUATION EXCEEDS AVAILABLE CAPABILITY AND/OR  CAPACITY, AND TO EXTEND PROVIDER CAPABILITIES TO CARE FOR LARGER NUMBERS OF CASUALTIES.  - BATTLEFIELD RESUSCITATION FOR IMMEDIATE STABILIZATION OF COMBAT CASUALTIES: HEMORRHAGE IS THE LEADING  CAUSE OF PREVENTABLE DEATHS AMONG COMBAT CASUALTIES OCCURRING BEFORE A MEDICAL TREATMENT FACILITY IS REACHED. THE  BATTLEFIELD RESUSCITATION FOR IMMEDIATE STABILIZATION OF COMBAT CASUALTIES PORTFOLIO SEEKS TO PROVIDE SOLUTIONS  TO ENABLE THE IMMEDIATE STABILIZATION AT THE POINT OF INJURY. CURRENT STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO PROVIDE: (1)  TECHNOLOGIES TO CONTROL BLEEDING IN THE PREHOSPITAL ENVIRONMENT, (2) SAFER, MORE EFFECTIVE, AND MORE LOGISTICALLY  SUPPORTABLE BLOOD PRODUCTS, AND (3) TECHNOLOGIES AND KNOWLEDGE SETS FOR IMPROVED DAMAGE CONTROL RESUSCITATION.  - NEUROTRAUMA: THE NEUROTRAUMA PORTFOLIO (NTP) IS FOCUSED ON CLOSING MILITARY-RELEVANT GAPS ACROSS A BROAD  RAN GE OF RESEARCH AREAS TO IMPROVE THE PREVENTION, DIAGNOSIS, MANAGEMENT, AND TREATMENT OF TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURY  (TBI) AND RELATED SEQUELAE FROM POINT-OF-INJURY THROUGH RECOVERY. THE NTP’S GOAL IS TO DECREASE MORBIDITY AND  MORTALITY FROM NEUROTRAUMA, MITIGATE SECONDARY BRAIN INJURY ACROSS ALL TBI SEVERITIES, AND ADVANCE MATERIEL AND  KNOWLEDGE DEVELOPMENT TO EXPAND AND DEVELOP NEW CLINICAL PRACTICE GUIDELINES, CARE ALGORITHMS, THERAPIES,  DEVICES, AND PROCEDURES THAT ADVANCE THE DECISION-MAKING CAPABILITIES OF MEDICAL PERSONNEL, ENABLING EARLIER  INTERVENTION AND IMPROVED OUTCOMES.  TO OPERATIONALIZE THE PROGRAMS NEEDED TO MEET NDAA GOALS AND ZERO PREVENTABLE DEATH OBJECTIVES, EXPANDED  PARTNERSHIPS WITH ACADEMIC MEDICAL INSTITUTIONS MUST BE FUNDED. FUNDING SHOULD EXPAND PARTNERSHIPS WITHIN CURRENT  CIVILIAN-MILITARY MEDICAL TRAINING PROGRAMS THAT ARE BOTH CAPABLE AND EXPERIENCED WITH DEVELOPING PILOT  INITIATIVES.  AUTHORIZING SPECIFIC FUNDING IN THE FY 2023 NDAA TO ESTABLISH A MINIMUM OF 7 GEO-DIVERSE AND UNIQUE ACADEMIC  MILITARY-CIVILIAN MEDICAL TRAINING CENTERS ACROSS THE COUNTRY WILL ACHIEVE NDAA OBJECTIVES. PILOT FUNDING IS  RECOMMENDED TO BE AT A MINIMUM $3 MILLION PER CENTER FOR FY 2023. FUNDING WOULD PROVIDE FOR THE START-UP COSTS OF  RECRUITING PERSONNEL, SECURING EQUIPMENT, AND EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES. FUNDING WILL ALLOW FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF  ACADEMIC PROGRAMS, RECRUITING TALENTED INNOVATORS, SECURING EDUCATIONAL INFRASTRUCTURE, AND CONDUCTING PILOT  TRAINING INITIATIVES.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - YWCA GREENWICH, CONNECTICUT, INC. 259 EAST PUTNAM AVENUE, GREENWICH, CT 06830 MARY LEE A. KIERNAN, PRESIDENT AND CEO ML.KIERNAN@YWCAGREENWICH.ORG 203-869-6501 WWW.YWCAGREENWICH.ORG FUNDING REQUEST: $75,000  YWCA GREENWICH, CONNECTICUT, INC. LOCATED AT 259 EAST PUTNAM AVENUE, GREENWICH, CONNECTICUT, WHOSE MISSION IS TO ELIMINATE RACISM, EMPOWER WOMEN AND PROMOTE PEACE, JUSTICE, FREEDOM, AND DIGNITY FOR ALL, IS THE SOLE PROVIDER OF DOMESTIC ABUSE SERVICES IN THE TOWN OF GREENWICH. DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, BEGINNING AROUND MARCH 2020 AND CONTINUING THOUGH TODAY, YWCA GREENWICH HAS SEEN A SURGE IN DEMAND FOR OUR SERVICES TO VICTIMS OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE AND THEIR CHILDREN. INCIDENTS OF VIOLENCE IN THE HOME HAVE INCREASED AS VICTIMS WERE TRAPPED AT HOME WITH THEIR ABUSERS. CHILDREN, WHO NORMALLY WOULD BE A SCHOOL AND SOMEWHAT SHIELDED FROM WITNESSING OR EXPERIENCING VIOLENCE, HAVE BEEN SEVERELY IMPACTED BY THE VIOLENCE IN THEIR HOMES. EVEN AS THE PANDEMIC RESTRICTIONS ARE LIFTED, MANY EMPLOYEES REMAIN WORKING FROM HOME, ADDING TO THE STRESS OF VICTIMS WHO ARE UNDER CONSTANT SCRUTINY BY THEIR ABUSERS. CURRENTLY YWCA GREENWICH’S DOMESTIC ABUSE SERVICES ARE LOCATED IN THE LOWER LEVEL OF OUR 44,000SF BUILDING WHICH ALSO HOUSES OUR PRESCHOOL, AFTERSCHOOL, SUMMER CAMP, ADULT AND YOUTH FITNESS AND AQUATICS PROGRAMS. HAVING THESE SERVICES AVAILABLE AT THE YWCA GREENWICH PROVIDES SAFETY AND ANONYMITY FOR VICTIMS SEEKING SERVICES. YWCA GREENWICH PROVIDES CRISIS INTERVENTION, INDIVIDUAL AND GROUP COUNSELING FOR ADULTS AND CHILDREN, SAFETY PLANNING, EMERGENCY SHELTER (NOT ON SITE), CIVIL AND CRIMINAL LEGAL GUIDANCE AND FINANCIAL LITERACY COURSES. WE LEAD GROUP SESSIONS AND PROVIDE PREVENTION EDUCATION TO PROMOTE HEALTHY RELATIONSHIPS.  YWCA GREENWICH IS SEEKING $75,000 TO FUND DESIGN COSTS INCLUDING ARCHITECTURAL AND ENGINEERING FEES TO RECONFIGURE THE SPACE IN OUR CURRENT BUILDING TO HOUSE OUR DOMESTIC ABUSE SERVICES. SPECIFICALLY, WE ARE SEEKING TO ADD MOR E SPACE TO ACCOMMODATE MORE COUNSELORS, MOVE THE PROGRAM OUT OF THE BASEMENT AND INTO A MORE ACCESSIBLE AREA OF THE BUILDING, INCREASE OUR CAPACITY TO OFFER SPECIALIZED SERVICES WITH AREAS DEVOTED TO GROUP COUNSELING AND CHILD COUNSELING WHILE MAINTAINING SECURITY AND ANONYMITY FOR OUR CLIENTS.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE THE CAPABILITIES OF THE ERIC MUNOZ TRAUMA CENTER AT UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL BY MAKING CHANGES TO THE CURRENT INFRASTRUCTURE THAT WILL ALLOW MORE RAPID INTERVENTIONS.  USING THE “GOLDEN HOUR” CONCEPT, WHERE MORTALITY IS DECREASED THE EARLIER DEFINITIVE (I.E. SURGERY) CARE IS RENDERED, THE CHANGES WE PROPOSE BRING US CLOSER TO THE BEGINNING OF THE “HOUR” RATHER THAN THE END. AS SUCH, THE PROJECT WILL PRIMARILY FOCUS ON CONVERTING THE CURRENT SHOCK TRAUMA TREATMENT AREA FROM 286 SQUARE FEET TO 458 SQUARE FEET, THEREBY ALLOWING US TO CONVERT THE SPACE INTO A FUNCTIONAL OPERATING ROOM.  THE NEW SPACE WOULD PROVIDE THE FUNCTIONALITY NEEDED FOR AN ENTIRE OPERATING ROOM TEAM TO CIRCULATE FREELY AROUND A CENTRAL SURGICAL FIELD AND IMPROVE THE POSITIONING OF NEEDED SURGICAL EQUIPMENT. WE PROPOSE TO ENHANCE AND ADD NEW SURGICAL DEVICES, IMPROVE LIGHTING, AND UPDATE TECHNOLOGY TO FURTHER IMPROVE SURGICAL PERFORMANCE AND OUTCOMES.  THE SPACE WILL BE BACKED UP 100% BY GENERATOR POWER TO ENSURE THE ROOMS ABILITY TO STAY FUNCTIONAL DURING NATURAL DISASTERS AND POWER OUTAGES.  FINALLY, WE WILL UPGRADE THE HVAC SYSTEM TO CURRENT REGULATORY STANDARDS FOR OPERATING ROOMS. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT SEEKS TO IMPROVE OUTCOMES FOR LESS SEVERE TRAUMA PATIENTS BY OFFERING AN ENHANCED TREATMENT SPACE.  THE TRAUMA TREATMENT BAYS WILL HAVE IMPROVED LIGHTING AND VISIBILITY ALLOWING THE ENTIRE CARE TEAM TO FOLLOW THE PATIENT ON ONE DATA DISPLAY.  PROPOSED IMPROVEMENTS AND UPDATES TO ELECTRICAL RECEPTACLES, MEDICAL GASES AND SURGICAL SUPPLIES WILL IMPROVE FLEXIBILITY OF THE SPACE AND ALSO ALLOW FOR A RAPID CENSUS INCREASE DURING CATASTROPHIC EVENTS. THE ADDITION OF TWO PATIENT HOLDING BAYS FOR USE AFTER STABILIZATION WILL ENABLE MORE CRITICALLY INJURED PATIENTS TO FLOW INTO THE TRAUMA TREATMENT BAYS.  THIS AREA WILL ALSO HAVE UPGRADED TECHNOLOGY AND LIGHTING IMPROVEMENTS.  SUPPORT SPACES WILL BE RECONFIGURED AND RELOCATED TO ACCOMMODATE TH E CHANGES PROPOSED IN THE SHOCK TRAUMA TREATMENT AREA AND TRAUMA BAYS. ULTIMATELY, BY CREATING A SPACE THAT WILL ALLOW MORE RAPID INTERVENTION FOR ALL OUR CRITICALLY ILL TRAUMA PATIENTS, HEALTH OUTCOMES WILL IMPROVE FOR THE PATIENTS OF OUR TRAUMA CENTER.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ORGANIZATION: UNIVERSITY HEALTH, 2301 HOLMES, KANSAS CITY, MO 64108 PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: JIM GILES CONTACT PHONE NUMBER: 816-404-2350 EMAIL ADDRESS: JAMES.GILES@UHKC.ORG WEBSITE ADDRESS: WWW.UHKC.ORG GRANT PROGRAM FUNDS REQUESTED: $2,500,000  TRUMAN MEDICAL CENTERS (TMC) WILL CREATE A STATE-OF-THE-ART SUBSTANCE USE DISORDER TREATMENT CENTER IN KANSAS CITY’S UMKC HEALTH SCIENCES DISTRICT. TMC WILL RENOVATE AN EXISTING FACILITY (21,591 SQUARE FEET) TO ACCOMMODATE A FULLY INTEGRATED SUBSTANCE USE DISORDER PRACTICE. THE CENTER FOR RECOVERY HEALTH WILL PROVIDE NEW AND EXISTING PATIENTS WITH DIRECT CARE SUCH AS PSYCHIATRIC SERVICES AND MEDICATIONS FOR ADDICTION TREATMENT (MAT), AS WELL AS CASE MANAGEMENT AND PEER RECOVERY INTERVENTIONS TO ADDRESS PSYCHOSOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH. THIS FACILITY WILL ALLOW TMC TO DOUBLE ITS PROVIDER TEAM, ENSURING RAPID ACCESS TO HIGH-QUALITY CARE FOR A PARTICULARLY VULNERABLE POPULATION.   FURTHER, IT WILL PROVIDE THE OPPORTUNITY TO IMPLEMENT NEW AND EMERGENT TREATMENT MODALITIES, INCLUDING AN ON-DEMAND CONSULT TEAM DELIVERING CARE VIA TELEHEALTH, LONG-ACTING INJECTABLE MEDICATIONS FOR THE TREATMENT OF OPIOID USE DISORDER, TRANSCRANIAL MAGNETIC STIMULATION (TMS), AND ESKETAMINE (AN EMERGING CARE MODALITY FOR TREATMENT-RESISTANT DEPRESSION). INVESTMENT IN THIS INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECT WILL HELP TO IMPROVE THE EQUITABLE DELIVERY OF HIGH-QUALITY CARE AND SENDS A MESSAGE OF HOPE AND RESPECT TO INDIVIDUALS LIVING WITH SUBSTANCE USE DISORDERS.  TMC RECOVERY HEALTH SERVICES CURRENTLY HAS THE CAPACITY TO SERVE APPROXIMATELY 1,000 PATIENTS ANNUALLY, BUT THE NEED IS SIGNIFICANTLY HIGHER AND GROWING. TMC OFFERS A WIDE RANGE OF EVIDENCE-BASED INTERVENTIONS THROUGH A MULTIDISCIPLINARY TEAM, TREATING EVERYTHING FROM ALCOHOL TO INTRAVENOUS HEROIN. TELEHEALTH SERVICES HAVE ALLOWED US TO REACH MORE PATIENTS AND KEEP THEM ENGAGED DESPITE TRAVEL AND OTHER BARRIERS. IN ADDITION TO CONTINUING OUR CURRENT OPERATIONS AND SERVING MORE PEOP LE, WE WANT TO EXPAND AND OFFER NEW WAYS TO DELIVER CARE AND ENGAGE THOSE IN NEED. CURRENTLY, WE ARE CREATING A CONSULTATION SERVICE TO PROVIDE SAME DAY TREATMENT FOR PATIENTS WHO PRESENT IN THE EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT, PRIMARY CARE, OR WOMEN’S HEALTH. IN ADDITION TO THE OPIOID EPIDEMIC, RAPIDLY EXPANDING STIMULANT MISUSE REQUIRES US TO IMPLEMENT NEW APPROACHES, INCLUDING CONTINGENCY MANAGEMENT.  TMC WORKS TO ENGAGE THE MOST MARGINALIZED PATIENT POPULATIONS IN KANSAS CITY AND JACKSON COUNTY, INCLUDING THOSE IN THE CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM, INDIVIDUALS IMPACTED BY HOMELESSNESS, AND PREGNANT WOMEN. PROVIDING BEHAVIORAL HEALTH AS PART OF A HOSPITAL SYSTEM ALLOWS US TO ENGAGE PATIENTS IN UNIQUE WAYS AND FOLLOW THEM ACROSS THE CONTINUITY OF CARE - AN ESSENTIAL COMPONENT TO REDUCING BARRIERS. WE COLLABORATE WITH EPICC (ENGAGING PATIENTS IN CARE COORDINATION) TO PROVIDE RAPID MEDICATION AND TREATMENT TO PATIENTS AFTER THEY PRESENT TO AREA EMERGENCY DEPARTMENTS FOLLOWING A DRUG OVERDOSE. IN ADDITION, TMC RECOVERY HEALTH SERVICES PROVIDES INTENSIVE CASE MANAGEMENT AND OUTREACH SERVICES TO ENGAGE PATIENTS IMPACTED BY HOMELESSNESS. THE TEAM WORKS CLOSELY WITH HOUSING SPECIALISTS AND UTILIZES HOUSING OPTIONS AS A PRIMARY INTERVENTION IN TREATMENT OF ADDICTION.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - SUNY DOWNSTATE HEALTH SCIENCES UNIVERSITY WILL ESTABLISH A COMMUNITY HEALTH PRIMARY CARE PILOT SITE IN CENTRAL BROOKLYN THAT ADDRESSES HEALTH INEQUITIES AND THE COMPLEXITY OF OUR PATIENTS THROUGH A COORDINATED POPULATION HEALTH APPROACH. RENOVATION OF A NEW FAMILY MEDICINE LOCATION THAT SERVES BOTH CHILDREN AND ADULTS WILL INCLUDE TECHNOLOGY THAT FACILITATES CARE MANAGEMENT AND ASSISTS WITH ADDRESSING SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PROJECT ABSTRACT: ADDRESS: 251 W. LIGUSTRUM, SAN ANTONIO, TX 78228 PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: DAN A. RATLIFF, PH.D. CONTACT PHONE NUMBERS (VOICE, FAX) VOICE: 210-438-6400; FAX:  EMAIL ADDRESS: DRATLIFF@STMARYTX.EDU WEBSITE ADDRESS: HTTPS://WWW.STMARYTX.EDU/OUTREACH/COUNSELING/  BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT: CDS FUNDING WAS PROVIDED FOR RENOVATION AND MODERNIZATION OF THE FAMILY LIFE CENTER (FLC) OF ST. MARY’S UNIVERSITY.  THE FLC SERVES PRIMARILY LOW-INCOME CLIENTS FROM CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT 20 (TX-20), USING GRADUATE STUDENT INTERNS UNDER SUPERVISION BY EXPERIENCED, LICENSED FACULTY MEMBERS.  IN ADDITION, GRADUATE STUDENT INTERNS PROVIDE SERVICES IN OVER 30 OTHER COMMUNITY AGENCIES AND SCHOOL DISTRICTS. MODERNIZATION OF CLINICAL AREAS OF THE FLC FACILITY INCLUDE: 1) BUILDING EXTERIOR; 2) HEATING, VENTILATION, AND AIR CONDITIONING (HVAC); 3) IMPROVEMENT OF INTERIOR ARRANGEMENTS OF EXISTING FACILITY; AND 4) PURCHASE OF EQUIPMENT.  NEEDS TO BE ADDRESSED:  THE POPULATION PROFILE OF TX-20 HAS THE GREATEST DISPARITIES IN MENTAL HEALTH CARE IN THE US.  TX-20 IS WITHIN A MENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONALS SHORTAGE AREA, AS DESIGNATED BY THE TEXAS DEPARTMENT OF STATE HEALTH SERVICES.  HISPANICS ARE LESS LIKELY TO USE ANY FORM OF MENTAL HEALTH CARE THAN NON-HISPANIC WHITE POPULATION. AMONG HISPANIC ADULTS WHO RECEIVED ANY MENTAL HEALTH TREATMENT, EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT CARE OR PRIMARY CARE WERE THE MOST FREQUENT SOURCES OF TREATMENT. COLLABORATIVE CARE AND INTERNET-BASED MENTAL HEALTH CARE CAN OVERCOME ACCESS AND UTILIZATION BARRIERS FOR THIS POPULATION.   THE FLC IS HOUSED IN A FORMER RESIDENCE OF A RELIGIOUS ORDER, BUILT IN 1958. MUCH OF THE EXISTING HVAC AND BUILDING ENVELOPE ARE ORIGINAL AND IS NOT ADEQUATE FOR SAN ANTONIO WEATHER. ALTHOUGH THE BUILDING MEETS THE STANDARDS OF THE ARCHITECTURAL BARRIERS ACT, INSTALLATION OF A REMOTE ENTRY SYSTEM AND WIDENING OF DOORS TO CLINICAL ROOMS WILL ENHANCE CLINICAL SERVICES.   THE PROPOSED SERVICES:  THE CONS TRUCTION MODERNIZATION WILL SUPPORT TRADITIONAL FACE-TO-FACE AND TELE-HEALTH MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES TO THE UNDERSERVED POPULATION OF TX-20. MODERNIZATION OF THE BUILDING EXTERIOR WILL INCLUDE INSTALLATION OF A REMOTE ENTRY SYSTEM FOR TWO MAIN ENTRIES, AND WEATHERIZATION/STRATEGIC REPLACEMENT OF WINDOWS FOR GREATER ENERGY EFFICIENCY. MODERNIZATION OF HVAC SYSTEMS INCLUDE REPLACEMENT OF EXISTING BOILER (INSTALLED IN 1958) AND EXISTING AC UNIT (INSTALLED IN 1969). IMPROVEMENT OF INTERIOR ARRANGEMENTS INCLUDE WIDENING AND REPLACING DOORS OF FIRST FLOOR ROOMS TO ENHANCE ACCESS AND PRIVACY, MODERNIZING WINDOW TREATMENTS FOR GREATER ENERGY EFFICIENCY, AND INSTALLATION OF INTERNET LINES AND WIFI ACCESS POINTS TO SUPPORT TELE-HEALTH SERVICES. THE EQUIPMENT PURCHASES WILL SUPPORT TELE-HEALTH SERVICES AND INSTRUCTIONAL TECHNOLOGY. .  THE CONSTRUCTION AND EQUIPMENT WILL SUPPORT OUTREACH PROGRAMMING TO HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS WITHIN THE DISTRICT TO PROMOTE COLLABORATIVE MENTAL HEALTH CARE. THIS PROGRAM INITIATIVE WILL UTILIZE TELE-HEALTH SERVICES IN PRIMARY CARE OFFICES, SCHOOLS, SENIOR CENTERS, AND OTHER INSTITUTIONS IN THE COMMUNITY THAT CAN PROVIDE PRIVATE SPACE.  HALF OF THE COMPUTERS USED FOR TELE-HEALTH SERVICES WILL BE INSTALLED IN THE FAMILY LIFE CENTER WITH THE REMAINDER INSTALLED IN COLLABORATING AGENCIES AND OFFICES.  POPULATION GROUP(S) TO BE SERVED: THE POPULATION PROFILE OF TX-20 IS 69.4% HISPANIC, WITH 25.5% OF CHILDREN UNDER 18 AND 11.2% AGED 65 AND OLDER. OF THE POPULATION OF DISTRICT 20, 23.7% OF HOUSEHOLDS MAKE 125% OR LESS OF THE POVERTY LEVEL.  COMPUTERS ARE OWNED BY 91.6% OF THE DISTRICT’S POPULATION, WITH 82.6% INDICATING BROADBAND INTERNET ACCESS (US CENSUS, AMERICAN COMMUNITY SURVEY, 2020).  NO OTHER GRANT PROGRAM FUNDS ARE REQUESTED IN THIS APPLICATION.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ST. JOSEPH’S UNIVERSITY MEDICAL CENTER, INC. (SJUMC) IS THE FLAGSHIP MEDICAL CENTER OF ST. JOSEPH’S HEALTH, A NEW JERSEY-BASED HEALTHCARE SYSTEM. SJUMC IS THE NEW JERSEY DIVISION OF MENTAL HEALTH AND ADDICTION SERVICES-DESIGNATED SCREENING CENTER FOR PASSAIC COUNTY, NJ FOR PSYCHIATRIC EMERGENCIES, CRISIS INTERVENTION SERVICES, INFORMATION AND REFERRAL. THE $1,000,000 FUNDING ALLOCATED THROUGH HRSA’S CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING (CDS):  CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS FOR OUR EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT (ED) PSYCHIATRIC SCREENING CENTER WILL BE USED TO COMPLETELY RENOVATE APPROXIMATELY 3,000 SQUARE FEET OF EXISTING PHYSICAL STRUCTURE.  IT WILL ALLOW ST. JOSEPH’S HEALTH TO RELOCATE AND EXPAND THE TREATMENT/HOLDING SPACE FOR PSYCHIATRIC PATIENTS IN THE ST. JOSEPH’S UNIVERSITY MEDICAL CENTER ED IN ORDER TO ENHANCE ACCESS TO SERVICES AND PROVIDE BETTER HEALTH OUTCOMES.  THE NEW ED PSYCHIATRIC SCREENING CENTER WILL BE RELOCATED TO A LARGER SPACE AND ACCOMMODATE ADDITIONAL PSYCHIATRIC ED BEDS THAT WILL ALLOW FOR BETTER CARE, ASSESSMENT AND TREATMENT PRIOR TO PATIENTS ACCESSING THE NEXT LEVEL OF SERVICE THEY NEED. THE LARGER SPACE WILL ALSO ALLOW FOR THE CREATION OF A CENTRALIZED NURSES’ STATION AND A SINGLE SUITE CALL CENTER, RESULTING IN THE CO-LOCATION OF STAFF IN THE ED.  IN ADDITION, THE SPACE THAT WAS PREVIOUSLY OCCUPIED BY THE PSYCHIATRIC SCREENING CENTER WILL BE FULLY RENOVATED FOR OCCUPANCY TO SUPPORT THE TREATMENT OF OUR GERIATRIC PATIENT POPULATION ADMITTED INTO THE ED.  THE RENOVATION AND REDESIGN OF THIS SPACE WILL ALLOW FOR A SAFER AND MORE COMFORTABLE PATIENT ENVIRONMENT AND INCREASED STAFF COLLABORATION, RESULTING IN BETTER CARE AND TREATMENT OF OUR PATIENTS.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PROJECT ABSTRACT:  ONE SKY COMMUNITY SERVICES PROPOSES TO BUY A PROPERTY IN NORTHWOOD, NEW HAMPSHIRE AND CONSTRUCT A GROUP FACILITY THAT WILL HOUSE 6 RELOCATED INDIVIDUALS WHO ARE CURRENTLY LIVING OUT-OF-STATE AND SERVED BY OUR ORGANIZATION.   THERE IS AN URGENT HOUSING SHORTAGE FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES IN NH THAT IS DEPRIVING THESE INDIVIDUALS OF A BASIC HUMAN RIGHT – A DECENT PLACE OF THEIR OWN TO CALL HOME. THE PROBLEM IS WORSENING AS THE NUMBER OF INDIVIDUALS LIVING WITH AGING PARENTS, THOSE WHO REQUIRE 24/7 CARE, AND THOSE WITH INADEQUATE FUNDING AND FINANCIAL MEANS TRY TO MEET THE RAISING LIVING COSTS IN NH. AVAILABLE TREATMENT BEDS NEEDED TO MAINTAIN A PERSON’S RESIDENTIAL PLACEMENT WITHIN THE GEOGRAPHICAL BOUNDARIES OF NEW HAMPSHIRE ARE EXHAUSTED, RESULTING IN NUMEROUS OUT-OF-STATE RESIDENTIAL PLACEMENTS TO FACILITIES IN FLORIDA, PENNSYLVANIA, AND TEXAS. OUT OF STATE PLACEMENT SEPARATES INDIVIDUALS IN NEED OF SUPPORT FROM THEIR FAMILIES AND THE COMMUNITY THEY RELY ON, WHILE SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASING THE SUPPORT THAT INDIVIDUAL NEEDS DOUBLING THE ASSOCIATED COSTS TO CARE FOR THEM.   IT ALSO MAKES MORE SENSE FOR AN ORGANIZATION SUCH AS OURS TO PLAY AN ACTIVE ROLE AS WE CAN ENSURE THAT THESE CHALLENGES ARE MET WITH KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERTISE. ACCESSIBILITY IS JUST ONE OF THE MAJOR FACTORS TO DEAL WITH: PHYSICAL FACTORS SUCH AS WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE, WIDER DOORWAYS, RAISED ELECTRICAL OUTLETS AND LOWER KITCHEN SURFACES, AND THEN ENSURING THAT THE APPROPRIATE SERVICES AND SUPPORTS ARE IN PLACE WITH THE NECESSARY STAFF.   ANOTHER IMPORTANT MOTIVATION IN CREATING THIS HOUSING IS TO INTEGRATE THESE INDIVIDUALS BACK INTO THE SEACOAST COMMUNITY AND OUT OF AN INSTITUTIONAL SETTING. A MOVE THAT THAT HAS FAR-REACHING BENEFITS FOR THE INDIVIDUAL’S MENTAL AND EMOTIONAL WELL-BEING.  ONE SKY COMMUNITY SERVICES, IS A NONPROFIT HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ORGANIZATION, CONTRACTED WITH THE NH DIVISION OF LONG-TERM SUPPORTIVE SERVICES, LAUNCH ED AN INITIATIVE TO CONSTRUCT HOUSING TO HELP ADDRESS THE LOCAL HOUSING SHORTAGE CRISIS FACING OUR CLIENTS.  WE ESTIMATE THAT WITHIN TWO YEARS, BETWEEN 75 TO 100 ADDITIONAL INDIVIDUALS WILL BE AT RISK FOR OUT-OF-STATE SPECIALIZED HOUSING PLACEMENT, FOLLOWING IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF 70 RESIDENTS ALREADY LIVING IN OUT-OF-STATE. THEY DESERVE TO BE RETURNED TO NH WHERE THEY WERE RAISED, CARED FOR AND TO BE BACK IN AN ENVIRONMENT THAT IS QUITE FAMILIAR AND SAFE TO THEM. THE EXORBITANT COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH KEEPING THESE INDIVIDUALS LIVING OUT OF STATE CAN BE MITIGATED BY CREATING HOUSING THAT IS SUPPORTIVE, AFFORDABLE GREATLY REDUCING THE YEARLY COSTS NOW PAID BY THE STATE WHERE THOSE SAVINGS CAN HELP TO PAY FOR FUTURE HOUSING NEEDS.  LIVING WITHOUT STABILITY AND SECURITY THAT FAMILY AND COMMUNITY CAN PROVIDE - CAN DRASTICALLY EXACERBATE HEALTH CONDITIONS AND PREVENT THOSE CONDITIONS FROM BEING ADDRESSED. MANY OF OUR CLIENTS ALSO EXPERIENCE BEHAVIORAL CRISES AND ARE OFTEN TAKEN TO HOSPITAL EMERGENCY ROOMS. MOST WILL NOT BE ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL BUT WILL REMAIN IN THE EMERGENCY ROOM UNTIL AVAILABLE HOUSING CAN BE FOUND. THESE SITUATIONS CAN TAKE DAYS TO MONTHS TO RESOLVE BASED ON THE AVAILABILITY OF TEMPORARY OR PERMANENT TREATMENT BEDS APPROPRIATE TO THE INDIVIDUAL’S NEEDS. SADLY, THESE INDIVIDUALS WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES AND ACQUIRED BRAIN DISORDERS WILL SPEND WEEKS AND MONTHS LANGUISHING IN EMERGENCY ROOM LIMBO.  SUPPLEMENTAL SECURITY INCOME, GENERAL REVENUE DOLLARS, AND PRIVATE DONATIONS PROVIDE LITTLE RELIEF IN ADDRESSING THIS ISSUE. ACCESS TO TREATMENT BEDS WITHIN THE COMMUNITY CAN ONLY BE CREATED BY RESIDENTIAL SUPPORT AGENCIES WITH CLINICAL PROGRAMS COMPREHENSIVE ENOUGH TO MEET THE CHALLENGES OF THE INDIVIDUALS WE SUPPORT.  CONTINUED ACCESS TO A BROAD ARRAY OF SUPPORTS AND SERVICES, COUPLED WITH SAFE AND SECURE HOUSING IS ESSENTIAL AND BUILDS THE FOUNDATION FOR A FULL AND PRODUCTIVE LIFE IN ONE’S COMM

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - NATIONAL ALLIANCE FOR MENTAL ILLNESS, OHIO IS PARTNERING WITH THE MENTAL HEALTH AND RECOVERY SERVICES BOARD OF LUCAS COUNTY TO CONSTRUCT A NEW FACILITY ON STATE LEASED LAND NEAR THE CORNER OF SOUTH DETROIT AND ARLINGTON AVENUES, TOLEDO OHIO. THE LEASED LAND IS AN EMPTY PARCEL BEHIND THE NORTHWEST OHIO PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITAL (NOPH.) JUST AS REHABILITATION CENTERS FOR INDIVIDUALS LEAVING HOSPITAL FOLLOWING A STROKE OR A HIP FRACTURE ARE AVAILABLE, A REHABILITATION CENTER FOR ADULTS LEAVING HOSPITALS WHO SUFFER FROM A MENTAL HEALTH BREAK IS PLANNED FOR NORTHWEST OHIO.  A SIXTEEN BED REHABILITATION CENTER WILL SPECIFICALLY SERVE INDIVIDUALS, 18 YEARS AND OLDER, DISCHARGED FROM A STATE OR PRIVATE PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITAL, WHO NEED ADDITIONAL TREATMENT UNDER A SUPERVISED LIVING ARRANGEMENT. THE CENTER, TO BE NAMED DANI'S PLACE, WILL BE OWNED BY THE LUCAS COUNTY BOARD, OPERATED BY A NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION, AND PROVIDE CLINICALLY APPROPRIATE SERVICES, EPISODIC MEDICAL CARE WITH LINKAGE TO PRIMARY MEDICAL CARE, ASSISTANCE WITH DAILY LIVING SKILLS, MEALS, FAMILY INTEGRATION INTO TREATMENT, DISCHARGE PLAN, REENTRY ASSISTANCE WITH HOUSING AND LINKAGE TO A COMMUNITY MENTAL HEALTH CASE MANAGER.  INDIVIDUALS REFERRED TO DANI'S PLACE WILL BE FROM ONE OF 23 HOME COUNTIES IN NORTHWEST OHIO INCLUDING: LUCAS (THE PROJECT SITE), ALLEN, AUGLAIZE, DARKE, DEFIANCE, ERIE, FULTON, HANCOCK, HARDIN, HENRY, HURON, MERCER, MIAMI, OTTAWA, PAULDING, PUTNAM, SANDUSKY, SENECA, SHELBY, VAN WERT, WILLIAMS, WOOD, AND WYANDOT. OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE REDUCED RECIDIVISM TO MORE COSTLY IN-PATIENT HOSPITALIZATION, REDUCED INCIDENCES OF SUICIDE FOLLOWING HOSPITALIZATION, INCREASED ACCESS TO TREATMENT BEDS, AND IMPROVED DISCHARGE PLANNING WITH HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES. A GEOTECHNICAL ENGINEER WILL EVALUATE THE LAND TO MEET ALL ENVIRONMENTAL AND HISTORICAL REQUIREMENTS FOR CONSTRUCTION.  AN ARCHITECTURAL/ENGINEERING FIRM WILL BE HIRED IN ACCORDANCE WITH ALL REQUIRED BUILDING CODES  AND DESIGN. DESIGN FEATURES WILL ALLOW FOR INPUT FROM THE NONPROFIT PROVIDER AND PEOPLE WITH LIVED EXPERIENCE OF PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITALIZATION. ALL WORK WILL BE MANAGED BY THE FIRM, HPLEX, AN OHIO-BASED, EXPERIENCED HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONAL FIRM, HIRED AS THE OWNERS’ REPRESENTATIVE FOR THE PROJECT.  HPLEX WILL ENSURE ADHERENCE TO ALL FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL REGULATIONS AND CODES, ASSIST WITH SOLICITING AND HIRING OF PROFESSIONALS AND CONTRACTORS, BUDGETING AND COST CONTROLS AND ENSURE QUALITY CONSTRUCTION DELIVERY.  LOCAL AND STATE REGULATIONS FOR BIDDING CONSTRUCTION WORK WILL BE FOLLOWED. THE PROJECT WILL BE A NEW GREENFIELD FACILITY, ESTIMATED AT 20,000 TO 30,000 SQUARE FEET OF RESIDENTIAL SPACE WITH SINGLE ROOMS, SHARED BATHS, COMMUNITY ROOMS, THERAPEUTIC ROOMS, A TEACHING KITCHEN, DINING AREA, RECREATIONAL SPACE, OFFICES, AND STORAGE.  THE BUILDING WILL BE EQUIPPED WITH A SECURITY SYSTEM TO IMPROVE SAFETY FOR THE RESIDENTS AND STAFF. THERE WILL BE IMPROVEMENTS TO THE SITE INCLUDING DRIVEWAY, PARKING, OUTDOOR COURTYARD SPACE FOR THE RESIDENTS. THE TIMELINE FOR THE PROJECT BEGAN IN JULY 2022 AND IS EXPECTED TO MOVE INTO 2023 WITH CONTRACTING BIDDING, AND CONSTRUCTION, CONCLUDING WITH AN OCCUPANCY PERMIT IN 2025. THE FIRST RESIDENT WILL BE TREATED WITH REHABILITATION SERVICES IN DANI'S PLACE BEFORE THE END OF 2025.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE HOPE HILL SOBERING CENTER (HHSC) WILL SERVE THE GREATER MORGANTOWN AND MONONGALIA COUNTY REGION AND IS AN INTEGRAL PLAYER IN KEEPING OUR COMMUNITY HEALTHY.    EACH OF THE STAFF WILL PLAY A VITAL ROLE IN THE FULFILLMENT OF OUR MISSION AND VISION. BETWEEN MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS, AND COUNSELORS, THE HHSC PROVIDES THE UNIQUE ABILITY TO CARE FOR THE RESIDENTS AND VISITORS WHILE IN A VULNERABLE STATE TO ACHIEVE DIVERSION, SAFE SOBERING, AND INTERVENTION. THE CENTER WILL FOSTER A HEALTHY WORKING ENVIRONMENT THAT IS EMPHASIZED THROUGH TEAMWORK AND COLLABORATION TO PROVIDE THE BEST CLIENT CARE.   THE CENTER IS SCHEDULED TO OPEN FALL OF 2022 AND WILL BE A NEWLY RENOVATED 5,100 SQUARE FOOT FACILITY WITH ROOM FOR APPROXIMATELY 20 BEDS. LOCATED WITHIN A LARGER 100,000 SQUARE FOOT FACILITY, OPERATED BY MORGANTOWN COMMUNITY RESOURCES, INC. (MRC), WHICH WILL SERVE AS A PRIMARY HUB FOR SOCIAL SERVICES IN THE AREA. THE MRC IS DEVELOPING THE MAIN FACILITY INTO A ONE-ROOF COMMUNITY SHELTER AND TREATMENT FACILITY. THE FOUR-STORY CAMPUS WILL PROVIDE NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS THE OPPORTUNITY TO COLLABORATE AND SOLVE COMPLEX, COMMUNITY FACING ISSUES IN AN EFFICIENT AND THOUGHTFUL MANNER.  MRC HAS IDENTIFIED THESE ISSUES INTO THREE MAJOR AREAS OF CONCERN:  UNSHELTERED HOMELESSNESS, FOOD INSECURITY, AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE MULTISPECIALTY CENTER WILL BE A MULTI-STORY, MIXED-USE HEALTHCARE FACILITY ADJACENT TO THE HOSPITAL AND WILL OFFER EXPANDED SERVICES INCLUDING PEDIATRIC OPERATIONAL SERVICES FOR SOUTH MISSISSIPPI. THE CENTER WILL ACCOMMODATE SEVERAL NEW AND VITAL PROGRAMS INCLUDING A STATE-OF-THE-ART OUTPATIENT SURGERY CENTER FOR PEDIATRICS, A POST-ANESTHESIA CARE UNIT (PACU) TO SUPPORT PEDIATRIC SPECIALTY, SUBSPECIALTY AND ADULT SURGICAL CARE, SOME OF WHICH ARE CURRENTLY UNAVAILABLE IN SOUTH MISSISSIPPI, AND AN EXPANDED INPATIENT REHAB FACILITY. ADDITIONALLY, THE CENTER WILL HOUSE NEW TELEMEDICINE AND RESIDENCY PROGRAMS.   MEMORIAL AND ITS CLINICS ARE UNABLE TO SURGICALLY TREAT PEDIATRIC PATIENTS, WHICH REQUIRES SOUTH MISSISSIPPI FAMILIES TO TRAVEL OUT OF STATE FOR TREATMENT. THE CENTER WILL PROVIDE THE NEEDED FACILITY SPACE AND COMPONENTS FOR MEMORIAL TO PERFORM PEDIATRIC OUTPATIENT SURGERY, THEREBY PREVENTING FURTHER HEALTHCARE LEAKAGE TO NEIGHBORING STATES AND WILL ALLOW FAMILIES TO BE TREATED IN THEIR OWN COMMUNITY. MEMORIAL HAS PARTNERED WITH A LARGE MISSISSIPPI ACADEMIC AND MEDICAL FACILITY TO SUPPLY THESE SERVICES AND ALLOW CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES TO STAY HOME TO RECEIVE CARE IN THEIR COMMUNITY.   THE FACILITY WILL HOUSE A 60-BED INPATIENT REHAB FACILITY WHICH IS CRITICAL TO A PHYSICIAN’S ABILITY TO ENSURE CONTINUITY OF CARE, FROM WELLNESS TO PRIMARY AND EMERGENCY CARE TO ACUTE CARE AND ULTIMATELY TO REHAB OR LONG-TERM CARE. MEMORIAL CURRENTLY HAS 33 BEDS THAT ARE FREQUENTLY AT CAPACITY FORCING FAMILIES TO LEAVE THE LOWER SIX COUNTIES FOR TREATMENT; THE ADDITIONAL BEDS FOR THE INPATIENT REHAB FACILITY ARE CRITICAL TO MEMORIAL’S ABILITY TO SERVE SOUTH MISSISSIPPI IN THE FUTURE.  TELEMEDICINE CAPABILITIES, WHICH WILL BE HOUSED IN THE CENTER, ARE A COMPONENT OF THE MEMORIAL VIRTUAL MEDICINE PROGRAM (MVM) AND WOULD PROVIDE DIRECT CARE TO RESIDENTS IN THEIR HOMES AND PLACES OF EMPLOYMENT, COVERING THE ENTIRETY OF SOUTH MISSISSIPPI.  THE CENTER WILL FE ATURE AN AUDITORIUM, HIGH-TECHNOLOGY CLASSROOMS, AND ADMINISTRATIVE SPACE FOR THE COMMUNITY TO ESTABLISH OUTREACH PROGRAMS. CASEWORKERS, EDUCATORS, NURSE NAVIGATORS, CLINICIANS AND SUPPORT STAFF WILL BE ABLE TO ADDRESS CURRENT AND FUTURE SOCIAL DETERMINANTS THAT SHAPE THE TYPICAL HEALTH ISSUES FACED BY MISSISSIPPIANS.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PROJECT ABSTRACT  ADDRESS: 700 N SPRING STREET, CALIENTE, NEVADA 89008 PROJECT DIRECTOR: MELISSA ROWE, ADMINISTRATOR/CEO PROJECT DIRECTOR CONTACT: PHONE - (775) 726-8005; FAX -N/A PROJECT DIRECTOR EMAIL: MISSIE@GCDMC.ORG WEBSITE: WWW.GCDMC.ORG GRANT PROGRAM FUNDS REQUESTED: ALL FUNDS REQUESTED AT THIS TIME ARE FROM CDS HRSA-22-134.   LINCOLN COUNTY HOSPITAL DISTRICT, D/B/A GROVER C. DILS MEDICAL CENTER (THE MEDICAL CENTER), IS A HOSPITAL DISTRICT FORMED UNDER THE PROVISIONS OF THE NEVADA REVISED STATUTES AND OPERATES A FOUR-BED ACUTE-CARE CRITICAL ACCESS HOSPITAL IN CALIENTE, NEVADA.  THE MEDICAL CENTER ALSO PROVIDES SKILLED NURSING SERVICES AND OPERATES TWO PRIMARY CARE CLINICS.  THE MEDICAL CENTER SERVES ALL OF LINCOLN COUNTY, NEVADA, WHICH INCLUDES THE TOWNS OF PIOCHE, PANACA, CALIENTE, ALAMO, RACHEL, AND URSINE.  LINCOLN COUNTY HAS AN ESTIMATED POPULATION OF 4,500 RESIDENTS BASED ON THE RESULTS OF THE 2020 CENSUS.  THE EXISTING CAMPUS IS SPREAD AMONG MULTIPLE OLD, OUTDATED BUILDINGS, WITH MANY FACTORS LIMITING ITS CURRENT OPERATIONS AND FUTURE DEVELOPMENT AND GROWTH.  THERE IS NO ABILITY TO GROW SERVICES IN THE HOSPITAL DUE TO CODE ISSUES WHICH PREVENT ANY RENOVATIONS/ADDITIONS WITHOUT BRINGING THE WHOLE FACILITY UP TO CODE.  NO BED CAPACITY EXISTS TO ACCOMMODATE GROWTH IN ACUTE OR SWING PATIENTS.  THERE IS NO SURGICAL OPERATING ROOM FOR MINOR PROCEDURES OR ENDOSCOPY PROCEDURES (I.E., COLONOSCOPIES).  MEDICAL CENTER STAFF WOULD IDEALLY HAVE ALL HOSPITAL, CLINIC AND THERAPY SERVICES LOCATED UNDER ONE ROOF.  SERVICES SUCH AS CT, INPATIENT AND OUTPATIENT THERAPY, AND CLINIC ARE LOCATED OUTSIDE OF THE HOSPITAL AND IS DIFFICULT FOR PATIENT SERVICE AND ACCESS.  IN ADDITION TO THE DISCONNECTED CAMPUS LAYOUT, INABILITY TO RENOVATE THE EXISTING FACILITY DUE TO CODE COMPLIANCE IMPLICATIONS, AND CAPACITY LIMITATIONS, THE EXISTING BUILDINGS ALSO SUFFER FROM SIGNIFICANT INFRASTRUCTURE ISSUES, INCLUDING LEAKS IN THE ROOF, CONSTANT MAINTENANCE NEEDS FOR TH E HVAC AND PLUMBING SYSTEMS, AND THE OVERALL HIGH UTILITY COST TO RUN AND MAINTAIN AN OLD, INEFFICIENT BUILDING.  IT WOULD NOT BE FINANCIALLY RESPONSIBLE TO INVEST SIGNIFICANT DOLLARS INTO AN OLD INFRASTRUCTURE SYSTEM, AS THOSE SYSTEMS ARE LIKELY TO CONTINUE TO BREAK DOWN AND DON’T CREATE ANY PATIENT ACCESS OR PATIENT SATISFACTION IMPROVEMENTS.   ULTIMATELY, THE MEDICAL CENTER PLANS TO UTILIZE THE PROPOSED GRANT FUNDS, IN LINE WITH THE PURPOSE IT IS BEING PROVIDED FOR, TO COVER PORTIONS OF THE ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN AND ENGINEERING SERVICES COST, AS WELL AS STRATEGIC PLANNING INITIATIVES, OF A FUTURE CAMPUS REPLACEMENT PROJECT TO ADDRESS THE DEFICIENCIES NOTED ABOVE BY EXPANDING THE LEVEL OF SERVICES OFFERED AND INCREASE THE QUALITY OF CARE FOR RESIDENTS OF LINCOLN COUNTY.  AS THIS IS A DESIGN ONLY PROJECT, ONLY HIGH-LEVEL SPECIFICATIONS HAVE BEEN ESTIMATED, AS THE SPECIFICATIONS NEEDED WOULD BE THE OUTPUT FROM THE DESIGN PROCESS.  HIGH-LEVEL ESTIMATES RANGE FROM 25,000 – 30,000 SQUARE FEET TO CONSTRUCT A REPLACEMENT FACILITY, INCLUDING A HOSPITAL WITH INPATIENT, SWING-BED, OBSERVATION, AND LONG-TERM CARE SERVICES, AS WELL AS THE MAJOR ANCILLARY SERVICES INCLUDING EMERGENCY, MINOR SURGERY, IMAGING MODALITIES, LAB, PHARMACY, AND PHYSICAL AND OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - KIDS IN NEED OF DENTISTRY (KIND) IS A 109-YEAR OLD DENTAL NON-PROFIT PROVIDING FULL-SERVICE DENTAL AND ORTHODONTIA CARE AND EDUCATION TO CHILDREN IN NEED, REGARDLESS OF ABILITY TO PAY. KIND SEEKS TO RENOVATE AN EXISTING SPACE FOR A NEW PEDIATRIC DENTAL CLINIC IN COMMERCE CITY, AS PART OF A COLLABORATIVE CO-LOCATION PROJECT WITH PARTNERING SERVICE AGENCIES SYNERGISTICALLY ALIGNED TO SERVE LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AT THE C4: COMMERCE CITY COMMUNITY CAMPUS.    KIND HAS SERVED IN COMMERCE CITY FOR OVER 10 YEARS VIA THEIR CURRENT CLINIC AND SCHOOL-BASED PROGRAMS, SERVING OVER 2,000 ADAMS COUNTY RESIDENTS ANNUALLY. WITH A REQUIREMENT TO RELOCATE, KIND RECOGNIZES AN OPPORTUNITY TO INCREASE CAPACITY, (WHICH ARE MAXIMIZED AT CURRENT LOCATION), AND EXPAND AVAILABLE SERVICES, CONTINUING TO PROVIDE HIGH-QUALITY, AFFORDABLE DENTAL CARE WITH DIGNITY AS PART OF AN INNOVATIVE PATIENT-CENTERED EXPERIENCE. OUR CLINIC WOULD SHARE SPACE WITH A PARTNER PEDIATRIC PRIMARY AND MENTAL HEALTH PROVIDER WITHIN THE C4.   THROUGH CO-LOCATION AND COORDINATION AMONG OUR C4 PARTNERS, CHILDREN, FAMILIES AND OTHERS WILL HAVE ONE-STOP ACCESS TO EARLY CHILDHOOD SUPPORT, PROMOTORAS, COMMUNITY ORGANIZING, FOOD AND NUTRITION RESOURCES, HOUSING AND MORE. ACCESS TO THESE SERVICES HELPS ENSURE COMMUNITY MEMBERS HAVE THE CARE AND SUPPORT THEY NEED TO TRULY ACHIEVE EQUITABLE HEALTH OUTCOMES AND OVERALL WELLBEING.   THE COMMERCE CITY COMMUNITY CAMPUS (C4) WILL ALSO BECOME A MODEL FOR OTHER COLORADO COMMUNITIES TO LEARN FROM AND REPLICATE. THE PRIVATE SECTOR HAS A NUMBER OF SUCCESSFUL CLIENT SERVICE MODELS LIKE SUPER TARGET, AND C4 WILL BUILD UPON THEM TO ADD NEW LAYERS OF INNOVATION AND ACCESS. THE AREA IN AND AROUND C4 IS ON TRACK TO BECOME A VIBRANT COMMUNITY RESOURCE HUB ONCE AGAIN.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - IN 2014, THE COMMUNITY OF FLINT EXPERIENCED A HARROWING PUBLIC HEALTH EMERGENCY: THE FLINT WATER CRISIS. THIS EVENT, CAUSED BY UNSAFE AMOUNTS OF LEAD IN CITY DRINKING WATER, EXPOSED 30,000 CHILDREN TO DANGEROUS LEVELS OF THE NEUROTOXIN, RESULTING IN WIDESCALE BEHAVIORAL, EMOTIONAL, AND NEURODEVELOPMENTAL CONDITIONS. AS THE PUBLIC MENTAL HEALTH CARE PROVIDER FOR THE PAST 50 YEARS, GHS HAS BEEN A FRONTLINE RESPONDER TO THIS CRISIS, PROVIDING TREATMENT TO THOUSANDS OF CHILDREN IN THE AREA AND, IN 2019, ESTABLISHING THE NEURODEVELOPMENTAL CENTER FOR EXCELLENCE (NCE). TO ADDRESS INCREASES IN THE NEED FOR INTERVENTION AND SUPPORT, GHS AND GFMHF ARE WORKING TOGETHER TO ESTABLISH THE GHS CENTER FOR CHILDREN'S INTEGRATED SERVICES, WHICH WILL PROVIDE ESSENTIAL AND HIGH-QUALITY BEHAVIORAL AND PHYSICAL HEALTH SERVICES AND SUPPORT TO CHILDREN AND FAMILIES STRUGGLING WITH A WIDE RANGE OF CONCERNS, INCLUDING EFFECTS CAUSED BY THE FLINT WATER CRISIS.  THE DESIGN FOR THE NEW FACILITY BRINGS TOGETHER THREE CORE PROGRAMMING AREAS WITHIN GHS’ CHILDREN’S BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PROGRAM - THE NCE, AUTISM SERVICES, AND CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES – ALONG WITH A NEW FEDERALLY QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTER (FQHC). THE PROPOSED 60,000 SQUARE FOOT BUILDING WILL BE DESIGNED TO SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASE THE CAPACITY AND QUALITY OF SERVICES AND SUPPORT TO MEET THE ONGOING AND EXPANDING NEEDS OF GENESEE COUNTY’S CHILDREN AND FAMILIES. SPECIFICALLY, THE FACILITY WILL INCLUDE SPACES FOR THE AUTISM PROGRAM TO PROVIDE STATE-OF-THE-ART TREATMENT; MODERN OFFICE FACILITIES FOR THE CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES AND COMMUNITY OUTREACH PROGRAMS TO SUPPORT THE NEEDS OF A HIGHLY MOBILE, COMMUNITY- BASED STAFF; AND SPECIALIZED CLINICAL FACILITIES FOR THE NCE TO ACCOMMODATE THE GROWING NEED FOR ASSESSMENTS AS WELL AS TO ATTRACT TOP RESEARCHERS.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL PROVIDE: COMPREHENSIVE NEUROPSYCHOLOGICAL EVALUATIONS FOR AT LEAST 750 CHILDREN PER YEAR, MORE THAN DOUBLING THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN AND FAMILIES SERVED IN THE NCE'S FIRST YEAR; CASE MANAGEMENT SERVICES FOR 342 LEAD-AFFECTED FAMILIES, HELPING THEM NAVIGATE MEDICAL, EDUCATIONAL, AND OTHER COMMUNITY RESOURCES AS PART OF THEIR CARE PLAN; COMMUNITY OUTREACH, FAMILY NAVIGATION, AND OTHER COMMUNITY SERVICES TO 3,845 RESIDENTS; AND THE ADDITION OF THE FQHC WILL IMPROVE THE CONTINUUM OF CARE FOR PATIENTS AS WELL AS PROVIDE AN IMPORTANT SOURCE OF PRIMARY CARE, BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES, AND DENTAL SERVICES.  ESTABLISHING THE GHS CENTER FOR CHILDREN'S INTEGRATED SERVICES WILL ALLOW FAMILIES TO COME TO ONE SINGLE LOCATION FOR ALL OF THEIR CHILDREN'S TREATMENT AND SUPPORT NEEDS. THIS COMPREHENSIVE BUILDING WILL SAVE FAMILIES TIME, REDUCE TRANSPORTATION CONCERNS, AND ALLOW FOR BETTER CARE COORDINATION. FAMILIES THAT MAY HAVE OTHERWISE NOT BEEN ABLE TO UTILIZE DIFFERENT TREATMENT OPTIONS BECAUSE OF TIME AND/OR TRANSPORTATION CONCERNS WILL NOW BE MORE LIKELY TO ENGAGE IN SERVICES, ALLOWING MORE CHILDREN TO RECEIVE THE CARE THEY NEED.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE GATEWAY COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTER, INC., (GCHC) PROPOSED WEST CLINIC LOCATED AT 1702 LAFAYETTE ST., IS SITUATED ALONG THE U.S. – MEXICO BORDER AND IS MAINLY COMPRISED OF LOW-INCOME MINORITY POPULATIONS. LAREDO, TEXAS HAS BEEN CONFIRMED BY THE HEALTH RESOURCES AND SERVICES ADMINISTRATION (HRSA) AS A HEALTH PROFESSIONAL SHORTAGE (HPSA) AND A MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED AREA (MUA) AND MAKES UP ABOUT 14.8%  OF THE ENTIRE WEBB COUNTY POPULATION. ABOUT 82.6% OF THE RESIDENTS LIVING IN THE VICINITY OF THE PROPOSED WEST SIDE CLINIC ARE LIVING BELOW THE 200% POVERTY LEVEL AND ARE UNINSURED. MANY OF THE RESIDENTS LIVING IN THIS AREA FACE VARIOUS HEALTH BARRIERS LIKE TRANSPORTATION AND FINANCIAL ISSUES. THESE INDIVIDUALS ALSO SUFFER FROM MISINFORMATION AND APPREHENSION WHICH MAKE IT DIFFICULT FOR RESIDENTS TO SEEK AND RECEIVE PROPER HEALTHCARE. IN THE PAST YEAR, ABOUT 28.7% OF THE TARGET POPULATION DELAYED OR REFUSED TO SEEK MEDICAL CARE BECAUSE OF THE HIGH COSTS.   GCHC IS ONE OF THE LEADING PRIMARY HEALTHCARE CLINICS SERVING THE TRI-COUNTY REGION OF WEBB, ZAPATA, AND JIM HOGG COUNTY IN SOUTH TEXAS. THROUGH ITS CLINICS AND THE PROPOSED GATEWAY CHC WEST CLINIC, GCHC HOPES TO ALLEVIATE THE HEALTH ISSUES PLAGUING THE LOCAL COMMUNITIES BY OFFERING A WIDE ARRAY OF MEDICAL CARE SERVICES PROVIDED BY PHYSICIANS AND/OR MID-LEVEL PRACTITIONERS. PREVENTIVE HEALTH SERVICES INCLUDE PRENATAL CARE, IMMUNIZATIONS, DIABETES AWARENESS AND DIABETES SELF-MANAGEMENT COURSES, EDUCATION PROGRAMS, CANCER SCREENING PROGRAMS, AND FAMILY PLANNING SERVICES. SUPPORT SERVICES INCLUDE PHARMACY, X-RAYS, AND LABORATORY TESTS. IN AN EFFORT TO CONTINUE ITS GOAL OF CREATING A ONE-STOP-SHOP FOR HEALTHCARE IN THE TRI-COUNTY REGION, GCHC HAS ALSO ADDED PREVENTIVE AND RESTORATIVE DENTAL CARE TO ITS LIST OF PREEMPTIVE SERVICES AS WELL AS BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES.   THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE WEST CLINIC WILL ENABLE GCHC TO PROVIDE THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITY WITH ACCESS TO CARE MAKING IT AN IMPORTANT I NTEGRATION INTO THE AREA. CURRENTLY, ABOUT 16% OF THE TOTAL GCHC REGISTERED PATIENT POPULATION RESIDES IN THIS AREA. THUS GCHC’S PROPOSED CONSTRUCTION PROJECT IS IMPERATIVE FOR THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY. GCHC PROPOSES TO CONSTRUCT A 5,000 SQUARE FOOT CLINIC, CAPABLE OF MEETING THE COMMUNITY NEEDS. THE LOCATION SELECTED FOR THIS PROJECT CURRENTLY FUNCTIONS AS A PARKING LOT AND MEASURES ABOUT THREE-QUARTERS OF AN ACRE (34,692 SQ. FT.). THE CLINIC WILL BE EQUIPPED WITH ALL THE NECESSARY MEDICAL SPACES, EQUIPMENT, AND TECHNOLOGY SUITED FOR ALL SERVICES PROVIDED. IT WILL ALSO BE OUTFITTED WITH THE NECESSARY ANTIMICROBIAL SAFETY FEATURES (WALL PAINTS, TILES, VENTILATION SYSTEMS) THAT PROTECT THE STRUCTURE AGAINST A BROAD SPECTRUM OF BACTERIA, MOLD AND MILDEW. THESE MODIFICATIONS WILL ACCOMMODATE THE HOSPITAL GRADE STANDARDS OF CLEANLINESS AND ARE IN A DIRECT RESPONSE TO REDUCE CONTAGION OF COVID-19 AND OTHER VIRUSES.   THE GCHC WEST CLINIC WILL BE LOCATED IN AN AREA THAT IS NOT CONSIDERED A HISTORIC PROPERTY NOR DOES IT SIT ON TRIBAL LANDS. THIS AREA WAS SELECTED BECAUSE OF THE DIRE FINANCIAL NEED THE SURROUNDING POPULATION IS CURRENTLY FACING. THUS, GCHC’S PRIORITY IS TO PROVIDE EVERYONE WITH QUALITY HEALTHCARE AND THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY WILL ENSURE GCHC’S ACHIEVES ITS MISSION.    SOURCE: MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED AREA-HTTPS://MAPS.UDSMAPPER.ORG/MAP?RESET=TRUE

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE FREE CLINIC OF MERIDIAN, A 501C3 ORGANIZATION, IS REQUESTING FUNDING FOR EXPANSION OF ITS CURRENT FACILITY.  THE EXPANSION WOULD INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: 1.	ADDITION OF TWO EXAM ROOMS 2.	ADDITION OF A MULTI-USE ROOM FOR PHYSICAL THERAPY, MENTAL HEALTH COUNSELING, AND BOARD MEETINGS 3.	ADDITION OF ONE OFFICE 4.	ADDITION OF STORAGE SPACE 5.	ENLARGEMENT OF EXISTING LAB 6.	DIVISION OF CURRENT MULTI-USE ROOM INTO ONE OFFICE AND A MEDICATION ROOM 7.	REFIGURING OF EXISTING HANDICAP ACCESSIBLE RESTROOM  THE CLINIC IS CURRENTLY HOUSED IN A SMALL CLINIC PROVIDED BY ANDERSON REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTER.  HOWEVER, AS A RESULT OF OUR GROWTH, WE ARE IN NEED OF ADDITIONAL SPACE IN ORDER TO SERVE THE NEEDS OF OUR PATIENTS. ARCHITECTURAL SERVICES FOR THE PROJECT HAVE ALREADY BEEN DONATED.   THE EXPANSION OF THE FREE CLINIC OF MERIDIAN BUILDING IS NECESSARY DUE TO THE GROWING PATIENT POPULATION.  THE CLINIC SERVES ADULTS WHO ARE INELIGIBLE FOR MEDICAID OR MEDICARE AND WHO EARN 200% OR LESS OF THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL.  THE PATIENT POPULATION HAS GROWN FROM A FEW HUNDRED IN 2014 TO MORE THAN 1200 IN 2022.  MOST OF OUR PATIENTS ARE EMPLOYED IN LOW-PAYING JOBS THAT DO NOT OFFER MEDICAL INSURANCE.  WE PROVIDE PRIMARY HEALTHCARE AND REFERRALS FOR SPECIALIZED CARE.  THE EXISTING CLINIC HAS FOUR EXAM ROOMS AND A SMALL LAB.  THE DAILY VOLUNTEER MEDICAL STAFF GENERALLY CONSISTS OF TWO PHYSICIANS AND SEVERAL NURSES AND/OR MEDICAL ASSISTANTS.  THE ADDITION OF TWO EXAM ROOMS AND THE ENLARGEMENT OF THE EXISTING LAB WOULD ALLOW US TO SEE MORE PATIENTS PER DAY IN A MORE EFFICIENT TIMEFRAME.  IN ADDITION, ONE OF THE ADDITIONAL EXAM ROOMS WOULD BE EQUIPPED TO ALLOW PHYSICIANS TO PERFORM MINOR PROCEDURES SUCH AS I&D OF ABSCESSES, MOLE AND LESION REMOVAL, AND BIOPSY OF SKIN LESIONS.  THE ADDITIONAL OFFICE WOULD PROVIDE A PRIVATE SPACE FOR BOTH DISCUSSIONS WITH PATIENTS AND TELEHEALTH CALLS.  THE ADDITIONAL MULTI-USE ROOM WOULD PROVIDE SPACE FOR PHYSICAL THERAPY, MENTAL HEALTH TH ERAPY, AND OTHER SPECIALIZED NEEDS.  THE FREE CLINIC SERVES PATIENTS IN EIGHT RURAL COUNTIES OF EAST MISSISSIPPI AND WEST ALABAMA.  THE PERCENTAGE OF UNINSURED ADULTS IN THOSE COUNTIES RANGES FROM 16.6% TO 22.1%.  THOSE LIVING BELOW THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL RANGES FROM 22% TO 22.7%.   THE FREE CLINIC OF MERIDIAN FOCUSES ON THE MANAGEMENT OF CHRONIC ILLNESSES WHICH REQUIRE CONSISTENT CARE.  IN OUR SERVICE AREA, RESIDENTS DIAGNOSED WITH TYPE 2 DIABETES RANGES FROM 12.8% TO 15.4%; HYPERTENSION 34.2% TO 46.3%; AND HIGH CHOLESTEROL 34.8% TO 42%, ALL OF WHICH ARE RISK FACTORS FOR CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE WHICH IS THE LEADING CAUSE OF DEATH IN BOTH MISSISSIPPI AND ALABAMA.  THE LACK OF CONSISTENT CARE FOR THESE CHRONIC ILLNESSES PLACES EACH UNINSURED INDIVIDUAL AT A HIGHER RISK FOR LIFE THREATENING COMPLICATIONS, WHICH INCREASES THE BURDEN ON AREA HOSPITALS, MANY OF WHICH ARE SMALL RURAL FACILITIES THAT ARE ALREADY STRUGGLING TO REMAIN OPEN.  THE FREE CLINIC OF MERIDIAN IS TOTALLY SUPPORTED BY GRANTS AND DONATIONS.  RUSH HEALTH SYSTEMS PROVIDES LAB SERVICES THAT WE ARE UNABLE TO PROCESS IN OUR SMALL SPACE.  PATIENT CARE IS PROVIDED BY VOLUNTEER PHYSICIANS AND NURSE PRACTITIONERS.  OUR PARTNERSHIP WITH PRACTITIONERS EC HEALTHNET’S RURAL FAMILY RESIDENCY PROGRAM PROVIDES NOT ONLY CARE FOR OUR PATIENTS, BUT ALSO INVALUABLE EXPERIENCE FOR THESE YOUNG DOCTORS, MANY OF WHOM HAVE CHOSEN TO STAY IN RURAL AREAS OF MISSISSIPPI AFTER COMPLETING THEIR RESIDENCY.  NURSING SERVICES ARE PROVIDED BY VOLUNTEER NURSES AND A PARTNERSHIP WITH AREA NURSING EDUCATION PROGRAMS.  BEGINNING IN 2022, STUDENTS FROM THE PHYSICIAN ASSISTANT PROGRAM THROUGH MISSISSIPPI STATE UNIVERSITY WILL ALSO EARN CLINICAL HOURS IN OUR CLINIC.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ADDRESS: 8221 WILLOW OAKS CORPORATE DR, FAIRFAX, VA 22031 PROJECT DIRECTOR: SEBASTIAN TEZNA CONTACT PHONE: 703-207-7788 CONTACT EMAIL: SEBASTIAN.TEZNA@FAIRFAXCOUNTY.GOV  WEBSITE ADDRESS: WWW.FAIRFAXCOUNTY.GOV/CSB  PROJECT DESCRIPTION: THE FAIRFAX-FALLS CHURCH COMMUNITY SERVICES BOARD’S (CSB) SHARON BULOVA CENTER FOR COMMUNITY HEALTH RENOVATION PROJECT WILL SERVE TO ENHANCE A CRITICAL COMMUNITY-BASED BEHAVIORAL HEALTH TREATMENT CENTER THAT PROVIDES 24/7/365 ACCESS TO SERVICES. IN VIRGINIA, CSBS SERVE AS THE PUBLIC BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PROVIDERS IN COMMUNITIES. THE CENTER SERVES INDIVIDUALS FROM A LARGE GEOGRAPHIC AREA – OVER 400 SQUARE MILES. COUNTY LEADERS SUPPORT A CONTINUUM OF CRISIS SERVICES WITH STRONG JUSTICE-BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PARTNERSHIPS. THE RENOVATION PROJECT SEEKS TO MEET GROWING COMMUNITY NEEDS.  THE DESIGN AND SPACE ARE NOT CONDUCIVE TO THE GROWTH OF PROGRAMS AND SERVICES PROVIDED AT THE CENTER. THIS LOCATION OFFERS 24/7 EMERGENCY BEHAVIORAL HEALTH/ASSESSMENT SERVICES AND PROVIDES AN ARRAY OF OTHER BEHAVIORAL HEALTH AND WELLNESS/HEALTH PROMOTION SERVICES. RENOVATION IS NEEDED TO SUSTAIN AND EXPAND OPERATIONS AS THERE HAVE BEEN SIGNIFICANT PROGRAMMING CHANGES SINCE THE OPENING OF THE BUILDING IN 2016.   THE REDESIGN WILL EXPAND THE CAPACITY FOR SERVING INDIVIDUALS IN A BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CRISIS IN THE LEAST RESTRICTIVE SETTING. THE RENOVATIONS WILL PROVIDE PROPER DESIGN TO ADDRESS A GAP IN OUR CONTINUUM OF CRISIS SERVICES BY IMPLEMENTING A PROGRAM TO DE-ESCALATE INDIVIDUALS’ LEVEL OF DISTRESS AND PROVIDE AN ALTERNATIVE TO AN EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT/INPATIENT/RESIDENTIAL LEVEL OF CARE. THIS 23-HOUR PROGRAM IS TO ENSURE INDIVIDUALS STRUGGLING WITH BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CRISES ARE SERVED IN THE LEAST RESTRICTIVE SETTING. OFTEN THESE INDIVIDUALS HAVE LONG WAIT TIMES IN BUSY EMERGENCY DEPARTMENTS, WHICH IS NOT CONDUCIVE TO MEETING THEIR IMMEDIATE BEHAVIORAL HEALTH NEEDS. THIS MULTI-DISCIPLINARY APPROACH TO BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE INCLUDES LAW ENFORCEM ENT, PEER SUPPORT SPECIALISTS, NURSES, AND CLINICIANS AND REQUIRES AN EFFICIENT SPACE. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO ADDRESS SECURITY CONCERNS THAT HAVE EMERGED AT THE CENTER AND WILL BE NEEDED FOR THE 23-HOUR PROGRAM THE RENOVATIONS WILL HELP PROVIDE THE PROPER DESIGN TO BEST IMPLEMENT THIS PROGRAM.  THE CENTER IS A CRITICAL COMPONENT OF THE COUNTY’S CRISIS CONTINUUM. A COMMUNITY THE SIZE OF FAIRFAX (1.2 MILLION RESIDENTS) REQUIRES MULTIPLE SERVICES ALONG A CONTINUUM TO ENSURE EQUITABLE CRISIS RESPONSE AND LINKAGE TO SERVICES. THE COUNTY LAUNCHED ITS DIVERSION FIRST INITIATIVE IN 2016. DIVERSION FIRST PROVIDES ALTERNATIVES TO INCARCERATION FOR PEOPLE WITH MENTAL ILLNESS, CO-OCCURRING SUBSTANCE USE DISORDERS, OR DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES, WHO ENCOUNTER THE CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM FOR LOW-LEVEL OFFENSES. THE GOAL IS TO INTERCEDE AND PROVIDE ASSESSMENT, TREATMENT OR NEEDED SUPPORT TO PREVENT REPEATED ENCOUNTERS WITH THE CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM, PROMOTE A SAFER COMMUNITY, AND ENHANCE PUBLIC SAFETY.   DIVERSION FIRST PROVIDES SIGNIFICANT ECONOMIC BENEFITS TO THE COUNTY AS IT IS FAR MORE COST-EFFECTIVE TO SERVE INDIVIDUALS IN THE COMMUNITY THAN TO INCARCERATE THEM. IT COSTS APPROXIMATELY $181 PER DAY TO HOLD AN INDIVIDUAL IN THE ADULT DETENTION CENTER. BY CONTRAST, IT COSTS $60 PER DAY TO PROVIDE SUPPORTIVE COMMUNITY RESIDENTIAL SERVICES AND $21 PER DAY TO PROVIDE INTENSIVE CASE MANAGEMENT. ADDITIONALLY, THE DAILY SAVINGS FROM AVOIDING A HOSPITALIZATION IS $959 PER INDIVIDUAL.  THE CENTER IS A KEY COMPONENT OF DIVERSION FIRST. THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE COUNTY’S SIGNIFICANT LOCAL INVESTMENTS IN COMMUNITY-BASED BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CRISIS SERVICES. EXAMPLES OF CURRENT CRISIS CONTINUUM SERVICES INCLUDE 24/7/365 ONSITE LAW ENFORCEMENT; MEDICAL ASSESSMENT FOR PSYCHIATRIC/CRISIS STABILIZATION ADMISSION; A MULTI-DISCIPLINARY COMMUNITY RESPONSE TEAM; 23-HOUR CRISIS STABILIZATION BEDS; AND A REGIONAL HUB FOR CONTRACTED SERVICES F

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - AGENCY:  EL PROYECTO DEL BARRIO INC ADDRESS:  8932 WOODMAN AVENUE, ARLETA, CA 91331 PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: CORINNE SANCHEZ, JD, PRESIDENT AND CEO CONTACT PHONE NUMBERS: (818) 810-3500, FAX (818) 221-3750 EMAIL ADDRESS: CORINNESA@ELPROYECTO.US WEBSITE ADDRESS:  HTTPS://WWW.ELPROYECTO.US/ FUNDING REQUEST: $1,000,000    TOTAL PROJECT BUDGET:  $1,410,000  APPLICANT OVERVIEW EL PROYECTO DEL BARRIO, INC. HAS PROVIDED AN EXTENSIVE ARRAY OF HEALTH AND MEDICAL, EMPLOYMENT, BEHAVIORAL HEALTH AND CHILD DEVELOPMENT SERVICES TO THE COMMUNITY FOR MORE THAN 50 YEARS.  FOUNDED IN 1971 TO PROVIDE SERVICES TO THE NORTHEAST SAN FERNANDO VALLEY, EL PROYECTO HAS EXPANDED ITS SERVICES TO THE ENTIRE SAN FERNANDO VALLEY, THE SAN GABRIEL VALLEY AND EAST LOS ANGELES. THE ORGANIZATION INFUSES CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE STRATEGIES WITH AN AFFIRMATION OF FAMILY VALUES AND TRADITIONS THROUGHOUT ITS ORGANIZATION AND SERVICES.  THIS APPROACH HAS ESTABLISHED EL PROYECTO AS A TRUSTED SERVICE PROVIDER THAT CREATES A SAFE AND RESPECTFUL ENVIRONMENT FOR ITS CLIENTS.  EL PROYECTO WORKS WITH COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, CITIES, LOS ANGELES COUNTY, THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA AND THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT, SMALL COMPANIES AND MAJOR CORPORATIONS TO FUND COMPREHENSIVE COMMUNITY AND ADVOCACY SERVICES FOR ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED YOUTH AND ADULTS. THE SIX (6) EL PROYECTO DEL BARRIO INC HEALTH CLINICS EACH PROVIDE ACCESSIBLE AND AFFORDABLE HEALTH CARE SERVICES TO THE UNDERSERVED POPULATION IN SAN FERNANDO VALLEY AND SAN GABRIEL VALLEY COMMUNITIES.  MORE THAN 175,000 PATIENT VISITS (IN PERSON AND VIRTUAL) OCCUR EACH YEAR THROUGH OUR CLINICS. OUR HEALTH SERVICES INCLUDE FAMILY PRACTICE, OBSTETRICS AND GYNECOLOGY, PEDIATRICS, PODIATRY, BEHAVIORAL HEALTH, HIV TESTING AND TREATMENT, FAMILY PLANNING AND COUNSELING, COMPREHENSIVE PERINATAL SERVICES PROGRAM, WOMEN’S HEALTH, MAMMOGRAMS, IMMUNIZATIONS, RADIOLOGY, PHARMACY, LABORATORY, AND DENTAL.   PROJECT SUMMARY THE PROJECT LOCATION IS THE S. MARK TAPER FOR A HEALTHY COMMUNITY-WINNETKA CLINIC,  20800 SHERMAN WAY, WINNETKA, CA 91306. THIS PROJECT IS A RECONFIGURATION OF THE EXISTING INTERIOR SPACE OF THE CLINIC. THE WINNETKA CLINIC IS A THREE (3) STORY BUILDING WITH A TOTAL OF 27,423 SQUARE FEET OF INTERIOR SPACE.  THE AREA PROPOSED FOR IMPROVEMENTS IS WITHIN A PORTION OF THE 9,141 SQUARE FOOT SECOND FLOOR OF THE BUILDING.  THIS PROJECT-SPECIFIC AREA INCLUDES APPROXIMATELY 3,500 SQUARE FEET (PLEASE SEE ATTACHMENT 3).  THE PROPOSAL IS TO TAKE THE CURRENT OFFICE SPACE AND CONVERT IT INTO EIGHT (8) MEDICAL EXAM ROOMS FOR PEDIATRIC AND OB/GYN PATIENT CARE, INCLUDING AN ACCOMPANYING PATIENT-WAITING AREA AND ‘HUB’ FOR ADMINISTRATIVE AND MEDICAL STAFF, AS WELL AS STORAGE AND SPECIALTY SPACE.  THIS RENOVATED AREA WILL BE ADJACENT TO A PHARMACY AND DENTAL OFFICE SUITE, WHICH ARE BOTH LOCATED ON THE SAME FLOOR.  THE PROPOSED START DATE OF WORK, POST NOTICE OF AWARD, IS AUGUST 20, 2022, WITH AN END/COMPLETION DATE OF JULY 9, 2024, FOR A TOTAL OF 96 WEEKS.  THIS TIMELINE ACCOUNTS FOR THE COMPLEXITY OF THE PROJECT AND INCLUDES TYPICAL, ANTICIPATED DELAYS EXPERIENCED DUE TO THE INSPECTIONS AND PERMITTING PROCESSES IN THE CITY OF LOS ANGELES. WITHIN OUR SUBMITTED SF424C BUDGET, EQUIPMENT COSTS TOTALING $219,107 WILL ADDRESS THE PURCHASE OF CLINICAL AND NON-CLINICAL EQUIPMENT ESSENTIAL TO PROVIDE THE SERVICES INDICATED, AND THE BALANCE OF $1,191,000 REPRESENT PROJECT EXPENSES INCLUDING ARCHITECTURAL & ENGINEERING, INSPECTION FEES, DEMO, CONSTRUCTION, GENERAL CONDITIONS (OH&P), PROJECT SUPERVISION, AND CONTINGENCY COSTS.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE DELAWARE-MORROW MENTAL HEALTH AND RECOVERY SERVICES BOARD (BOARD) IS THE STATUTORY AUTHORITY FOR THE PLANNING, FUNDING, MONITORING AND EVALUATING OF PUBLIC BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES IN DELAWARE AND MORROW COUNTIES IN CENTRAL OHIO. SPACE FOR A FOURTH PROVIDER WHO WILL SERVE CHILDREN AND FAMILIES AND PROVIDE SCHOOL BASED MENTAL HEALTH CARE WILL BE ADDED WITH THIS EXPANSION.  THE FACILITY REQUIRES RENOVATION TO MODERNIZE THE FACILITY AND IMPROVE ACCESS TO BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE IN MORROW COUNTY, A RURAL COUNTY LACKING RESOURCES AND SERVICES. THIS PROJECT WILL UPDATE THE EXISTING +/- 10,980 SF FACILITY TO MEET CODE REGULATIONS, PROVIDE SECURITY UPDATES, MAXIMIZE SQUARE FOOTAGE AND UTILIZATION OF FEATURES FOR THE STAFF AND CONSUMERS WHO ARE CURRENT OCCUPANTS AND VISITORS. COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PROJECT TITLE: CHAMPLAIN ISLANDS HEALTH CENTER - DENTAL APPLICANT ORGANIZATION NAME: COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTERS OF BURLINGTON, INC. PROJECT ADDRESS: 52 COMMUNITY LANE, SOUTH HERO, VT 05486 PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: JEFFREY MCKEE, PSY.D. CONTACT PHONE NUMBERS: (802) 264-8190 E-MAIL ADDRESS: JMCKEE@CHCB.ORG  WEBSITE ADDRESS: WWW.CHCB.ORG GRANT PROGRAM FUNDS REQUESTED IN APPLICATION: $1,000,000  THE HRSA CDS (CONSTRUCTION) PROJECT INVOLVES THE BUILD-OUT OF A NEW DENTAL CENTER AT THE COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTERS OF BURLINGTON’S (CHCB) EXISTING CHAMPLAIN ISLANDS HEALTH CENTER (CIHC), WHICH CURRENTLY OFFERS MEDICAL AND PSYCHIATRY/MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ONLY. WHEN CHCB COMPLETED CONSTRUCTION OF CIHC IN 2016, THE APPROXIMATELY 2,000 SQUARE FOOT LOWER LEVEL OF THE FACILITY WAS RESERVED FOR THE FUTURE HOME OF A DENTAL CENTER, TO BE COMPLETED AT A TIME WHEN A FUNDING OPPORTUNITY AROSE. NOW IS THAT TIME! THE FUNDS FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE UTILIZED TO TRANSFORM THE PRE-EXISTING SPACE INTO A DENTAL PRACTICE THROUGH THE CONSTRUCTION OF FIVE DENTAL OPERATORIES; A LAB AND STERILIZATION ROOM; PATIENT WAITING AREA; STORAGE AREAS; AND STAFF AREAS SUCH AS A COLLABORATIVE OFFICE, A CHANGING AREA, BREAK ROOM, AND RESTROOM.  ESTABLISHED IN 2004, CHCB’S DENTAL PROGRAM IS THE SOLE POINT OF ACCESS TO QUALITY, AFFORDABLE DENTAL SERVICES FOR OVER 7,000 VERMONTERS ANNUALLY; HOWEVER, ACCESS TO DENTAL CARE IS EXTREMELY LIMITED IN VERMONT’S CHAMPLAIN ISLANDS. GRAND ISLE COUNTY IS THE ONLY COUNTY IN VERMONT WITH NO REPORTED DENTAL PRACTICE. TRAVELING LONG DISTANCES TO ACCESS DENTAL CARE PRESENTS A BURDEN TO THE RESIDENTS OF SOUTH HERO, NORTH HERO, AND GRAND ISLE, THE TOWNS THAT COMPRISE SOUTHERN GRAND ISLE COUNTY. APPROXIMATELY 30% OF RESIDENTS IN THIS REGION ARE AGED 60 YEARS AND OVER (US CENSUS ACS 2019), SO THERE ARE ISSUES OF TRANSPORTATION AND FINANCIAL MEANS. ADDITIONALLY, VERY FEW PRIVATE DENTAL PRACTICES IN NEIGHBORING COUNTIES ACCEPT MEDICAID, A SIGNIFICANT BARRIER FOR THE ALMOS T 18% OF CIHC PATIENTS WHO ARE MEDICAID RECIPIENTS. IN FACT, APPROXIMATELY 15% OF THE POPULATION OF SOUTHERN GRAND ISLE COUNTY IS CONSIDERED LOW-INCOME (BELOW 200% FPL). GRAND ISLE IS ALSO HOME TO A LARGE POPULATION OF MIGRANT WORKERS WHO OFTEN HAVE LITTLE TO NO ACCESS TO TRANSPORTATION. ACCORDING TO 2018 COUNTY-LEVEL DATA AVAILABLE IN THE UDS MAPPER TOOL, APPROXIMATELY 25% OF ADULTS IN SOUTHERN GRAND ISLE COUNTY “HAD NO DENTAL VISIT IN THE PAST YEAR.” THIS HAS CERTAINLY BEEN EXACERBATED BECAUSE OF THE COVID-19 OUTBREAK, WHICH RESULTED IN A TREND OF PEOPLE FORGOING PREVENTIVE CARE APPOINTMENTS.  THE LOCAL SENIOR COMMUNITY AND YOUTH ARE THE TWO DEMOGRAPHICS HARDEST HIT BY A LACK OF LOCAL DENTAL SERVICES. TO HELP REACH THEM, WE WILL PARTNER WITH THE CHAMPLAIN ISLANDERS DEVELOPING ESSENTIAL RESOURCES (C.I.D.E.R.) ORGANIZATION. C.I.D.E.R. PROVIDES TRANSPORTATION TO SENIORS AND THOSE WITH LIMITED MOBILITY, WHICH WILL EMPOWER THIS POPULATION WITHIN THE REGION TO ATTEND TO THEIR ORAL HEALTH. IN ADDITION, SENIOR LIVING APARTMENTS CURRENTLY UNDER CONSTRUCTION DIRECTLY BEHIND THE CIHC ENSURES RESIDENTS LITERALLY HAVE DENTAL CARE IN THEIR BACK YARD. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL USE OUR SCHOOL-BASED DENTAL PROGRAM EXPERTISE TO HELP MEET THE DENTAL NEEDS OF CHILDREN ENROLLED IN THE GRAND ISLE SUPERVISORY UNION. THE ISLANDS MODEL WILL TRANSPORT STUDENTS FROM THEIR SCHOOLS TO CIHC THROUGH OUR PARTNERSHIP WITH C.I.D.E.R. THIS WILL HELP MANY PARENTS WHO ARE LACKING IN TRANSPORTATION OR THE FLEXIBILITY TO TAKE TIME OFF FROM WORK TO BRING THEIR CHILDREN TO APPOINTMENTS. LASTLY, HAVING THIS LOCATION WILL ALSO FREE UP SPACE TO OFFER A TRAINING SITE FOR GENERAL PRACTICE DENTAL RESIDENTS, MAKING CHCB A SUPPORTIVE EDUCATOR TO THE NEXT GENERATION OF DENTISTS.  THIS NEW DENTAL CENTER WILL PROVIDE HIGH-QUALITY ORAL HYGIENE AND PREVENTIVE CARE, WHILE ALSO OFFERING SERVICES UNIQUE TO A FQHC. WE ANTICIPATE MOST OF OUR 2,467 EXISTING CIHC PATIENTS

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE PROJECT, LOCATED AT 648 CHETCO AVENUE, BROOKINGS, OREGON WILL FACILITATE A RENOVATION OF AN ALREADY EXISTING MEDICAL FACILITY TO EXPAND ACCESS TO PRIMARY CARE AND OTHER MEDICAL SERVICES PROVIDED THROUGH BANDON COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTER, DBA. COAST COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTER UNDER THE DIRECTION OF PROJECT DIRECTOR AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, LINDA MAXON. COAST COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTER IS AN ESTABLISHED FEDERALLY QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTER WHICH HAS EXISTED ALONG THE SOUTH COAST SERVING THE MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED SINCE 2010. THE CATCHMENT AREAS IS RECOGNIZED AS A HEALTH PROVIDER SHORTAGE AREA AND MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED AREA, INVOLVING THE REGION OF SOUTHERN COOS & CURRY COUNTIES.  RENOVATION OF THIS PRIOR SURGERY WHICH WAS AN APPROVED CMS FACILITY WILL CREATE 10 EXAM AND PROCEDURE ROOMS, VACCINES ADMINISTRATION ROOMS, NURSE CONSULTING ROOMS, 4 INTEGRATED BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PATIENT ENCOUNTER ROOMS, A LARGE IN-PATIENT 340B/RETAIL PHARMACY WHICH WILL HAVE INCLUDE AN EXTERIOR DRIVE UP WINDOW,  MEDICAL TEAM POD AREA, GROUP THERAPY ROOM, AND SUPPORT OFFICES FOR WRAP AROUND SERVICES PROVIDED BY THE POPULATION HEALTH TEAM.   THE REGION HAS BEEN UNDERSERVED WITH NOT ACTIVE FEDERALLY QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTER FULL-SERVICE SITE ESTABLISHED IN THIS GEOGRAPHIC AREA THAT SUPPORTS APPROXIMATELY 10,200 CONSTITUENTS.  DUE TO COAST'S DEEP COMMITMENT TO RESPOND TO COVID DURING THE PAST 2-1/2 YEARS, THE CENTER HAS MORE THAN DOUBLED THE NUMBER OF PATIENTS ESTABLISHED AND RECEIVING CARE AT THE EXISTING TWO FACILITIES. CONSTITUENTS IN THIS REGION TRAVEL 45 MINUTES NORTH TO RECEIVE SERVICES AT THE NORTH CURRY FACILITY, LOCATED IN PORT ORFORD, OREGON. THE CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED CONSTRUCTION FUNDING WILL ALLOW THE HEALTH CENTER TO IMMEDIATELY IMPACT EXPANDED SERVICES TO S. CURRY COUNTY THROUGH THE PARTNERSHIP WITH A RETIRED PHYSICIAN WHO OFFERED THIS FACILITY FOR THE CENTER'S USE. THE CENTER'S COMPASSIONATE TENURED PROVIDERS WORK WITH A LARGE POPULATION OF MEDI CARE PATIENTS AND AGING IN PLACE, END OF LIFE CARE, WHILE OUR OTHER PROVIDERS HAVE EXPERIENCE WITH PEDIATRIC AND SCHOOL-BASED HEALTHCARE FOR THE YOUNG VULNERABLE COMMUNITY MEMBERS. THE CENTER'S OPPORTUNITY FOR EXPANSION WILL SUPPORT COMPREHENSIVE SERVICES FOR ANY AND ALL IN THE SOUTH COUNTY AND BRIDGE THE CURRENT DEFICIT OF PRIMARY CARE SERVICES THAT EXIST IN THE REGION. THE CENTER WILL ALSO SUPPORT THE EXISTING RELATIONSHIP WITH THE REGION'S COORDINATED CARE ORGANIZATIONS, (ALL CARE HEALTH AND ADVANCED HEALTH) WHO MANAGE THE LIVES OF MEDICAID PATIENTS. THE ECONOMIC INVESTMENT OF THESE FUNDS AND THE ASSOCIATED PROJECT WILL BRING A STRONG ECONOMIC INVESTMENT TO THE REGION TO SUPPORT CONTRACTS, EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES, WORK SOURCE DEVELOPMENT, COLLABORATION WITH LOCAL COMMUNITY COLLEGES, AMONG OTHER ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES. EQUALLY THE INVESTMENT IN PRIMARY CARE, ACUTE AND WALK-IN HEALTHCARE SERVICES THROUGH THE HEALTH CENTER DEVELOPMENT WILL SUPPORT EQUITABLE HEALTHCARE SERVICES TO THE MIGRANT FARMWORKER POPULATION, AND THOSE WHO ARE FINANCIALLY VULNERABLE, THE HOMELESS AND THOSE CHALLENGED BY MENTAL HEALTH AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH, WHILE LIFTING THE BURDEN EXPERIENCED BY THE HOSPITAL EMERGENCY ROOM DEPARTMENTS FOR UTILIZATION OF ER SERVICES FOR PRIMARY, PREVENTATIVE AND ACUTE CARE INAPPROPRIATELY.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - FUNDING THROUGH THE HRSA-22-134 OPPORTUNITY WILL SUPPORT THE CONSTRUCTION OF AN AMBULATORY SURGERY CENTER – INCLUDING 16 PRE- AND POST-OPERATIVE ROOMS AND 4 FULL OPERATING SUITES – AND A WOMEN AND CHILDREN’S CLINIC, INCLUDING MEDICAL, DENTAL, BEHAVIORAL HEALTH, OPTOMETRY, AND OTHER PROCEDURE/EXAMINATION ROOMS. THIS FACILITY WHERE THE CDS CONSTRUCTION PROJECT WILL TAKE PLACE IS LOCATED AT 1720 WEST GRAND STREET IN SPRINGFIELD, MISSOURI.   THE PRIMARY PROPOSED ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE IMPROVEMENT AND RECONFIGURATION OF THE INTERIOR ARRANGEMENTS OF AN EXISTING FACILITY. THE 50,000-SQUARE-FOOT FACILITY AT 1720 WEST GRAND STREET WAS ORIGINALLY PURCHASED BY THE HEALTH CENTER TO SUPPORT A RAPID EXPANSION OF COVID-19 TESTING, TREATMENT, AND VACCINATION EFFORTS. IN LOOKING BEYOND THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, AND UPON AN EVALUATION OF SERVICE AREA NEEDS, THIS FACILITY WAS IDENTIFIED AS AN IDEAL LOCATION FOR THE EXPANSION OF JORDAN VALLEY’S WOMEN AND CHILDREN’S SERVICES, AND THE CREATION OF AN AMBULATORY SURGERY CENTER TO PROVIDE ORAL SURGERY AND OTHER OUTPATIENT PROCEDURES.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ADDRESS: 	CITY OF HOUSTON FIRE / EMS DEPARTMENT 			500 JEFFERSON, 16TH FLOOR 			HOUSTON, TX 77002   PROJECT DIRECTOR:	DR. PERSSE  CONTACT PHONE:		#832-394-6818  EMAIL ADDRESS:		DAVID.PERSSE@HOUSTONTX.GOV 	 WEBSITE:		HTTP://WWW.HOUSTONTX.GOV/MAYOR/EMS.HTML  FUNDS REQUESTED:	$906,584.00     MOBILE STROKE UNIT PROPOSAL FOR CONGRESS  BACKGROUND: STROKES REPRESENT ONE OF THE MOST DEVASTATING MEDICAL CATASTROPHES A PERSON CAN EXPERIENCE.  STROKE IS RECOGNIZED AS THE FOURTH LEADING CAUSE OF DEATH AMONG AMERICANS, AS WELL AS A LEADING CAUSE OF DISABILITY.  BEGINNING IN AUGUST OF 2014, THE HOUSTON FIRE DEPARTMENT EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES COORDINATED AND COLLABORATED IN AN AGGRESSIVE RESEARCH PROJECT WITH THE HOUSTON STROKE CONSORTIUM TO IMPROVE THE CARE OF PERSONS SUFFERING FROM STROKES DURING THE FIRST MOMENTS OF THEIR CONTACT WITH THE HEALTH CARE SYSTEM.   THE GOAL WAS TO TREAT ELIGIBLE PATIENTS WITH THE CLOT DISSOLVING MEDICATION, TPA, AND HOPEFULLY REVERSE THE STROKE BEFORE IT CAUSES PERMANENT BRAIN DAMAGE.  THE STUDY ENROLLED 1,047 TPA-ELIGIBLE PATIENTS, 617 IN THE MOBILE STROKE UNIT (MSU) GROUP AND 430 IN STANDARD MANAGEMENT (SM).  AMONG TPA ELIGIBLE PATIENTS, 97% WERE TREATED WITH TPA IN THE MSU GROUP AND 80% IN THE SM GROUP. TIME FROM LAST KNOWN NORMAL (LKN) TO TPA TREATMENT WAS SHORTER IN THE MSU GROUP COMPARED TO SM. IMPORTANTLY, 33% OF MSU AND 3% OF SM PATIENTS WERE TREATED WITHIN 60 MIN OF LKN.  COMPARED TO SM, THE MSU GROUP HAD A MORE FAVORABLE NEUROLOGIC OUTCOME SCORE AND THE PROPORTION NORMAL OR NEAR-NORMAL WAS 10% HIGHER (53% MSU VERSUS 43% SM).  THIS MEANS THAT ON AVERAGE, FOR EVERY 100 PATIENTS TREATED ON A MOBILE STROKE UNIT RATHER THAN STANDARD CARE, 27 WILL HAVE LESS FINAL NEUROLOGIC DISABILITY AND 11 OF THE 27 WILL BE DISABILITY-FREE.  THE CHALLENGE CREATED: ALL PERSONS IN THE CITY OF HOUSTON WHO SUFFER AN ACUTE STROKE SHOULD BE ABLE TO RECEIVE THE SUPERIOR CARE AND ACHIEVE THE SUPERIOR OUTCOMES AFFORDED BY THE CARE AVAILABLE WITH  A MOBILE STROKE UNIT. THIS COMMUNITY-BASED MSU PROGRAM PROMOTES EQUITY IN ALL DEMOGRAPHIC AND GEOGRAPHIC AREAS OF THE CITY OF HOUSTON: 1) COMMUNITIES DISPROPORTIONATELY IMPACTED BY COVID-19 (LOW-INCOME NEIGHBORHOODS, MINORITIES, DISCONNECTED YOUTH, UNEMPLOYED VETERANS AND PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES), 2) NEGATIVE ECONOMIC IMPACTED POPULATIONS AND 3) GROUPS HISTORICALLY AND MARGINALIZED BY HEALTH DISPARITIES. HOWEVER, IN ORDER TO ACHIEVE THAT LEVEL OF CARE ACROSS THE CITY, MULTIPLE SUCH MSU’S WILL BE NEEDED.  EACH MSU COVERS AN AREA OF ~154 SQUARE MILES.  THE CITY OF HOUSTON ENCOMPASSES AN AREA OF APPROXIMATELY 620 SQUARE MILES.  THEREFORE, FOUR MSU AMBULANCES ARE REQUIRED TO COVER THE GEOGRAPHIC TERRITORY OF THE CITY OF HOUSTON.  CURRENTLY ONLY ONE MSU IS IN OPERATION WITHIN THE CITY OF HOUSTON / 620 SQUARE MILES.  THUS, THE ASK OF AN ADDITIONAL MSU WOULD ALLOW MORE STROKE PATIENTS TO BE TREATED EACH DAY.  THE SOLUTION OFFERED: HAVE THE CITY OF HOUSTON PROVIDED UP TO FOUR MSU’S AND ONE IN RESERVE, AS WELL AS PARAMEDIC STAFFING WHILE THE MSU CONSORTIUM CONTINUES TO PROVIDE NEURO-CRITICAL CARE NURSE AND CT TECHNICIAN STAFFING AS WELL AS TPA, TELERADIOLOGY AND TELENEUROLOGY.    CONCLUSION: THIS NOVEL MODEL IN THE CITY OF HOUSTON, IS DELIVERING ACUTE STROKE TREATMENT AND ADVANCING CARE ON THE STREETS, WHICH COULD HAVE A POTENTIAL IMPACT ACROSS THE NATION.  WHEN PATIENTS WHO QUALIFY FOR TPA COMPARED TO STANDARD BY EMS ARE EVALUATED, IMAGED AND TREATED IN THE PRE-HOSPITAL SETTING, THE DATA SUGGESTS A SAVING OF A CRITICAL-HOUR AND FEWER LONG-TERM DISABILITIES, IMPROVED QUALITY OF LIFE AND REDUCTION IN OVERALL HEALTHCARE COSTS.  IN ADDITION, THE SUCCESS OF THE MSU PROJECT HAS LED TO DISCUSSIONS BY THE TRAUMA SERVICES OF BOTH BAYLOR AND UT TO HAVE FIELD HEAD CT’S PERFORMED ON HEAD TRAUMA PATIENTS AND DEPARTMENTS OF CARDIOLOGY AND EMERGENCY MEDICINE FOR BOTH MEDICAL SCHOOLS ARE CONSIDERING HIGH-COMPLEXITY DIAGNOSTIC AS WE

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ADDRESS: ROWAN UNIVERSITY RUTGERS-CAMDEN BOARD OF GOVERNORS JOINT HEALTH SCIENCES CENTER 201 SOUTH BROADWAY, SUITE 440 CAMDEN, NJ 08103 PROJECT DIRECTOR - DANA L. REDD, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER TELEPHONE: (856)203-6757 EMAIL: DREDD@RURCBOG.COM PROGRAM FUNDS: $500,000.00, COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS (HRSA-22-134) FUNDING IS REQUESTED BY THE ROWAN UNIVERSITY/RUTGERS-CAMDEN BOARD OF GOVERNORS TO FURTHER ADVANCE HEALTH PROFESSIONS EDUCATION, WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT AND MEDICAL RESEARCH AT THE JOINT HEALTH SCIENCES CENTER LOCATED IN DOWNTOWN CAMDEN, NEW JERSEY. FUNDING WILL BE UTILIZED TO ACQUIRE CAPITAL EQUIPMENT FOR ROWAN UNIVERSITY, RUTGERS UNIVERSITY-CAMDEN, THE COOPER MEDICAL SCHOOL OF ROWAN UNIVERSITY AND CAMDEN COUNTY COLLEGE. SPECIFICALLY, FUNDING WILL BE USED 1.) TO PURCHASE A SUPER-RESOLUTION MICROSCOPE IN ORDER TO ADVANCE MEDICAL RESEARCH AND 2.) TO PURCHASE VENTILATOR AND ULTRASOUND SIMULATION EQUIPMENT TO TRAIN MEDICAL AND NURSING STUDENTS AT THE JOINT HEALTH SCIENCES CENTER. IT IS NOW POSSIBLE TO DETERMINE THE LOCALIZATION OF MOLECULES WITH UNPRECEDENTED RESOLUTION WITH IMPORTANT APPLICATIONS IN BIOLOGICAL, BIOENGINEERING, AND MATERIALS SCIENCES. THIS MICROSCOPE IS EXTREMELY USER FRIENDLY AND DOES NOT REQUIRE SPECIALIZED EXPERTISE OR A DEDICATED OPERATOR, MAKING IT AN ACCESSIBLE AND INVALUABLE RESOURCE FOR SCIENTISTS AND ENGINEERS AT ROWAN UNIVERSITY AND RUTGERS UNIVERSITY-CAMDEN AND OTHERS IN SOUTHERN NEW JERSEY. SIMULATION IS RECOGNIZED AS AN INNOVATIVE APPROACH TO EDUCATION THAT HAS BECOME AN ESSENTIAL AND POPULAR ELEMENT OF MEDICAL AND HEALTHCARE EDUCATION. TWO AREAS IN MEDICAL AND HEALTHCARE EDUCATION WHERE SIMULATION HAS PROVEN PARTICULARLY EFFECTIVE ARE VENTILATION AND ULTRASOUND TRAINING. TEACHING MECHANICAL VENTILATION TO STUDENTS AT THE BEDSIDE WITH REAL CRITICALLY ILL PATIENTS IN THE ICU IS EXTREMELY DIFFICULT. THE ABILITY TO USE A VENTILATOR IN A SIMULATED SPACE ALLOWS FOR A N OPPORTUNITY TO EDUCATE THE STUDENT ABOUT DIFFERENT MODES OF VENTILATION AND ALSO ALLOWS THE STUDENT TO PRACTICE MAKING ADJUSTMENTS AND IDENTIFYING THE BEST OPTIONS FOR DIFFERENT PATIENTS. AN ULTRASOUND CAN PROVIDE VERY IMPORTANT DIAGNOSTIC INFORMATION ABOUT MULTIPLE CRITICAL PATIENT ISSUES. AN ULTRASOUND SIMULATOR MIMICS WHAT A STUDENT WOULD SEE DURING THE PATIENT EXAMINATION OR PROCEDURE. ALLOWING THE STUDENT TO PRACTICE USING THIS EQUIPMENT ALLOWS THEM TO DEVELOP ESSENTIAL SKILLS PRIOR TO ENTERING THE CLINICAL ENVIRONMENT.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE RHODE ISLAND DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (RIDOH) DIVISION OF HEALTH LABORATORIES & MEDICAL EXAMINERS REQUESTS $900,000 FROM THE COMMUNITY PROJECT/ CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING (CDS) FUNDING OPPORTUNITY. RIDOH’S PROPOSAL ASKS FOR LABORATORY EQUIPMENT TO SUPPORT ALL THREE OF THE STATE HEALTH LABORATORIES CENTERS (BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES, ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES AND FORENSIC SCIENCES), AND INCLUDES MANY CRITICAL LARGE ITEMS THAT HAVE BEEN UNABLE TO BE FUNDED PREVIOUSLY THROUGH OUR STATE BUDGET. INSTRUMENTS REQUESTED INCLUDE THOSE THAT TEST FOR VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS, PCBS, HERBICIDES, PESTICIDES AND OTHER CONTAMINANTS IN BOTH DRINKING AND GROUND WATER; AN INSTRUMENT TO TEST FOR OPIOIDS AND OTHER DRUGS IN IMPAIRED DRIVING CASES AND POSTMORTEM SPECIMENS; AND AN INSTRUMENT TO TEST FOR ILLICIT DRUGS IN LAW ENFORCEMENT CASES. TWO SMALLER BUT IMPORTANT REQUESTS ARE FOR A RAPID AUTOMATED DEVICE TO REPLACE TIMELY CENTRIFUGATION AND EQUIPMENT TO ASSIST IN PROPER RESPIRATOR/MASK FIT TESTING. ALL OF THIS EQUIPMENT WILL BE USED TO POSITION THE STATE HEALTH LABORATORY WITH NEWER, MORE RELIABLE METHODS WHICH WILL SERVE THE ENTIRE STATE OF RHODE ISLAND. FOR MANY STAKEHOLDERS, SUCH AS PUBLIC SAFETY, ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT, AND DRUG TASK FORCES, THE DATA RECEIVED WILL HELP INFORM POLICY DECISIONS.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ADDRESS: 1000 E. VICTORIA STREET, CARSON, CA 90747-0001 PROJECT DIRECTOR: DR.  TEL: 310-243-2046 EMAIL: KIMMS@CSUDH.EDU FUNDS REQUESTED: $700,000  CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY, DOMINGUEZ HILLS (CSUDH) RESPECTFULLY SEEKS SUPPORT TO UPDATE AND UPGRADE EQUIPMENT, SIMULATION CAPABILITIES, AND TECHNOLOGIES USED FOR THE EDUCATION OF NURSES AND OCCUPATIONAL THERAPISTS (OTS). CSUDH HAS A STELLAR RECORD OF ACHIEVEMENT IN EDUCATING NURSES, OTS AND OTHER HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONALS WHO GRADUATE, ENTER THE WORKFORCE IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA AND BEYOND, AND SERVE THE HEALTHCARE NEEDS OF THE DIVERSE POPULATION OF SOUTH LOS ANGELES COUNTY. STUDENTS GAIN EXPERIENCE DURING THEIR EDUCATIONAL PURSUITS IN CLINICAL LABORATORIES WHERE THEY DEMONSTRATE SKILL PROFICIENCY, REAL-WORLD EXPERIENCES ARE SIMULATED, AND INSTRUCTORS OBSERVE AND MENTOR STUDENTS. THE EXISTING SKILLS LAB IS OUTDATED AND NEEDS TO BE UPGRADED TO MEET THE COMPLEX ACADEMIC NEEDS OF CSUDHS MULTI-CULTURAL STUDENT BODY. THE LAB ALSO NEEDS TO BE UPGRADED TO BETTER ADDRESS CURRENT AND EMERGING HEALTHCARE PRACTICES IN THE RAPIDLY CHANGING REAL-WORLD HEALTHCARE ENVIRONMENT. AN INVESTMENT IN UPGRADING THE LAB WILL ENHANCE THE EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE AND SUCCESS OF STUDENTS AND IMPROVE THE DELIVERY OF HEALTHCARE AND THERAPEUTIC SERVICES THROUGHOUT THE REGION THUS REDUCING HEALTH DISPARITIES AND FOSTERING LONG-TERM HEALTH OUTCOMES FOR GENERATIONS TO COME.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - RYAN HEALTH | WOMEN & CHILDREN’S CENTER (W&C CENTER) IS LOCATED AT 801 AMSTERDAM AVENUE IN NEW YORK CITY AND IS ONE OF SIX PRIMARY AND SPECIALTY CARE LOCATIONS THAT RYAN HEALTH OPERATES. THE HEALTHCARE SERVICES THAT ARE AVAILABLE AT W&C CENTER: PEDIATRICS; WOMEN’S HEALTH; WOMEN, INFANTS, AND CHILDREN (WIC) NUTRITION PROGRAM; AND, THE MENTAL HEALTH CLINIC KNOWN AS THE EMOTIONAL WELLNESS CENTER.  IN 2021, RYAN HEALTH NEGOTIATED A LEASE AMENDMENT FOR ADDITIONAL SPACE WITHIN THE 801 AMSTERDAM BUILDING ON THE FIRST FLOOR. THIS ADDITIONAL SPACE IS BEING RENOVATED TO EXPAND THE OVERALL FOOTPRINT OF THE W&C CENTER, WHICH INCLUDES THE ADDITION OF A FIRST-FLOOR LOCATION TO HOUSE A RELOCATED EMOTIONAL WELLNESS CENTER.    SPECIFICALLY, THROUGH THE CONSTRUCTION GRANT AWARD, RYAN HEALTH WILL MEET ITS PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF RELOCATION OF THE EMOTIONAL WELLNESS CENTER FROM THE LOWER LEVEL, AND NEW CONSTRUCTION INTO A MUCH LARGER AND ACCESSIBLE LOCATION ON THE FIRST FLOOR, MORE THAN DOUBLING THE SIZE OF THE EXISTING 1,500 SQ. FT. CENTER TO 3,600 SQ. FT. PROJECT FUNDING WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO MENTAL AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH TREATMENT AND SERVICES FOR LOW-INCOME MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED ADULTS AND ADOLESCENTS IN NEW YORK CITY, AND WILL HELP MEET THE GROWING NEED FOR THESE SERVICES THAT HAS BECOME PARTICULARLY EVIDENT SINCE THE ADVENT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.  IN SUM, TO MEET ITS MENTAL HEALTH CLINIC OBJECTIVES, RYAN HEALTH WILL: A) LEASE NEW SPACE ON THE FIRST FLOOR OF THE 801 AMSTERDAM AVENUE BUILDING; B) RELOCATE MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES (FROM THE LOWER LEVEL) TO THE NEWLY LEASED SPACE ON THE FIRST FLOOR; C) RELOCATE THE WIC PROGRAM (FROM THE SECOND FLOOR) TO THE NEWLY LEASED SPACE ON THE FIRST FLOOR; AND D) REORGANIZE AND INCREASE THE OVERALL FOOTPRINT OF THE PEDIATRICS AND WOMEN’S HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (ON THE SECOND FLOOR) FOR OPERATIONAL EFFICIENCY. RECONFIGURATION WILL ALSO IMPROVE ADA ACCESSIBILITY, VISITOR MOVEMENTS THROUGHOUT THE FACILITY, SECURITY AND PRIVACY FOR PATIENTS AND STAFF, AND NEW SIGNAGE WILL MAKE THE FACILITY FEEL WELCOMING.  	 THE NEW MENTAL  HEALTH CLINIC WILL HAVE SEPARATE AND DIRECT ACCESS FROM THE STREET AS WELL AS ACCESS FROM THE EXISTING RYAN HEALTH LOBBY AND THE NEWLY-CONSTRUCTED SPACE WILL CONSIST OF: ONE ADULT WAITING ROOM; ONE YOUTH WAITING ROOM; ONE REGISTRATION AREA; ONE QUIET-ROOM; ONE INTAKE ROOM; ONE CASE WORKER ROOM; TWO PSYCHOTHERAPY GROUP ROOMS; SIX PSYCHOTHERAPY PRIVATE CONSULT ROOMS; ONE VITALS ROOM; ONE PRESCRIBER/MEDICATION OFFICE; (AND, PATIENT TOILETS; TWO STAFF OFFICES; PANTRY; STORAGE; JANITOR CLOSET; AND IDF/IT ROOM). THE DEDICATED INTAKE AND DE-ESCALATION ROOMS ARE NEW ADDITIONS AS PER “BEST PRACTICES” IN MENTAL HEALTH.   THE HVAC SYSTEM ON THE FIRST FLOOR WILL BE BRAND NEW IN THE PREVIOUSLY UNOCCUPIED SHELL SPACE. FIRE PROTECTION AND SPRINKLER SYSTEMS WILL BE INSTALLED. HEATING AND COOLING WILL BE CONTROLLED BY A NEW BUILDING MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (BMS) THAT WILL COMMUNICATE WITH THE RYAN HEALTH BMS SYSTEM IN OTHER FACILITIES. THE ELECTRICAL INFRASTRUCTURE FOR THE SPACE WILL BE UPGRADED AND THERE WILL BE A NEW PLUMBING SYSTEM BRANCHING OFF FROM THE BASE BUILDING INCLUDING COLD/HOT WATER, SANITARY DRAINING AND VENTS, AND NEW PLUMBING DEVICES INCLUDING SINKS AND TOILETS.   IN EARLY 2021, FORMAL PLANNING FOR THE PROJECT BEGAN AND BY JULY 2021 A COMPETITIVE RFP PROCESS WAS COMPLETED. RYAN HEALTH HIRED AN ARCHITECTURAL FIRM AND AN ENGINEERING FIRM WHICH COMPLETED SCHEMATICS AND DESIGN WORK. THE CONSTRUCTION MANAGER WAS HIRED SHORTLY THEREAFTER, AND UPON DESIGN COMPLETION, BIDS WERE SOLICITED FROM SUBCONTRACTORS AND TRADES LEADING TO A GMP IN PLACE AT THE BEGINNING OF 2022, AND A CONSTRUCTION START DATE OF APRIL 2022. THE PROJECT IS ON TRACK FOR A FALL 2022 COMPLETION DATE.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - WASHINGTON HOSPITAL FOUNDATION IMPROVING THE BEHAVIORAL HEALTH UNIT AT THE WASHINGTON HOSPITAL.  THE FACILITY IS ONE OF THE ONLY ACUTE INPATIENT BEHAVIORAL HEALTH UNITS PROVIDING 24-HOUR TREATMENT FOR PATIENTS WITH MENTAL HEALTH EMERGENCIES IN WASHINGTON, GREENE COUNTIES, AND SURROUNDING SOUTHWESTERN PENNSYLVANIA AND WEST VIRGINIA COUNTIES.  IT SERVES AS A CRITICAL SAFETY NET FOR THESE COUNTIES AS THE RATES OF MENTAL ILLNESS AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE INCREASE. THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE OUR PATIENTS’ SAFETY, AND RECOVERY SO THEY MAY RESUME THEIR EVERYDAY ACTIVE LIVES, WHILE IMPROVING THE OVERALL HEALTH AND WELLNESS OF OUR COMMUNITY.  WASHINGTON HOSPITAL’S PROJECT FEATURES IMPROVEMENTS TO DECREASE LIGATURE (HANGING OR STRANGULATION) RISKS AND SAFETY UPGRADES, INCLUDING IMPROVED LIGHTING, SECURITY MIRRORS, FIRE ALARM DEVICES, A SECURE CEILING SYSTEM, NEW CARD READERS, AND A NEW NURSE CALL SYSTEM.  THE PROJECT ALSO CREATES A CONSULT/TRIAGE ROOM AND AN IMPROVED SALLY PORT DOOR SYSTEM, WHICH IS A SECURE VESTIBULE AT THE ENTRANCE OF THE UNIT THAT PROVIDES A DOUBLE DOOR SYSTEM AND SERVES AS THE ONLY WAY FOR PATIENTS TO ENTER OR EXIT THE UNIT.  THIS PROTECTS UNIT STAFF AND REDUCES THE POTENTIAL OF A PATIENT LEAVING THE UNIT WITHOUT AUTHORIZATION.  IN ADDITION TO THE SAFETY MEASURE, NEW PAINT AND COLORS WILL PROMOTE A SENSE OF WELLBEING AND RELAXATION FOR OUR PATIENTS.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - HENRY FORD JACKSON/ALLEGIANCE HEALTH IS ESTABLISHING A NON-PROFIT HUMAN MILK DONOR BANK TO SUPPORT INFANT HEALTH. HUMAN MILK IS GENERALLY CONSIDERED THE OPTIMAL SOURCE OF NUTRITION FOR MOST INFANTS, AND IS ESPECIALLY IMPORTANT FOR PREMATURE BABIES IN NEED OF ADDITIONAL NUTRIENTS FOR DEVELOPMENT. HOWEVER, MANY DO NOT RECEIVE BREAST MILK FOR THE RECOMMENDED AMOUNT OF TIME DUE TO PHYSICAL, CULTURAL, AND SOCIETAL BARRIERS.  ONE WAY TO HELP ENSURE EVERY BABY HAS ACCESS TO BREAST MILK, REGARDLESS OF THEIR CIRCUMSTANCES, IS THROUGH A MILK BANK, WHICH ALLOWS WOMEN WITH EXCESS MILK TO DONATE TO THOSE IN NEED. THERE ARE FEWER THAN 30 MILK BANKS IN THE UNITED STATES, AND ONLY ONE IN MICHIGAN. HOSPITAL CLINICIANS, AS PROPONENTS OF DONOR MILK, KNOW FIRSTHAND THE BENEFITS AND NEED FOR INCREASED AVAILABILITY.   THE MILK BANK WILL OPERATE A FULL INTAKE AND DONATION PROGRAM THAT INCLUDES INTAKING MILK DONATIONS, PROCESSING MILK WITH HEAT FOR PASTEURIZATION, STORING MILK, AND QUEUING OUTGOING MILK. THE DONOR BANK WILL HAVE THE ABILITY TO SERVE PATIENTS WITHIN A 60-MILE RADIUS OF HENRY FORD JACKSON/ALLEGIANCE HEALTH’S MAIN HOSPITAL IN JACKSON COUNTY, WITH THE POTENTIAL TO EXPAND FURTHER ONCE ESTABLISHED.   THE HUMAN DONOR MILK BANK WILL INCREASE ACCESS IN MICHIGAN TO A CRITICAL SOURCE OF NUTRIENTS FOR BABIES AND HELP TO CREATE A STRONG FOUNDATION FOR INFANTS AND THEIR FAMILIES AT THE START OF LIFE.   THE FEDERAL FUNDS WILL SUPPORT THE SPACE RENOVATION FOR THE MILK BANK, AS WELL AS THE PURCHASE OF EQUIPMENT AND TECHNOLOGY FOR THIS EFFORT.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ADDRESS: 64-66 BRIDGE AVENUE, SUITES 64C&D AND SUITES 66C&D                  RED BANK, NJ 07701 PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: CHRISTOPHER RINN CONTACT PHONE NUMBER: 732-502-5151   EMAIL ADDRESS: CHRISTOPHER.RINN@VNAHG.ORG WEBSITE ADDRESS: WWW.VNACHC.ORG  THIS IS AN IMPROVEMENT AND RECONFIGURATION OF THE INTERIOR ARRANGEMENTS OF AN EXISTING FACILITY. THE RELOCATION TO A RENOVATED FACILITY WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO CARE FOR PATIENTS AS IT WILL INCREASE THE NUMBER OF MEDICAL EXAM ROOMS FROM FOUR TO EIGHT AND ADD DENTAL SERVICES BY THE INCLUSION OF THREE DENTAL OPERATORIES.
