AS EMERGENCY SERVICE PROVIDERS OF ADVANCED LIFE SUPPORT AND PREHOSPITAL CARE IN RURAL AREAS OF YAVAPAI COUNTY, IT IS EXTREMELY CRUCIAL OUR PARAMEDICS HAVE DIAGNOSTIC EQUIPMENT AVAILABLE THAT HE/SHE CAN USE IN THE FIELD AS OUR DISTRICTS ARE 20+ MILES FROM A LEVEL 4 TRAUMA CENTER AND AS MUCH AS 100 MILES FROM A LEVEL 1 FACILITY.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PROJECT DIRECTOR: MICHELLE HOFFMAN, EXPANDED AOR PROJECT TITLE: CARDIAC MAGNETIC RESONANCE IMAGING MACHINE (MRI)  APPLICANT NAME: DEBORAH HEART AND LUNG CENTER ADDRESS: 200 TRENTON ROAD, BROWNS MILLS, NJ 08015-1705 PHONE: (609) 893-0100 EXT. 8101 FAX: (609) 893-3821 EMAIL: GRANTWRITER@DEBORAHFOUNDATION.ORG  PROJECT PERIOD: JULY 1, 2022 THROUGH JUNE 30, 2025 PROGRAM FUNDS REQUESTED: $1,000,000.00   THIS APPLICATION REQUESTS SUPPORT FOR A CARDIAC MAGNETIC RESONANCE IMAGING MACHINE (MRI) AT DEBORAH HEART AND LUNG CENTER IN ORDER TO MEET THE DEMAND FOR DIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT OF CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE IN THE REGION. THE NEED FOR THIS EQUIPMENT IS CRITICAL, AS THERE IS NO OTHER ACCESS TO A CARDIAC MRI IN THE SERVICE AREA. DEBORAH IS LOCATED IN A MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED AREA/MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED POPULATION AS DEFINED BY HRSA. THIS EQUIPMENT WILL PROVIDE ACCESS TO STATE-OF-THE-ART HEALTH CARE FOR MANY INDIVIDUALS FROM TYPICALLY UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS.  WHAT TRULY SETS DEBORAH APART FROM ALL OTHER HOSPITALS IN THE UNITED STATES IS OUR OUTSTANDING REPUTATION AS A TOP CARDIOVASCULAR HOSPITAL. FOR A CENTURY, DEBORAH HAS NEVER RENDERED A BILL TO A PATIENT FOR SERVICES RECEIVED WITHIN THE HOSPITAL, NO CO-PAYS, NO DEDUCTIBLES, AND NO BALANCE BILLING. DEBORAH IS THE ONLY HOSPITAL IN THE UNITED STATES THAT TREATS BOTH CHILDREN AND ADULTS, YET HAS NEVER ISSUED A BILL TO A PATIENT. DEBORAH’S PURPOSE BY ACQUIRING THE ONLY CARDIAC MRI MACHINE IN THE REGION IS TO INCREASE ACCESS TO SPECIALIZED CARDIOVASCULAR CARE. OUR OBJECTIVE IS TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR THE PEOPLE IN OUR REGION AND TO SAVE LIVES.   HEART DISEASE IS THE LEADING CAUSE OF DEATH IN THE UNITED STATES; IT AFFECTS EVERY SEGMENT OF THE POPULATION. IT IS THE LEADING CAUSE OF DEATH AMONG ALL AMERICANS, MEN AND WOMEN ALIKE. IT IS ALSO THE LEADING CAUSE OF DEATH AMONG WHITES AND BLACKS AND THE SECOND LEADING CAUSE OF DEATH AMONG HISPANICS AND ASIANS. ONE PERSON DIES EVERY 36 SECONDS IN THE U.S. FROM  CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE. ABOUT 659,000 AMERICANS DIE FROM HEART DISEASE EACH YEAR – ACCOUNTING FOR ONE IN EVERY FOUR DEATHS.    A CARDIAC MRI USES A POWERFUL MAGNETIC FIELD, RADIOFREQUENCY WAVES, AND A COMPUTER TO CREATE DETAILED CROSS-SECTIONAL 2-DIMENSIONAL AND 3-DIMENSIONAL IMAGES OF THE INSIDE OF THE HEART WITHOUT USING IONIZING RADIATION. THE TEST SHOWS THE HEART’S STRUCTURE (MUSCLE, VALVES, AND CHAMBERS) AND HOW WELL BLOOD FLOWS THROUGH THE HEART AND MAJOR VESSELS. AN MRI OF THE HEART LETS THE CARDIOLOGIST SEE IF THE HEART IS DAMAGED FROM A HEART ATTACK, OR IF THERE IS LACK OF BLOOD FLOW TO THE HEART MUSCLE BECAUSE OF NARROWED OR BLOCKED ARTERIES.  IT IS A PAINLESS AND NONINVASIVE IMAGING TEST THAT CAN SAVE A PATIENT’S LIFE BY HELPING THE CLINICIAN TO DIAGNOSE MANY DIFFERENT HEART CONDITIONS QUICKLY AND ACCURATELY, WITH NO HARMFUL SIDE EFFECTS.   SITUATED IN BROWNS MILLS, NEW JERSEY, DEBORAH PRIMARILY SERVES PATIENTS FROM NEW JERSEY, PENNSYLVANIA, NEW YORK, AND DELAWARE. IN ADDITION, PATIENTS COME TO DEBORAH FROM ALL ACROSS THE UNITED STATES FOR TREATMENT. OUR PRIMARY SERVICE AREAS INCLUDE BURLINGTON, MONMOUTH, AND OCEAN COUNTIES.   IN 2021, THERE WERE OVER 72,500 OUTPATIENT VISITS AT DEBORAH. EIGHTY PERCENT OF OUR PATIENTS RANGED IN AGE FROM ADULT TO ADVANCED-AGED (35 TO 85+) 56% MALE AND 44% FEMALE. THE AVERAGE LENGTH OF STAY WAS APPROXIMATELY 3 DAYS.  TWENTY-FIVE PERCENT OF OUR PATIENTS ARE OF ETHNIC ORIGIN.  DEBORAH IS ONE MILE FROM THE JOINT BASE MCGUIRE-DIX-LAKEHURST AND CARES FOR THOUSANDS OF ACTIVE DUTY MILITARY, VETERANS, AND THEIR FAMILIES THROUGH OUR HEROCARE CONNECT PROGRAM. IN 2021, 53% OF MILITARY PATIENTS TREATED AT DEBORAH WERE ACTIVE DUTY OR DEPENDENTS OF ACTIVE DUTY; 47% WERE VETERANS OR DEPENDENTS OF VETERANS. AMONG OUR MILITARY PATIENTS, 68% WERE MALE AND 32% WERE FEMALE. THE AGE RANGE OF THE ACTIVE DUTY MILITARY, VETERAN, AND DEPENDENT PATIENTS WAS 8% (UNDER AGE 18), 63% (18-65 YRS.)

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - FRIEND HEALTH, A 23-YEAR-OLD FQHC SERVING MORE THAN 47,000 PATIENTS ON CHICAGO'S SOUTHSIDE, IS REQUESTING FUNDING FOR MEDICAL EQUIPMENT AND SOME FURNITURE FOR ITS NEWEST AND LARGEST HEALTH CENTER SITE IN THE WOODLAWN COMMUNITY (6250 SOUTH COTTAGE GROVE, CHICAGO, IL 60637). FRIEND HEALTH HAS SERVED COMMUNITY RESIDENTS SINCE ITS INCEPTION. THE MAJORITY OF PATIENTS WHO USE FRIEND HEALTH SERVICES ARE AFRICAN-AMERICAN/BLACK AND/OR HISPANIC/LATINO, AND THE MAJORITY OF RESIDENTS IN WOODLAWN ARE AFRICAN-AMERICAN/BLACK. THIS NEW LOCATION, A $34,000,000 CAMPUS, ALLOWS THE ORGANIZATION TO EXPAND ITS REACH TO THE COMMUNITY. THIS LOCATION WILL INCLUDE A STATE-OF-THE-ART HEALTH CENTER, OFFERING INTEGRATED, HIGH QUALITY MEDICAL, DENTAL, MENTAL HEALTH, SUBSTANCE USE DISORDER, AND MAMMOGRAM/ULTRASOUND SERVICES TO A "MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED AREA" THAT PREDOMINANTLY SERVES LOW-INCOME INDIVIDUALS. REUSING A VACANT PROPERTY AT AN IMPORTANT COMMERCIAL/TOD NODE, THE MEDICAL CAMPUS SUPPORTS CITY OF CHICAGO REDEVELOPMENT EFFORTS AT THE 63RD & COTTAGE GROVE INTERSECTION, CENTRAL TO THE REVITALIZATION OF WOODLAWN. THIS PROJECT CREATES AN ADDITIONAL 100 CONSTRUCTION JOBS AND BRINGS 276 PERMANENT FULL-TIME JOBS. ADDITIONALLY, THE CAMPUS HAS INTENTIONALLY BEEN DESIGNED TO TRULY SERVE AS A CENTER FOR THE COMMUNITY. THE FRIEND HEALTH MEDICAL CAMPUS HAS DEDICATED COMMUNITY SPACE, WHERE IN ADDITION TO ROBUST HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROGRAMMING, FRIEND HEALTH SEEKS TO MAKE THE SPACE AVAILABLE FOR COMMUNITY USE. LIKEWISE, THE CAMPUS INCORPORATES AN IMMEDIATE CARE CLINIC, TO FURTHER INCREASE COMMUNITY ACCESS TO HEALTHCARE IN THE MOST COST-EFFECTIVE MANNER. FINALLY, THE DESIGN CAN ACCOMMODATE SPACE TO SUPPORT LOCAL RETAILERS, WHO MIGHT NOT OTHERWISE HAVE ACCESS TO A PRIME RETAIL CORRIDOR. WHILE WE ANTICIPATE THIS LOCATION TO OPEN IN SUMMER OF THIS YEAR (2022), WE ARE REQUESTING FUNDING FOR SOME ESSENTIAL EQUIPMENT FOR OUR 55 PRIMARY CARE EXAM ROOMS AND 4 POINT OF CARE TESTING ROOMS. EQUIPMENT NEEDED INCLUDE SCALES FOR OUR PEDIATRIC AND ADULT POPULATIONS, CHAIRS FOR BLOOD DRAWS, CHAIRS FOR PATIENT EXAM ROOMS, HAND SANITIZER, AUTOMATIC PAPER TOWEL DISPENSERS, WASTE BINS, SHARPS DISPOSAL CONTAINERS, OBSTETRICAL DOPPLER PROBES, AND STORAGE FOR EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING MEDICATION. WE ARE ALSO REQUESTING FUNDING FOR COMPREHENSIVE VACCINATION SERVICES, INCLUDING ADMINISTRATION, TRACKING AND STORAGE OF VACCINES, PPE, TEMPERATURE CHECKING, AND OTHER RELATED EQUIPMENT AND MATERIALS.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE UCLA MOBILE HEALTHCARE PROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO REACH THE MOST VULNERABLE PATIENTS; UNHOUSED VETERANS AND OTHERS EXPERIENCING HOMELESSNESS, THE UNINSURED AND THE UNDOCUMENTED WHO OFTEN STRUGGLE TO RECEIVE PREVENTATIVE CARE. INSTEAD, WE BRING MEDICAL AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE TO THESE VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES BY PARTNERING WITH AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS TO TREAT PATIENTS IN NOVEL SETTINGS, LIKE HOMELESS ENCAMPMENTS.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PROJECT ABSTRACT  APPLICANT ORGANIZATION:                    PALO VERDE HOSPITAL DISTRICT PROJECT ADDRESS: 			         250 N. 1ST STREET BLYTHE, CA 92225 PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: 	    	          LIZ MANJARREZ CONTACT PHONE: 			         (760) 921-5120 EMAIL ADDRESS: 			         LIZ.MANJARREZ@PALOVERDEHOSPITAL.ORG WEBSITE ADDRESS: 			        HTTPS://WWW.PALOVERDEHOSPITAL.ORG FUNDING REQUESTING: 			$352,345.00 PROJECT GUIDANCE NUMBER: 		HRSA22-134  FY 2022 CONSOLIDATED APPROPRIATIONS ACT (P.L. 117-103) FUNDS WERE APPOINTED BY THE 36TH DISTRICT CONGRESSMAN RAUL RUIZ, MD OUT OF CALIFORNIA TO ASSIST PALO VERDE HOSPITAL DISTRICT IN ACQUIRING A MUCH NEEDED 37-FOOT LONG (APPROX.) MOBILE MEDICAL CLINIC. THIS MOBILE MEDICAL CLINIC WILL CONSIST OF TWO EXAM ROOMS, A LAB STATION AND WILL BE FULLY FUNCTIONAL FOR TELEHEALTH SERVICES. THE PALO VERDE HOSPITAL MOBILE CLINIC -PVHMC WILL CLOSE THE HEALTH DISPARITIES GAP AND UNMET HEALTH NEEDS FOR THE PALO VERDE VALLEY BY PROVIDING IMMEDIATE ACCESS IN QUALITY HEALTHCARE; PREVENTATIVE AND PRIMARY CARE SERVICES, DISEASE PREVENTION (VACCINATIONS), PATIENT EDUCATION, MENTAL AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE SCREENING, TREATMENT, AND REFERRAL PROCESS.    THERE ARE FOUR LOCAL AREAS THAT MAKE UP THE PALO VERDE VALLEY; BLYTHE, RIPLEY, PALO VERDE AND MESA VERDE, WHICH ARE HOME TO 19,581 RESIDENTS. BLYTHE AND ITS SURROUNDING SERVICE AREAS ARE CONSIDERED RURAL HEALTH AREA WITH HIGH POVERTY RATES, A FEDERALLY DESIGNATED MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED AREA AND A HEALTH PROFESSIONAL SHORTAGE AREA IN MENTAL HEALTH, PRIMARY CARE, AND DENTAL. ACCORDING TO THE 2020 CENSUS REPORTER, BLYTHE HAS A 58% HISPANIC AND 11% AFRICAN AMERICAN WITH A 62% POVERTY RATE BETWEEN CHILDREN AND SENIORS. CONSEQUENTLY, MOST OF THE PALO VERDE COMMUNITY DON’T OWN A VEHICLE OR HAVE FUNDS TO TRAVEL OUT OF TOWN FOR HEALTHCARE SERVICES OR CAN DRIVE TO THE LOCAL HOSPITAL, WHICH IS OVER 10MILES FROM THEIR HOMES. AS A RESULT, THERE ARE HIGHER HEALTH NEEDS IN HEART DISEASE, OBESITY, DIABET ES HEALTH EDUCATION, SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND MENTAL HEALTH TREATMENT.    DUE TO THESE FINDINGS, THE PVHMC WILL ADDRESS THE HEALTHCARE CHALLENGES AND SOCIAL DETERMINANTS BY PROVIDING REMOTE HEALTHCARE SERVICES WITHIN WALKING DISTANCE FROM COMMUNITY MEMBERS HOMES ON MON-FRI FROM 8AM-5PM AND ROTATING WEEKENDS. EACH AREA WILL HAVE A DESIGNATED SITE WHERE THE MOBILE CLINIC WILL BE PROVIDING SERVICES (COMMUNITY STATE PARKING LOTS OR PARKS CLOSE TO RESIDENTS’ HOMES) SUCH AS, LOW-INCOME APARTMENT COMPLEXES. THE DILEMMA OF PATIENT’S HEALTH WORSENING, MISSED APPOINTMENTS, AND DELAYED MEDICAL CARE, WILL BE ADDRESSED BY TESTING/ASSESSING, TREATING/TRIAGE, REFERRING/COLLABORATING WITH OTHER PHYSICIANS AND BY PROVIDING TELEHEALTH SERVICES FOR CONTINUED CONTINUITY OF CARE.   THE PVHD’S MOBILE CLINIC’S CAPACITY WILL EXPAND SERVICES BY PARTICIPATING IN THE CALIFORNIA PRIME/QIP INITIATIVE, BIENESTAR DIABETIC PROGRAM, AND MOU’S /COLLABORATION WITH OTHER HEALTH FACILITIES. IN ADDITION, THE  PVHD HAS GREAT TEAM THAT CONSISTS OF CARE COORDINATORS, COMMUNITY HEALTH PROMOTORS, NURSE PRACTITIONERS AND ROTATING MD'S WHOM ARE EMPATHETIC, DEDICATED TO PATIENTS AND EAGER TO ADDRESS THESE HEALTH DISPARITIES OUT IN THE COMMUNITY. FURTHERMORE, WITH THIS MOBILE CLINIC IT WILL TRANSITION QUALITY OF CARE INTO WHOLE PERSON CARE HEALTHY PEOPLE 2023 OUTCOMES WHILE IMPLEMENTING A NEW LEVEL OF IMPROVED EFFICIENCY IN MOBILE HEALTHCARE IN THE PALO VERDE VALLEY.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - TITLE: BUILDING A CAREGIVER-CENTERED APPROACH TO DATA COLLECTION & ANALYSIS   ROSALYNN CARTER INSTITUTE FOR CAREGIVERS, INC.  PO BOX 647, AMERICUS, GA 31709   PROJECT DIRECTOR: KARL BOND, DIRECTOR OF OPERATIONS & ADMINISTRATION  PHONE: 706.530.1396  EMAIL: OPS@ROSALYNNCARTER.ORG  WWW.ROSALYNNCARTER.ORG  FUNDS REQUESTED: $1,100,000   MORE THAN 53 MILLION PEOPLE SERVE AS UNPAID OR INFORMAL FAMILY CAREGIVERS IN THE UNITED STATES, THOSE WHO ARE SUPPORTING THE PHYSICAL, MENTAL, FINANCIAL, AND/OR SOCIAL NEEDS OF A RELATIVE, FRIEND, OR LOVED ONE.  CAREGIVERS FACE DISPROPORTIONATE PHYSICAL AND MENTAL HEALTH IMPACTS AS A RESULT OF THEIR CAREGIVING ROLES.  YET, THERE IS LIMITED UNDERSTANDING OF WHAT DRIVES THESE ADVERSE HEALTH EFFECTS AND WHAT CAN BE DONE TO REDUCE OR ELIMINATE THEM.  THIS FUNDING REQUEST FOR THE CAREGIVER DATABASE PROGRAM AT THE ROSALYNN CARTER INSTITUTE FOR CAREGIVERS (RCI), WILL ENABLE RCI TO BETTER MANAGE AND SHARE DATA WITH PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS TO SUPPORT THE IDENTIFICATION AND ADOPTION OF BEST PRACTICES.  FURTHER, IT WILL SUPPORT TRAINING OF STAFF AND PARTNERS TO UTILIZE DATA TO EFFECTIVELY IDENTIFY CHARACTERISTICS OF CAREGIVERS MOST LIKELY TO BENEFIT FROM COACHING PROGRAMS, ASSESS NEEDS AND CHALLENGES ACROSS DIFFERENT CAREGIVER GROUPS, AND ADAPT PROGRAMS TO SUPPORT CAREGIVERS IN GEORGIA AND, ULTIMATELY, THROUGHOUT THE COUNTRY.  CURRENTLY RESEARCHERS OFTEN SHARE FINDINGS ABOUT PROGRAMMATIC OUTCOMES MONTHS OR EVEN YEARS AFTER PROGRAMS CONCLUDE, AND THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OF THE CAREGIVER DATABASE PROGRAM WOULD EXPEDITE THE PROCESS OF COLLECTING AND MINING DATA TO DEMONSTRATE OUTCOMES AT THE POPULATION LEVEL.  RCI WILL UTILIZE THIS PROGRAM TO EXPAND ON OUR ABILITY TO SHARE OUR FINDINGS WITH THE PUBLIC AND CAREGIVER COMMUNITY, INCLUDING OUR PARTNERS AND INTERESTED CAREGIVER STAKEHOLDER COMMUNITIES, IN ORDER TO APPLY OUR LEARNINGS AND PROMOTE THE FASTER SCALING OF EFFECTIVE PROGRAMS TO REACH AND SUPPORT A GREATER POPULATIO N OF CAREGIVERS.   OVER ITS 35-YEAR HISTORY, THE ROSALYNN CARTER INSTITUTE FOR CAREGIVERS (RCI) HAS CONSISTENTLY STRIVED TO ENSURE THAT EVIDENCE-BASED AND EVIDENCE-INFORMED PROGRAMMING IS A CORE ELEMENT OF OUR ORGANIZATIONAL STRATEGY. IN RECOGNITION OF THE IMPORTANCE OF DATA TO INFORM  WORK WITH FAMILY CAREGIVERS, RCI HAS INVESTED OVER $3 MILLION IN ITS CAREGIVER DATA PLATFORM OVER THE PAST 4 YEARS. INITIALLY, THIS PLATFORM FOCUSED ON DATA FROM RCI’S CAREGIVER COACHING PROGRAMS, PROVIDING US WITH FOUNDATIONAL KNOWLEDGE OF HOW A DATA SYSTEM CAN BEST BE UTILIZED TO SUPPORT CAREGIVERS AND INFORM BOTH OUR WORK AND THE WORK OF OTHERS IN THE CAREGIVING SPHERE.? UNDER THE CURRENT SYSTEM, PARTNERS WHO LICENSE RCI PROGRAMS BENEFIT FROM THE SYSTEM WITH SUPPORT FROM RCI STAFF. THE PLANNED NEXT ITERATION OF THIS PLATFORM WILL OFFER A CENTRALIZED, ROBUST, AND ADAPTABLE SYSTEM FOR DATA COLLECTION, ANALYSIS, AND REPORTING BY DISPARATE ORGANIZATIONS WITHIN A LARGE AND GROWING NETWORK OF PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS SERVING CAREGIVERS.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - AN EVIDENTIAL BREATH ALCOHOL TESTING INSTRUMENT IS ONE OF THE MORE CRITICAL LINKS BETWEEN ARREST AND CONVICTION OF DWI IN OUR JUSTICE SYSTEM. THE CURRENT INSTRUMENT USED IN NEW MEXICO, THE INTOXILYZER 8000 (IR8000), PROVIDES LAW ENFORCEMENT PERSONNEL WITH THE EVIDENCE NEEDED TO SUCCESSFULLY PROVE THEIR CASE IN A COURT OF LAW. THE IR8000 HAS BEEN THE ONLY EVIDENTIAL BREATH ALCOHOL TESTING INSTRUMENT IN NEW MEXICO SINCE 2007, WITH SOME INSTRUMENTS IN USE SINCE 2003. MAINTENANCE AND REPAIRS OF THE IR8000 INSTRUMENTS HAVE BECOME COSTLY AND TIME-CONSUMING. THIS IS DUE TO REPLACEMENT PART SCARCITY AND RESOURCE LIMITATIONS. IT HAS BECOMING INCREASINGLY DIFFICULT FOR THE NEW MEXICO BREATH ALCOHOL PROGRAM TO PROVIDE OFFICERS WITH THE REQUIRED TOOLS TO INVESTIGATE AND PROSECUTE DWI OFFENSES. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO REPLACE THE EXISTING IR8000 INSTRUMENTS WITH THE NEWER AND BETTER-SUPPORTED MODEL INTOXILYZER 9000 (IR9000). THIS NEW GENERATION OF INSTRUMENTS HAS BEEN AVAILABLE SINCE 2013 AND IS EXPECTED TO BE IN PRODUCTION FOR ANOTHER TEN TO FIFTEEN YEARS. THE UPGRADING OF ALL EXISTING INSTRUMENTS TO THE NEWER MODEL IR9000 WILL SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE THE TIME AND MONEY SPENT ON MAINTENANCE AND REPAIRS. IT WILL ALSO DECREASE TURNAROUND TIME AND COSTS FOR INSTRUMENTS THAT REQUIRE MANUFACTURER REPAIRS. MOST IMPORTANTLY, THE PURCHASE WILL ENSURE CONTINUED SERVICE FOR ALL LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES. UPGRADING TO NEWER AND CURRENTLY SUPPORTED INSTRUMENTATION IS ESSENTIAL TO ENSURING THE MOST RELIABLE AND HIGHEST QUALITY OF SERVICE FROM NEW MEXICO’S BREATH ALCOHOL PROGRAM.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - DR.  GREGORY PAVEZA CHICAGO STATE UNIVERSITY. 9505 SOUTH KING DRIVE, BHS 607, CHICAGO IL 60628 773 995 3987, GPAVEZA@CSU.EDU  NOT ONLY IS THERE A SHORTAGE OF PROFESSIONALS READY TO STEP INTO THE QUICKLY GROWING HEALTH SCIENCES FIELDS, BUT THERE IS ALSO A SHORTAGE OF DIVERSE CANDIDATES. FOR EXAMPLE: IN ILLINOIS, 8.4% OF NURSES ARE AFRICAN AMERICAN AND 4.5% ARE HISPANIC OR LATINX. NATIONWIDE, 3.1% OF OCCUPATIONAL THERAPISTS ARE AFRICAN AMERICAN AND 3.2% ARE HISPANIC OR LATINX.  THIS UNDER REPRESENTATION CONTRIBUTES TO ONGOING SHORTAGES IN THE FIELDS, MISSED OPPORTUNITIES FOR BLACK AND HISPANIC AND LATINX COMMUNITIES TO ACCESS CAREERS THAT ARE GROWING AND WELL PAYING, AND LOWER QUALITY OF CARE FOR PATIENTS OF COLOR. THE RATIO OF HEALTH SCIENCE PROFESSIONALS WHO ARE PEOPLE OF COLOR TO PATIENTS OF COLOR MATTERS: IMPLICIT BIAS IS LESSENED, MORE TIME IS SPENT TOGETHER, AND OTHER INDICATORS OF CARE QUALITY IMPROVE.  CHICAGO STATE UNIVERSITY (CSU) IS A DRIVING FORCE IN DIVERSIFYING WHO IS ABLE TO STEP IN HEALTH SCIENCES FIELDS. CSU IS ILLINOIS’ ONLY FOUR-YEAR PREDOMINANTLY BLACK INSTITUTION AS DESIGNATED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION. IN THE LAST ACADEMIC YEAR, 70% OF OUR STUDENTS ARE BLACK AND 8% ARE LATINX. BEYOND EDUCATING DIVERSE STUDENTS, THE INSTITUTION HAS RECEIVED SUPPORT TO ENHANCE OUR EDUCATIONAL FACILITIES. CSU ALSO HAS STRONG HEALTH SCIENCES PROGRAMS THAT INCLUDES NURSING, OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY, AND PHARMACY.  AS PART OF REBUILD ILLINOIS, THE STATE’S MULTI-YEAR INFRASTRUCTURE PACKAGE, GOVERNOR PRITZKER APPROPRIATED AND FUNDED THE RENOVATION OF AN EXISTING BUILDING ON CSU’S CAMPUS TO BUILD AN INTER PROFESSIONAL HEALTHCARE SIMULATION LAB AND SPACE FOR THE COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES AND COLLEGE OF PHARMACY. THIS INVESTMENT WILL CREATE STATE-OF-THE-ART SIMULATION LABS FOR ACUTE CARE, EMERGENCY CARE AND LABOR AND DELIVERY, WHILE EXPANDING A BASIC SKILLS LABORATORY, PEDIATRIC LABORATORY, ALONG WITH A FULL APARTMENT FOR HOME CARE. THIS INTER-PR OFESSIONAL HEALTH CARE SIMULATION WILL BRING TOGETHER HEALTH INFORMATION MANAGEMENT, NURSING, OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY, PHARMACY AND PUBLIC HEALTH STUDENTS TOGETHER IN ADDRESSING THE NEEDS OF PATIENTS, FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES. THIS SHARED SPACE AND RELATED PROGRAMMING WILL ENHANCE THE COLLABORATION ACROSS HEALTH CARE PROGRAMS AND ENHANCE RESEARCH THAT ADDRESSES HEALTH DISPARITIES AND NEEDS OF MEDICALLY UNDER SERVED COMMUNITIES. CSU HAS A LONG HISTORY OF PRODUCING A HIGH NUMBER OF AFRICAN AMERICAN AND HISPANIC HEALTH PROFESSIONALS ACROSS THE DISCIPLINES WHO RETURN TO WORK IN HEALTH PROFESSIONAL SHORTAGE AREAS AND MEDICALLY UNDER SERVED COMMUNITIES.   TO MAKE OPERATIONAL THE SPACE, A SIGNIFICANT INVESTMENT OF $450,000 IS REQUIRED. THIS INVESTMENT WILL SUPPORT REAL-LIFE TRAINING EXPERIENCES THROUGH TECHNOLOGY, SPECIALIZED MANIKINS AND STANDARDIZED PATIENT ENVIRONMENTS. THIS TRAINING WILL RESULT IN HEALTH PRACTITIONERS WHO ARE CARING AND HOLD CUTTING-EDGE KNOWLEDGE.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PROJECT TITLE: NEOSHO MEMORIAL REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTER (NMRMC) NUCLEAR MEDICINE PROCUREMENT PROJECT  APPLICANT ORGANIZATION: NEOSHO MEMORIAL REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTER   ADDRESS: 629 S PLUMMER AVE., CHANUTE, KS 66720 WEBSITE: HTTPS://WWW.NMRMC.COM FACILITY TYPE: NONPROFIT WITHOUT 501C3 IRS STATUS     PROJECT DIRECTOR: ANNA METHVIN, DIRECTOR OF FOUNDATION OF NEOSHO MEMORIAL REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTER    CONTACT INFORMATION: 620-432-5496, ANNA_METHVIN@NMRMC.COM PROPOSED SERVICE REGION: NEOSHO COUNTY, KANSAS (FULLY RURAL UNDER HRSA)  GRANT FUNDS: $1,000,000 (HRSA-22-134 - CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING)     NEOSHO MEMORIAL REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTER (NMRMC) HAS SPENT MORE THAN 68 YEARS PROVIDING HIGH-QUALITY COMPASSIONATE HEALTHCARE TO THE GREATER NEOSHO COUNTY AREA. NMRMC IS CERTIFIED BY THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENT, MEDICARE AND MEDICAID PROGRAMS AND IS A 25-BED LICENSED CRITICAL ACCESS FACILITY. NMRMC STAFF PROVIDES CARE TO APPROXIMATELY 45,000 PATIENTS ANNUALLY, INCLUDING DIAGNOSTIC TESTS, EMERGENCY ROOM VISITS, OUTPATIENT CARE, FAMILY MEDICAL PRACTICE, AND OUTPATIENT SURGERY AND INPATIENT SERVICES. THE HOSPITAL HAS A LONG HISTORY OF SEEKING TO MEET THE HEALTH CARE NEEDS OF THE ENTIRE NEOSHO AND SOUTHEAST KANSAS POPULATION, AND HAS THE RESOURCES TO EFFECTIVELY LEAD, COORDINATE, AND MANAGE ITS NUCLEAR MEDICINE PROGRAM TO ENSURE THAT IT EFFECTIVELY ADDRESSES HEALTH ACCESS AND OUTCOME DISPARITIES EXPERIENCED BY VULNERABLE POPULATIONS IN THE NMRMC’S SERVICE AREA.  NMRMC SEEKS TO IMPLEMENT SERVICES THAT INCREASE ACCESS TO CARE AND CARE COORDINATION SERVICES, AS WELL AS SUPPORTING THE LONG-TERM GOAL OF SUSTAINING SERVICES FOR THE COMMUNITY THAT ADDRESS BOTH CLINICAL CARE AND THE SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF CARE.  THE NUCLEAR MEDICINE PROJECT WILL HELP IMPROVE HEALTH OUTCOMES FOR THE COMMUNITY AND ALIGN RESOURCES TO ACHIEVE EFFICIENCIES WHILE WORKING TOGETHER AS A TEAM TO FOSTER BOTH HEALTHY LIFESTYLES AND PROMOTE IMPROVED MENTAL HEALTH.  NUCL EAR MEDICINE IMAGINING IS CRITICAL IN TREATING A VARIETY OF CONDITIONS AND/OR TO EVALUATE HOW A PARTICULAR TREATMENT MAY BE WORKING ON THE BODY.  ACCORDING TO THE CLEVELAND CLINIC, “NUCLEAR MEDICINE IMAGING IS A METHOD OF PRODUCING IMAGES BY DETECTING RADIATION FROM DIFFERENT PARTS OF THE BODY AFTER A RADIOACTIVE TRACER IS GIVEN TO THE PATIENT. THE IMAGES ARE DIGITALLY GENERATED ON A COMPUTER AND TRANSFERRED TO A NUCLEAR MEDICINE PHYSICIAN, WHO INTERPRETS THE IMAGES TO MAKE A DIAGNOSIS.”  NUCLEAR MEDICINE IS PRIMARILY USED TO DIAGNOSE AND TREAT ILLNESSES INCLUDING BLOOD DISORDERS, THYROID DISEASE, HEART DISEASE, GALLBLADDER DISEASE, LUNG PROBLEMS, BONE PROBLEMS, KIDNEY DISEASE, CANCER, AND MANY MORE.   NUCLEAR MEDICINE EXPANDS ACCESS TO QUALITY OF HEALTHCARE SERVICES, SPECIFICALLY RURAL AREAS SUCH AS CHANUTE.  THIS WILL BE VERY CRITICAL TO THE LOCAL COMMUNITY AND BEYOND INCLUDING NEOSHO COUNTY AND IN THE EXTENDED NMRMC SERVICE AREA’S CONTIGUOUS COUNTIES, INCLUDING ALLEN COUNTY, WILSON COUNTY, AND LABETTE COUNTY.  FURTHERMORE, THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE HEALTH OUTCOMES FOR THE POPULATION.

SUPPORTED BY AN EXPERIENCED, NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED LEADERSHIP TEAM, ROY A. JENSEN, MD, HAS LED KUCC ON A STRONG UPWARD TRAJECTORY THAT HAS BEEN CATALYZED BY OVER $467M PHILANTHROPIC SUPPORT SINCE 2004. THE RESEARCH OF THE KUCC FACULTY MEMBERS IS SUPPORTED IN PART BY SEVERAL CORE FACILITIES AND SHARED RESOURCES ON THE KUMC CAMPUS. THESE ENHANCEMENTS WILL INCREASE OUR COMPETITIVE CAPABILITIES AND ALSO ADVANCE TEAM SCIENCE BY FOSTERING INNOVATIVE PARTNERSHIPS AND COLLABORATIONS.

PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME:	        MARK WHEELER CONTACT PHONE NUMBER:	417-836-5101  EMAIL ADDRESS:		        MARKWHEELER@MISSOURISTATE.EDU WEBSITE ADDRESSES:		HTTPS://DESIGN.MISSOURISTATE.EDU/  IN THE LAST 50 YEARS MISSOURI STATE UNIVERSITY’S (MSU) ENROLLMENT IN SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING AND MATHEMATICS FIELDS – KNOWN AS STEM – HAS GROWN FROM 1,000 TO 2,400 STUDENTS.  GRADUATE ENROLLMENT IN STEM PROGRAMS HAS DOUBLED IN THE LAST 25 YEARS.  DESPITE ENROLLMENT AND RESEARCH GROWTH, THE UNIVERSITY’S STEM FACILITIES HAVE REMAINED MOSTLY UNALTERED FOR DECADES.  THESE FACILITIES NO LONGER MEET MODERN SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNOLOGICAL NEEDS FOR WORKFORCE TRAINING, EDUCATION AND RESEARCH.  NOT ONLY DOES THIS FACILITY SUPPORT 1,100 STEM STUDENTS ON OUR CAMPUS BUT OVER 9,000 STUDENTS WILL TAKE LABS, ORGANIC CHEMISTRY OR FIRST YEAR SCIENCE CLASSES IN THE CENTER EACH YEAR.  MSU PROPOSES TO EXPAND AND RENOVATE TEMPLE HALL – CURRENTLY AT 125,000 SQ FT FACILITY BUILT IN 1971. STUDENTS WHO GRADUATE FROM THESE PROGRAMS PURSUE CAREERS IN HEALTH CARE, BIOCHEMISTRY, PHARMACOLOGY, IMMUNOLOGY AND DATA SCIENCE. COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: DR. SCOTT TOMAR CONTACT PHONE NUMBERS: 312-413-7365 EMAIL ADDRESS: STOMAR@UIC.EDU  WEBSITE ADDRESS, IF APPLICABLE: HTTPS://DENTISTRY.UIC.EDU/COMMUNITY-HEALTH/PREVENTION-PUBLIC-HEALTH/   UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS CHICAGO (UIC) COLLEGE OF DENTISTRY AND ORAL HEALTH FORUM (OHF) – A CHICAGO-BASED COMMUNITY NOT-FOR-PROFIT ORGANIZATION – ARE PARTNERING TO DELIVER COMMUNITY-BASED ORAL CARE DISEASE MANAGEMENT AND PREVENTION SERVICES. THE DELIVERY MODEL FOCUSES ON AGGRESSIVE ORAL DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION, WITH A PRIMARY FOCUS ON IMPROVING HEALTH OUTCOMES. THIS COLLABORATIVE EFFORT SEEKS TO REDUCE ORAL HEALTH DISPARITIES IN THE PILSEN COMMUNITY AND TO INCREASE ACCESS TO CARE FOR LOW-INCOME FAMILIES, ESPECIALLY CHILDREN. THE GOALS OF THE PROGRAM ARE:  (1)	PROVIDE PREVENTION AND EARLY INTERVENTION ORAL HEALTH SERVICES, INCLUDING NUTRITIONAL AND DIETARY COUNSELING, CARIES RISK ASSESSMENT, PERIODONTAL MAINTENANCE, MINIMALLY INVASIVE CARIES CONTROL, AND TOBACCO USE INTERVENTION; (2)	DEVELOP INTERPROFESSIONAL EDUCATION AND EXPERIENCES FOR STUDENTS IN UIC’S HEALTH PROFESSION PROGRAMS, INCLUDING DENTISTRY, NUTRITION, PUBLIC HEALTH, NURSING, AND SOCIAL WORK, TO IMPROVE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR RESIDENTS OF THE PILSEN COMMUNITY.   THE PILSEN CLINIC SITE IS OWNED BY THE CITY OF CHICAGO AND HAS SPACE THAT HAD ONCE BEEN A CITY-OPERATED DENTAL CLINIC. HOWEVER, THE DENTAL CLINIC HAS NOT BEEN USED IN MANY YEARS IS IN NEED OF REPAIR, RENOVATION, AND EQUIPMENT TO BE ABLE TO PROVIDE DENTAL SERVICES. THIS GRANT WILL ENABLE US TO RENOVATE THE SPACE, INSTALL NEW CABINETRY AND FIXTURES, FURNISH THE DENTAL OFFICE AND ORAL HEALTH EDUCATION ROOM, AND EQUIP THE THREE OPERATORY ROOMS WITH NEW DENTAL CHAIRS AND DELIVERY SYSTEMS.    THE MAIN SERVICES TO BE PROVIDED AT THE SITE INCLUDE:  1.	CARIES RISK ASSESSMENT AND EVIDENCE-BASED CARIES PREVENTION SERVICES SUCH AS FLUORIDE VARNISH, DENTAL SEALANTS, PRESCRIPTION OF HIGH-FLUORIDE TOOTHPASTES AND MOUTH RINSE S.  2.	PERIODONTAL MAINTENANCE 3.	MINIMALLY INVASIVE CARIES CONTROL  4.	NUTRITIONAL COUNSELING  5.	TOBACCO USE INTERVENTION, INCLUDING COUNSELING, PHARMACOTHERAPY, AND APPROPRIATE REFERRAL 6.	REFERRALS AND LINKAGES WITH SOCIAL AND HEALTH SERVICES   A DIVERSE NETWORK OF UIC’S ACADEMIC HEALTH PROGRAMS AND OHF WILL SUPPORT PATIENTS IN ACCESSING A HOLISTIC SYSTEM OF CARE THAT INCORPORATES DENTAL, NUTRITIONAL, SOCIAL, AND PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICES. HEALTH PROFESSIONAL STUDENTS WILL GAIN FIRST-HAND EXPERIENCE IN WORKING WITHIN INTERPROFESSIONAL TEAMS TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITY.

JOSEPH MEDICAL CENTER -	CONTACT PHONE:  (309 ) 655-5784 -	CONTACT EMAIL:  LYNN.A.FULTON@OSFHEALTHCARE.ORG -	WEBSITE:  HTTPS://WWW.OSFHEALTHCARE.ORG/ST-JOSEPH/  -	GRANT FUNDS REQUESTED:  $700,000  OSF ST. JOSEPH MEDICAL CENTER IS A 149-BED ACUTE CARE HOSPITAL SERVING THE BLOOMINGTON-NORMAL REGION IN CENTRAL ILLINOIS. OSF ST. JOSEPH MEDICAL CENTER WILL USE GRANT FUNDS FOR THE RENOVATION OF SPACE WITHIN THE HOSPITAL TO HOUSE THE NEW FAMILY MEDICINE RESIDENCY PROGRAM. THIS SPACE WILL BE CONSTRUCTED TO MEET THE REQUIREMENTS NECESSARY FOR ACGME ACCREDITATION FOR THE FAMILY MEDICINE RESIDENCY PROGRAM, TO INSURE A HIGH QUALITY EDUCATION AND PHYSICAL LEARNING SPACE FOR RESIDENTS. THIS SPACE WILL ACCOMMODATE 6 RESIDENTS PER YEAR FOR EACH YEAR OF THE THREE YEAR RESIDENCY PROGRAM, FOR A TOTAL OF 18 RESIDENTS IN THE OSF ST. JOSEPH LEARNING ENVIRONMENT.   OSF HAS IDENTIFIED SPACE (TOTAL OF 3,782 SQ FT) FOR THE PROGRAM IN OSF ST. JOSEPH’S EASTLAND MEDICAL PLAZA II (EMP 2), 2200 EAST WASHINGTON STREET, BLOOMINGTON, ILLINOIS 61704.  THE HOSPITAL IS LOCATED CLOSE TO THE CORNER OF VETERANS PARKWAY AND EMPIRE IN BLOOMINGTON, WHICH IS A MAJOR INTERSECTION IN THE CENTER OF BLOOMINGTON – NORMAL. THE LOCATION IS FULLY OWNED BY OSF HEALTHCARE.   EMP 2 IS CONNECTED TO THE HOSPITAL, WHICH IS CONVENIENT FOR THE RESIDENTS. THE MAJORITY OF THE SPACE (3,653 SQ FT) WAS FORMALLY USED AS A CARDIOLOGY CLINIC WITH OTHER AREAS (129 SQ FT) FORMALLY USED AS STORAGE AND A CONFERENCE ROOM. RENOVATING THIS AREA WILL ENABLE THE RESIDENCY PROGRAM TO HAVE ADEQUATE SPACE FOR LEARNING WHILE REMAINING CLOSE TO THE HOSPITAL.   THE FAMILY MEDICINE RESIDENCY SPACE WILL INCLUDE OFFICES FOR SUPPORT STAFF (PROGRAM DIRECTOR, PROGRAM COORDINATOR, ETC.) AND FACULTY, CONFERENCE AND EDUCATION SPACE THAT INCLUDES TECHNOLOGY WITH ACCESS TO LEARNING FROM TH E OSF FLAGSHIP HOSPITAL (OSF SAINT FRANCIS MEDICAL CENTER) AND HEADQUARTERS IN PEORIA AS WELL AS OTHER SISTER HOSPITALS, BREAKROOMS, SHOWERS AND BATHROOMS, QUIET ROOMS, AND MODULAR WORK STATIONS WITH SPACE FOR CHARTING AND ACCESSING INFORMATION.   NEED EARLY IN 2019 OSF ST. JOSEPH LEADERSHIP BEGAN DISCUSSIONS WITH SYSTEM LEADERSHIP AND THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS COLLEGE OF MEDICINE PEORIA REGARDING DEVELOPING A FAMILY MEDICINE RESIDENCY PROGRAM IN THE OSF EASTERN REGION (BLOOMINGTON-PONTIAC-URBANA-DANVILLE). BLOOMINGTON-NORMAL WAS IDENTIFIED AS THE CHOSEN LOCATION BECAUSE OF PRIMARY CARE NEED, MARKET DYNAMICS (GROWING), UN-OPPOSED ENVIRONMENT (MEANING RESIDENTS DO NOT HAVE TO COMPETE WITH OTHER GME RESIDENTS FOR CASES) AND AVAILABILITY OF FACULTY.   OSF MEDICAL GROUP HAS A LARGE WELL-DEVELOPED PRIMARY CARE NETWORK IN AND AROUND THE BLOOMINGTON NORMAL MARKET; HOWEVER MANY OF THE PHYSICIANS ARE AT THE AGE OF RETIREMENT OR WILL BE AT THAT AGE WITHIN THE NEXT 5 YEARS. IN TODAY’S WORLD, IT IS VERY HARD TO RECRUIT PHYSICIANS TO DOWNSTATE ILLINOIS UNLESS THEY ARE FROM THE AREA OR TRAINED IN THE AREA. A FAMILY MEDICINE RESIDENCY PROGRAM WILL HELP OSF GROW FAMILY PRACTICE PHYSICIANS AND INSURE LONG TERM ACCESS TO PRIMARY CARE SERVICES FOR THE COMMUNITY. RESEARCH STUDIES HAVE DOCUMENTED A LINK BETWEEN THE NUMBER OF PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIANS AND APP’S IN AN AREA AND THE HEALTH STATUS OF THE POPULATION.   THE 2020 POPULATION OF THE BLOOMINGTON-NORMAL AREA WAS ESTIMATED TO BE 201,268. IN CONTRAST TO THE REST OF ILLINOIS, THE AREA EXPERIENCED AN INCREASE IN POPULATION FROM 2010, WHEN THE POPULATION WAS 186,444. THE POPULATION AGES 65 YEARS AND OVER INCREASED FROM 20,720 (2010) TO 31,689 (2020), A CHANGE OF 10,969 (52.9%). THE POPULATION IS 77.3% WHITE; 9.7% BLACK; 8.6% ASIAN; 6.2% HISPANIC OR LATINO; AND 2.9% TWO OR MORE RACES.

AT PRESENT ONLY DENTAL EXTRACTIONS CAN BE PERFORMED DUE TO LIMITED SPACE AND EQUIPMENT. THIS EXPANSION WILL PROVIDE AMPLE SPACE AND EQUIPMENT THAT WILL ALLOW EXPANSION OF SERVICES FOR DIAGNOSTIC, PREVENTATIVE, RESTORATIVE, AND PROSTHODONTIC SERVICES I.E., FILINGS, CLEANINGS, AND DENTURES FOR THE UNINSURED POPULATION IN TARGET SERVICES AREAS. DUE TO LACK OF ACCESS TO DENTAL CARE, MANY TIMES POOR DENTAL HEALTH LEADS TO OTHER MEDICAL COMPLICATIONS SUCH AS HEART DISEASE, AND RESPIRATORY ISSUES. THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW EARLY DENTAL HEALTH INTERVENTION SO THAT MORE ADULTS INCLUDING SENIORS AGED 50+ ACCESS TO COMPREHENSIVE DENTAL CARE. WE SERVE ADULT POPULATIONS AGED 18 AND ABOVE. COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - SAVING PATIENT LIVES REQUIRES INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGY TO SERVE THE NEEDS OF HAWAII’S HOSPITALS AND EFFECTIVELY MANAGE EVOLVING PATHOGENS LIKE COVID-19, THE CURRENT BLOOD BANK OF HAWAII FACILITY MUST BE REPLACED. IT IS MORE THAN 42 YEARS OLD AND IN NEED OF MAJOR REPAIRS AND UPGRADES, AND FACES CHALLENGES INCLUDING:   -	BBH IS ONLY ONE OF TWO BLOOD CENTERS NATIONWIDE STILL USING OLD BLOOD FILTRATION TECHNOLOGY: THE CURRENT FACILITY CANNOT ACCOMMODATE THE WALK-          IN REFRIGERATION SYSTEM NEEDED TO CARRY OUT INDUSTRY-STANDARD BLOOD FILTRATION PROCESSES.  UNDERTAKING UPGRADES AND THE REPAIRS NEEDED AT THE          CURRENT FACILITY ARE COST PROHIBITIVE. -	STATE-OF-THE-ART STERILIZATION OF BLOOD PRODUCTS AGAINST VIRUSES SUCH AS ZIKA AND OTHER DEADLY DISEASES THAT EMERGE AND THREATEN OUR          COMMUNITY, CANNOT BE ACCOMMODATED AT THE CURRENT FACILITY.  -	WITH THE DEPLOYMENT OF COVID-19 VACCINES, WE LEARNED THE IMPORTANCE OF COLD CHAIN STORAGE, WHICH OUR CURRENT LOCATION CANNOT EFFECTIVELY          ACCOMMODATE.  THE CURRENT BLOOD BANK OF HAWAII FACILITY CANNOT BE UPDATED TO MEET FUTURE PRIORITIES. THE CONSTRUCTION OF A NEW 19,000-SQUARE-FOOT HEADQUARTERS AND FDA BIOSAFE LEVEL 2 FACILITY IS DESIGNED TO ENSURE BLOOD IS AVAILABLE TO ALL PATIENTS ON ALL HAWAIIAN ISLANDS WHEN NEEDED. THIS NEW PERMANENT HOME WILL OPERATE 24 HOURS A DAY, SEVEN DAYS A WEEK, PROVIDING UNRESTRICTED ACCESS TO COLLECT, PROCESS, TEST, STORE AND DISTRIBUTE BLOOD. THE NEW DONOR CENTER AND STORAGE FACILITY WILL UTILIZE HIGHLY SOPHISTICATED TEMPERATURE CONTROLS, RELIABLE BROADBAND CONNECTIVITY, A BIO-WASTE STORAGE AREA, ALONG WITH OTHER ESSENTIAL TECHNOLOGIES, ALLOWING HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS THE ABILITY TO PERFORM ADVANCED MEDICAL PROCEDURES HERE IN HAWAII.  IN ADDITION, THIS NEW FACILITY WILL GIVE BBH NEW OPPORTUNITIES TO DEVELOP SOCIAL ENTERPRISES TO ENSURE FINANCIAL SELF-SUFFICIENCY WHICH WILL INCREASE OUR ABILITY TO SUPPORT OUR MISSION.  KEY FEATURES OF THE NEW FACILITY INCLUDE:  -	NATION’S REPOSITORY FOR RARE BLOOD, FOUND PRIMARILY AMONG POLYNESIAN AND JAPANESE ETHNICITIES -	FEATURES THAT WILL ACCOMMODATE EMERGING AND LIFE-SAVING TECHNOLOGIES -	WORKFLOW DESIGN TO ELIMINATE ANY POSSIBLE CONTAMINATION OF BLOOD PRODUCTS -	COLD CHAIN STORAGE CAPABILITIES TO STORE PRODUCTS REQUIRING ULTRA-LOW FREEZER TEMPERATURES -	ADDRESSING THE NEED FOR TELECONFERENCING ROOMS TO ACCOMMODATE REMOTE CONSULTATION -	DESIGNED SPACE FOR PROGRAMS TO TRAIN YOUNG PEOPLE IN EMERGING HEALTHCARE CAREERS  -	SUFFICIENT SPACE (9,000 SQUARE FEET) TO ENABLE FUTURE EXPANSION -	ENERGY-EFFICIENT DESIGN

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE LSU HEALTH SHREVEPORT CENTER FOR MEDICAL EDUCATION AND EMERGING VIRAL THREATS BUILDING IS A TRANSFORMATIVE PROJECT THAT WILL PROVIDE THE UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY FOR LSU HEALTH SHREVEPORT TO ADVANCE ITS NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL VIRAL PATHOGENESIS AND PUBLIC HEALTH RESEARCH, WHILE ALSO TRAINING THE NEXT GENERATION OF MEDICAL DOCTORS AND SCIENTISTS TO SERVE THE CITIZENS OF LOUISIANA AND THE NATION.  CREATION OF THE CENTER FOR EMERGING VIRAL THREATS (CEVT) RESEARCH LABS WILL ENCOMPASS BIOLOGICAL SAFETY LEVEL 3 AND 2 LABORATORIES COUPLED WITH A COMPLEX MOLECULAR CLIA/CAP CERTIFIED TESTING LABORATORY ENABLING BOTH ADVANCED RESEARCH ON VIRAL PATHOGENS AND MOLECULAR TESTING FOR DIFFERENT VIRUSES SERVING PUBLIC HEALTH NEEDS.  IN ADDITION, THE CEVT RESEARCH FACILITY CONTAINS SPECIALIZED EDUCATION CAPABILITIES TO TRAIN INDIVIDUALS (STUDENTS, PHYSICIANS, AND SCIENTISTS) IN PROPER AND ADVANCED SAFETY ENVIRONMENTS NEEDED TO PERFORM HIGHLY SENSITIVE RESEARCH.  THE BUILDING IS ALSO DESIGNED TO PROVIDE STATE OF THE ART FACILITIES FOR MEDICAL EDUCATION INCLUDING ADVANCED SIMULATION TRAINING, ADVANCED COMPUTING AND DIGITAL CLASS ROOMS, ALONG WITH SMALL TEAM GROUP INSTRUCTIONAL OPPORTUNITIES.  THIS MODERN, STATE OF THE ART FACILITY WILL ENABLE LSU HEALTH SHREVEPORT AND THE STATE OF LOUISIANA TO ATTRACT TOP-NOTCH STUDENTS, TRAINEES, AND FACULTY FROM ACROSS THE NATION AND WORLD WHILE PROVIDING ADVANCED MEDICAL AND RESEARCH OPPORTUNITIES AND SERVICES FOR THE REGION.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY: ADDRESS: 1184 W. MAIN ST. DECATUR, IL 62522-2039 PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: RUBY JAMES, VICE PRESIDENT FOR FINANCE  CONTACT PHONE NUMBERS:  (217) 424-5071 EMAIL ADDRESS: RUBYJAMES@MILLIKIN.EDU WEBSITE ADDRESS: HTTPS://MILLIKIN.EDU/  WITH CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED FUNDING, MILLIKIN UNIVERSITY SEEKS TO PROVIDE THE SCHOOL OF NURSING ITS OWN DEDICATED BUILDING TO CREATE FACULTY OFFICES, CLASSROOMS, AND CLINICAL AND SIMULATION LABORATORIES THAT WILL MIRROR MEDICAL OFFICES AND HOSPITAL PATIENT ROOMS. THESE ADVANCEMENTS WILL INCLUDE A CONTROL ROOM IN WHICH FACULTY CAN MONITOR A NURSE-PATIENT SIMULATION VIA COMPUTER AND USE A MICROPHONE TO TALK TO STUDENTS AS THEY WORK. THIS RENOVATION WILL ALSO INCLUDE PRE-BRIEF, SIMULATION, AND DEBRIEF AREAS AS WELL AS CAMERAS AND RECORDING EQUIPMENT SO THAT STUDENT PERFORMANCES DURING THE SIMULATION CAN BE OBSERVED AND REVIEWED BY INSTRUCTORS AND CLASSMATES. TO ATTRACT AND RETAIN QUALIFIED STUDENTS AND FACULTY, AS WELL AS REMAIN ABREAST OF BEST STANDARDS OF PRACTICE IN SIMULATION EDUCATION, THERE IS AN IMMEDIATE NEED TO UPGRADE CURRENT EQUIPMENT AND CREATE DEDICATED SIMULATION ENVIRONMENTS AT MILLIKIN UNIVERSITY IN DECATUR, ILLINOIS. FURTHER ENHANCEMENT OF OUR FACILITIES WILL NOT ONLY ALLOW STUDENTS TO BE EXPOSED TO A REALISTIC, BUT ALSO AN INNOVATIVE PEDAGOGY TO CONTRIBUTE TO THEIR ABILITY TO TAKE PART AND EXCEL IN HANDS-ON PERFORMANCE LEARNING, A HALLMARK OF THE UNIVERSITY. A DEDICATED FACILITY WILL ENHANCE STUDENT ENGAGEMENT AND OUTCOMES, IMPROVE FACULTY AND STAFF EFFICIENCY AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, AND INCREASE OVERALL COLLABORATION. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES TWO CRITICAL PROBLEMS IN CENTRAL ILLINOIS: THE PROJECTED NURSING SHORTAGE AND THE EXODUS OF COLLEGE-BOUND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS TO OUT-OF-STATE COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES. A NEW FACILITY WITH UP-TO-DATE CLINICAL AND SIMULATION LABORATORIES WILL ADDRESS THE NEED FOR NURSES AND CREATE A STRONG PIPELINE OF MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS FOR OUR VALUED CO MMUNITY PARTNERS, AS WELL AS OTHER HOSPITALS AND CLINICAL SETTINGS ACROSS CENTRAL ILLINOIS. THESE MUCH-NEEDED TECHNOLOGICAL UPGRADES WILL ALSO HELP ATTRACT AND ENCOURAGE COLLEGE-BOUND STUDENTS, BOTH HIGH SCHOOL AND NONTRADITIONAL, TO STAY IN ILLINOIS FOR THEIR EDUCATION.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - MORTON COUNTY HEALTH SYSTEMS PROPOSED FACILITY UPGRADE PROJECT IS REQUESTING FUNDS TO IMPROVE HEALTH CARE RESOURCES FOR RURAL RESIDENTS OF SOUTHWESTERN KANSAS. THIS HOSPITAL HAS STRUGGLED DUE TO LACK OF FUNDING FOR FACILITY MODERNIZATION. WITH THE IMPROVEMENTS ACCESSIBLE THROUGH THIS GRANT, WE WILL RENOVATE AND HIRE THE PROVIDERS WE’VE STRUGGLED TO ATTRACT. WE HAVE LONG FEARED LOSING THE HOSPITAL  BECAUSE IT IS A FINANCIAL STRUGGLE TO MEET THE STRINGENT REQUIREMENTS FROM OSHA, CMS, AND OTHER AGENCIES THAT HAVE JURISDICTION ON HOSPITAL AND CLINIC OPERATIONS.  MORTON COUNTY HOSPITAL WAS ORIGINALLY BUILT IN 1957. ADDITIONS WERE ADDED IN 1978 AND 1986. OVER THE PAST 20 YEARS, DUE TO LIMITED FUNDS, THE FACILITY HAS NOT BEEN MAINTAINED AND IS IN DESPERATE NEED OF RESTORATION. THE CONSTRUCTION PLAN DOES NOT ADD SQUARE FOOTAGE BUT RENOVATES EXISTING FACILITIES, BRINGING THEM INTO COMPLIANCE WITH MODERN MEDICAL PRACTICES.  SOME OF THE AREAS IN THE HOSPITAL HAVE NOT BEEN USEABLE DUE TO LACK OF FUNDS FOR MAINTENANCE. THIS GRANT WILL ALLOW THE HOSPITAL TO REOPEN THE GERIATRIC-PSYCHIATRIC UNIT, MUCH NEEDED IN THE COMMUNITY BUT REQUIRING UPDATING WITH LIGATURE EQUIPMENT TO BE LICENSED. OTHER LINE ITEMS IN THE BUDGET RENOVATE THE RECEPTION AREAS, THE EMERGENCY ROOM, THE CONTROLLED MAIN ACCESS DOORS, CHILLER REPAIRS, REPLACING THE C-ARM WHICH IS USED FOR THE PAIN MANAGEMENT PROCEDURES AND THE REQUIRED EXAM BED FOR THE PROCEDURES.  THE GERI-PSYCHIC UNIT AND C-ARM ADD REVENUE IMPROVING HOSPITAL SUSTAINABILITY. SINCE OUR FACILITY DOES NOT HAVE SURGERY, PATIENTS NEEDING EMERGENCY SURGERY MUST BE AIR LIFTED TO OTHER HOSPITALS. SEVERAL HELICOPTERS HAVE DECLINED TO LAND BECAUSE WE ONLY HAVE A GRASS AND GRAVEL LANDING AREA. THIS GRANT WILL ALLOW US TO CONSTRUCT AN ILLUMINATED, COMPLIANT LANDING PAD OF CONCRETE ON THE EXISTING LANDING AREA.  WE FEEL THAT THESE PROPOSED IMPROVEMENTS WILL POSITION THE HOSPITAL TO CONTINUE PROPERLY FOR THE NEXT 5-10 YEARS.

INITIATIVE THAT WILL ESTABLISH A NEW LEVEL OF CARE TO ITS EXISTING CONTINUUM.  KNOWN AS EXTENDED STAY TREATMENT, IT IS ARGUABLY THE MOST CRITICAL LEVEL OF CARE, AND WILL HELP TO CREATE A FULL ARRAY OF ROBUST TREATMENT INTERVENTIONS IN ONE LOCATION.  IN ORDER TO PROVIDE THAT LEVEL OF CARE, VETERANS INC. IS REQUESTING FUNDING FOR NEW CONSTRUCTION DESIGN OF A 20,000 SQUARE FOOT FACILITY, WHICH WILL INCLUDE A MULTI-LEVEL RESIDENTIAL BUILDING CO-LOCATED WITH ALL OTHER LEVELS OF CARE AT THE INDEPENDENCE HALL CAMPUS. COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW ENGLAND (UNE) IS MAINE’S LARGEST PRIVATE UNIVERSITY AND ITS LARGEST EDUCATOR OF HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONALS. UNE IS CONSTRUCTING THE INSTITUTE OF INTERPROFESSIONAL EDUCATION AND PRACTICE ON ITS PORTLAND CAMPUS (IIPEP). UNE’S INSTITUTE WILL SERVE AS THE NEW HOME TO UNE'S COLLEGE OF OSTEOPATHIC MEDICINE, WHICH IS THE LARGEST PROVIDER OF PHYSICIANS FOR MAINE. THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND THE MEDICAL SCHOOL CLASS SIZE FROM 175 TO 200 STUDENTS ANNUALLY IN RESPONSE TO EXISTING AND PROJECTED PHYSICIAN WORKFORCE SHORTAGES. UNE ALSO WILL BUILD THE INFORMATION TECHNOLOGICAL INFRASTRUCTURE NECESSARY TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT DIGITAL HEALTH CURRICULA FOR MEDICAL AND HEALTH PROFESSIONS STUDENTS. THIS WILL INCLUDE TELEHEALTH, VIRTUAL SIMULATION, ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE, AND OTHER DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES THAT PREPARE UNE HEALTH PROFESSIONS STUDENTS FOR VIRTUAL HEALTHCARE DELIVERY TO RURAL AND UNDERSERVED MAINERS. THROUGH THE CO-LOCATION OF UNE’S COLLEGES OF OSTEOPATHIC MEDICINE, HEALTH PROFESSIONS, AND DENTAL MEDICINE ON THE PORTLAND CAMPUS, UNE WILL ESTABLISH A COMPREHENSIVE INTERPROFESSIONAL HEALTH EDUCATION SETTING WITH 2,500 HEALTH PROFESSIONS STUDENTS UNPARALLELED IN NEW ENGLAND. THIS WILL SUBSTANTIALLY EXPAND UNE’S CAPACITY TO DEVELOP NEW MODELS FOR INTERPROFESSIONAL EDUCATION, CLINICAL PRACTICE, AND RESEARCH NEEDED FOR HEALTHCARE EDUCATION AND PRACTICE REFORMS.   UNE’S PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE NUMBER OF AVAILABLE SEATS FOR PHYSICIAN EDUCATION AT THE COLLEGE OF OSTEOPATHIC MEDICINE BY NEARLY 15 PERCENT. THIS WILL SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE MAINE’S AND THE NATION’S PHYSICIAN PIPELINE.  THE ROBERT GRAHAM CENTER FOR POLICY STUDIES AND FAMILY MEDICINE IN PRIMARY CARE PREDICTS THAT MAINE WILL NEED AN ADDITIONAL 120 PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIANS BY 2030. THIS ANALYSIS ACCOUNTS FOR POPULATION CHANGES, AGING, AND THE IMPACT OF THE ACA. CURRENTLY, MORE THAN FOUR IN 10 MAINE PHYSICIANS ARE BETWEEN THE AGES OF 55 AND 74. THE U.S. HEALTH RESOURCES AND SERVICES  ADMINISTRATION HAS DESIGNATED PRIMARY CARE HEALTH PROFESSIONAL SHORTAGE AREAS AND MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED AREAS IN EACH OF MAINE’S 16 COUNTIES. MAINE IS THE OLDEST STATE IN THE NATION, WITH NEARLY ONE IN FIVE RESIDENTS AGED 65 OR OLDER. IN 2019, GOVERNOR JANET MILLS EXPANDED MEDICAID (MAINECARE) UNDER THE AFFORDABLE CARE ACT. AS OF MAY 2021, NEARLY 78,000 ADDITIONAL MAINERS HAVE ACCESS TO MAINECARE. WHILE THIS EXPANSION IS A WELCOME IMPROVEMENT IN HEALTHCARE ACCESS FOR THE UNDERSERVED, 78,000 ADDITIONAL PATIENTS ADDS PRESSURE TO THE PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIAN WORKFORCE.  UNE’S COLLEGE OF OSTEOPATHIC MEDICINE WILL BE A CRITICAL ASSET IN FILLING THE U.S. NEED FOR PHYSICIANS. FOUNDED IN 1978, UNE’S OSTEOPATHIC MEDICAL SCHOOL HAS GRADUATED OVER 4,000 OSTEOPATHIC PHYSICIANS INTO THE U.S. WORKFORCE. UNE’S MEDICAL SCHOOL IS MAINE’S LARGEST EDUCATOR OF PHYSICIANS, BOTH HISTORICALLY AND CURRENTLY. IN 2018, UNE GRADUATED MORE PHYSICIANS INTO THE MAINE PHYSICIAN WORKFORCE THAN TUFTS (WHICH OPERATES A MAINE TRACK PROGRAM), DARTMOUTH, AND THE UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS MEDICAL SCHOOLS COMBINED. FURTHERMORE, 65 PERCENT OF UNE’S OSTEOPATHIC MEDICINE GRADUATES PRACTICE A PRIMARY CARE SPECIALTY, ONE-THIRD PRACTICE IN A RURAL AREA, AND ONE IN FIVE PRACTICE IN A MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED AREA. WITH THE CONSTRUCTION OF UNE’S INSTITUTE FOR INTERPROFESSIONAL EDUCATION AND PRACTICE, WE WILL EXPAND CLASS ENROLLMENT TO 200 OSTEOPATHIC MEDICINE STUDENTS, A NEARLY 15 PERCENT INCREASE OVER CURRENT ENROLLMENT LEVELS. THIS IS ESSENTIAL TO ENSURING AN ADEQUATE SUPPLY OF PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIANS FOR THE FUTURE.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE ADVOCATE TRAUMA RECOVERY CENTER (TRC) IS A HEALTH CARE-BASED, TRAUMA-INFORMED PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES COMPREHENSIVE, EVIDENCE-BASED SERVICES TO VICTIMS, SURVIVORS, AND FAMILIES OF INTENTIONAL VIOLENCE. GUIDED BY A MISSION TO AID IN THE RECOVERY AND ESTABLISHMENT OF PERSONAL SAFETY AND STABILITY, TRC SERVICES INCLUDE INDIVIDUAL AND GROUP THERAPY, 2) SUPPORT AND ADVOCACY GROUPS, 3) OUTPATIENT CLINICAL ASSESSMENTS, 4) MEDICATION MANAGEMENT, 5) SAFETY AND SELF-CARE GUIDANCE AND, 6) CASE MANAGEMENT. THE TRC MEETS PATIENTS WHERE THEY ARE AT, AND OFFERS SERVICES THAT MEET EACH INDIVIDUAL’S, EMOTIONAL, PSYCHOLOGICAL, AND SPIRITUAL NEEDS. BY PROVIDING COMPREHENSIVE WRAPAROUND SERVICES, THE TRC IS BETTER ABLE TO ENHANCE STABILITY AND SENSE OF FELT SAFETY IN SURVIVORS AND THEIR FAMILIES. ALL CARE ADHERES TO CULTURALLY HUMBLE AND TRAUMA-INFORMED GUIDELINES, AS WELL AS FOLLOWS BEST PRACTICES BY DATA-DRIVEN RESEARCH, INCLUDING UTILIZATION OF THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS WITH EVIDENCE-BASED EFFICACY FOR TREATMENT OF TRAUMA-AND-STRESSOR RELATED DISORDERS. THE TRC PROVIDES CARE REGARDLESS OF ABILITY TO PAY, BOTH UNINSURED AND UNDERINSURED. THE TRAUMA RECOVERY CENTER WAS DEVELOPED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE ILLINOIS CRIMINAL JUSTICE INFORMATION AUTHORITY AND FUNDED IN PART BY THE VICTIMS OF CRIME ACT.    PROJECT FUNDING RATIONALE  MANY COMMUNITIES IN TRC SERVICE AREAS HAVE LITTLE ACCESS TO BEHAVIORAL HEALTH AND CASE MANAGEMENT SERVICES, DUE IN PART TO GEOGRAPHIC LOCATION AND INEQUITABLE HEALTH RESOURCE DISTRIBUTION. INDIVIDUALS IN THESE AREAS MUST OFTEN TRAVEL LONG DISTANCES TO RECEIVE SPECIALIZED TRAUMA CARE. RESIDENTS OFTEN HAVE LIMITED MEANS WITH HIGHER RATES OF POVERTY AND UNEMPLOYMENT, LOWER LEVELS OF EDUCATION, HIGHER INCIDENCE OF CHRONIC ILLNESS AND DISABILITY, AND MORE RECENTLY, ARE MOST IMPACTED BY COVID-19.  FOR MANY CLIENTS, AS WELL AS THOSE WITH DISABILITIES, RIDESHARE AND PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION ARE NOT ALWAYS POSSIBLE OPTIONS, AS THEY ARE COST PROHIBITIVE  AND NOT DISABILITY FRIENDLY. TRANSPORTATION ACCESS AND THE DIGITAL DIVIDE ARE CRITICAL SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH THAT THE TRC HOPES TO ADDRESS THROUGH THIS REQUEST. THE LOWERED-FLOOR MINI VANS WILL PROVIDE A SAFE MODE OF TRANSPORTATION TO AND FROM CARE, AS WELL AS BE USED FOR WRAPAROUND SUPPORT SUCH AS TRANSPORTING CLOTHING AND FOOD IF NEEDED. CHROMEBOOKS WILL PROVIDE CLIENTS WITH VITAL ACCESS TO TELEHEALTH SERVICES AND EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES. AS A RESULT OF COVID-19, OVER 50 PERCENT OF TRC’S SESSIONS NOW OCCUR VIRTUALLY, WHICH HAS UNEXPECTEDLY BOTH INCREASED CLIENT PARTICIPATION AND REDUCED CANCELATIONS. MOVING FORWARD, THE TRC WILL EMPLOY A HYBRID IN-PERSON/VIRTUAL MODEL, WHICH WILL ALLOW THE TRC TO CONTINUE PRESENT THE OPTION OF TELEHEALTH FOR THOSE IN GREATEST NEED.   CONCLUSION  ADVOCATE CHRIST MEDICAL CENTER OPENED IN 1961 FOLLOWING A FUNDRAISING EFFORT LED BY SOUTHLAND COMMUNITY MEMBERS. THANKS TO THE COMMITMENT OF ALL WHO BELIEVE IN ITS MISSION, ADVOCATE CHRIST MEDICAL CENTER HAS EVOLVED INTO ONE OF THE TOP HOSPITALS IN THE UNITED STATES. THE TRC THERE SERVES A CRITICAL PURPOSE IN THE COMMUNITY, AND IN THIS ERA OF DECLINING REIMBURSEMENTS AND INCREASING HEALTH NEEDS, WE BELIEVE THAT SHOULD THIS COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING REQUEST BE APPROVED, IT WOULD MAKE A SIGNIFICANT DIFFERENCE IN ENSURING ACCESS TO THE VERY BEST CARE FOR SURVIVORS OF TRAUMA. THANK YOU FOR YOUR CONSIDERATION.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ANDY'S PLACE II:  CREATING LONG TERM HOUSING TO COMBAT THE OPIATE CRISIS ANDY’S PLACE II PROPOSES TO BUILD 26 UNITS OF HOUSING INTENDED TO SUPPORT THE LONG-TERM HOUSING AND SOCIAL SERVICE NEEDS FOR PERSONS IN RECOVERY FROM OPIATE ADDICTION AND INCLUDES 15 ONE-BEDROOM UNITS AND 11 TWO-BEDROOM UNITS.   PREGNANT WOMEN AND FAMILIES WITH INFANT CHILDREN IN RECOVERY FROM ADDICTION WILL BE PRIORITIZED FOR TENANCY AT ANDY’S PLACE II.    ANDY’S PLACE II HAS ATTRACTED THE ATTENTION OF FAMILIES WHO HAVE LOST LOVED ONES TO OPIATE ADDICTION AND THEIR COMMENTS ABOUT ANDY’S PLACE II HAVE BEEN UNIVERSALLY THE SAME; IF ONLY ANDY’S PLACE HAD BEEN AVAILABLE, MY SON OR DAUGHTER OR FATHER OR MOTHER OR FRIEND MIGHT STILL BE ALIVE.  IN 2019, OPIOID OVERDOSES KILLED 1,768 MICHIGANDERS, AN AVERAGE OF ALMOST FIVE PEOPLE EVERY SINGLE DAY ACCORDING TO THE MICHIGAN OPIATES TASK FORCE 2020 ANNUAL REPORT.  AT ANDY'S PLACE II, FAMILIES WILL LIVE IN A SAFE, DRUG FREE ENVIRONMENT AND HAVE THE SUPPORT OF PROPERTY MANAGEMENT STAFF, CASE MANAGERS AND THERAPISTS WORKING AT THE BUILDING AS WELL AS SUPPORT FROM FELLOW TENANTS WHO ARE ALSO IN RECOVERY FROM ADDICTION.   TO BECOME A TENANT AT ANDY’S PLACE II, FAMILIES WOULD NEED TO FOLLOW STRICT LEASE AGREEMENTS INCLUDING MAINTAINING SOBRIETY AS A CONDITION OF TENANCY AND RANDOM DRUG TESTING.  SUBSIDIZED APARTMENT RENTS WOULD ALLOW VERY LOW INCOME FAMILIES TO RESIDE AT ANDY’S PLACE II.    ANDY’S PLACE II WILL ALSO ADDRESS THE HEART BREAKING CONSEQUENCES OF DRUG ADDICTION FOR PREGNANT WOMEN AND THEIR UNBORN AND SUPPORT THESE FAMILIES WITH THEIR STRUGGLE TO MAINTAIN SOBRIETY.  THE COMMUNITY ACTION AGENCY (CAA), CO-OWNER OF ANDY’S PLACE II, WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT SERVICES FOR FAMILIES.  CAA IS BOTH A PROVIDER FOR THE EARLY HEAD START AND HEAD START PROGRAMS AND WILL PROVIDE THESE SERVCIES FOR FAMILIES AT ANDY'S PLACE II.  FEDERAL FUNDING FOR ANDY'S PLACE II WILL PAY A PORTION OF THE PROJECT'S CONSTRUCTION COST.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ABSTRACT   PROJECT DIRECTOR: TIM SCHULTE				   PROJECT TITLE: NEW HEALTH PROFESSIONS BUILDING   APPLICANT NAME: MISSOURI VALLEY COLLEGE (“MVC”)   ADDRESS: 500 E. COLLEGE STREET, MARSHALL, MO 65340   PHONE: (660)831-4043   EMAIL: SCHULTET@MOVAL.EDU   PROJECT PERIOD: JULY 1, 2022 THROUGH JUNE 30, 2024      THIS APPLICATION REQUESTS SUPPORT FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF A NEW SCHOOL OF NURSING AND HEALTH SCIENCES ACADEMIC FACILITY AT MISSOURI VALLEY COLLEGE IN ORDER TO MEET THE CURRENT AND GROWING DEMAND FOR PRIMARY CARE PROVIDERS LOCALLY, STATE-WIDE AND NATIONALLY. THE NEW FACILITY WILL REPLACE THE EXISTING OUTGROWN SCHOOL OF NURSING CURRENTLY HOUSED IN THE BASEMENT OF A LOCAL HOSPITAL, MORE THAN DOUBLING THE CAPACITY OF THE MVC SCHOOL OF NURSING PROGRAM THE PROJECTED COST OF THE NEW FACILITY IS $5,291,750. MISSOURI VALLEY COLLEGE IS REQUESTING A CONSTRUCTION GRANT FROM HRSA OF $2,000,000. THE REMAINING $3,291,750 IS BEING FUNDED BY MVC FROM DONATIONS OF ALUMNI, FRIENDS OF THE COLLEGE, NON-PROFIT FOUNDATIONS, AND THE CITY OF MARSHALL. THE NEW FACILITY WILL BE COMPLETED WITHIN 24 MONTHS OF THE EXPECTED START DATE OF JUNE 1, 2022.       MISSOURI VALLEY COLLEGE WILL BUILD THE NEW 16,300 SQUARE-FOOT SCHOOL OF NURSING AND HEALTH SCIENCES BUILDING TO HOUSE THE NURSING PROGRAM, AND ULTIMATELY OTHER HEALTH CARE PROFESSION PROGRAMS, TRAINING AND GRADUATING CRITICALLY NEEDED NURSES TO MEET SIGNIFICANT STATE AND RURAL WORKFORCE SHORTAGES. THE NEW FACILITY WILL HOUSE STATE-OF-THE-ART TECHNOLOGY, SIMULATION, AND COMPUTER LABS, AND WILL PROVIDE SPACE FOR OTHER HEALTH PROFESSIONS AS THE INDUSTRY CONTINUES TO EVOLVE.    MISSOURI VALLEY COLLEGE CURRENTLY HOSTS A BACHELOR OF SCIENCE IN NURSING WITH TWO TRACKS: LPN TO BSN (ONLINE & FACE-TO-FACE) FOR CURRENTLY LICENSED LPNS AND A TRADITIONAL BSN. THE COLLEGE ALSO HAS A NEW MSN (MASTER OF SCIENCE IN NURSING- FAMILY NURSE PRACTITIONER) IN PLACE AND LOOKS TO ADD PROGRAMS AS THE NEED ARISES.    THE PANDEMIC HAS HIGHLIGHTED  THE IMPORTANCE OF MISSOURI’S HEALTH CARE WORKERS, PARTICULARLY NURSES. JOBS FOR REGISTERED NURSES HAVE GROWN BY 19% BETWEEN 2012 AND 2022, COMPARED TO THE 11% GROWTH AVERAGE FOR ALL OCCUPATIONS, ACCORDING TO THE BUREAU OF LABOR STATISTICS. IN MISSOURI, THE NURSING OCCUPATIONS OF A REGISTERED NURSE, CERTIFIED NURSE ASSISTANT, LICENSED PRACTICAL NURSE, AND NURSE PRACTITIONER HOLD EMPLOYEE VACANCY RATES OF OVER 7%, MARKING A HIGHLY INCREASED DEMAND FOR NURSING PROFESSIONALS. NURSING SHORTAGES ARE EVEN MORE PRONOUNCED WITHIN RURAL COUNTIES. COMPOUNDING THE WORKFORCE SHORTAGE, MORE THAN ONE-THIRD OF MISSOURI’S RNS ARE AGE 55 OR OLDER, INCREASING TO NEARLY HALF IN SOME RURAL COUNTIES, WITH RETIREMENT IMMINENT.   GRADUATES OF THE MISSOURI VALLEY COLLEGE SCHOOL OF NURSING ARE PREPARED TO SERVE IN A VARIETY OF CLINICAL SETTINGS INCLUDING LOCAL COMMUNITY HOSPITALS, TERTIARY CARE CENTERS, COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTERS, CLINICS, AND OTHER AGENCIES. THE BACHELOR’S AND MASTER’S LEVEL NURSING EDUCATION PROGRAMS ARE WELL-RESPECTED; 90% OF MVC NURSING STUDENTS ARE OFFERED A JOB PRIOR TO GRADUATION. THE MISSOURI VALLEY COLLEGE SCHOOL OF NURSING FOLLOWS ALL STANDARDS AND GUIDELINES OF THE MISSOURI STATE BOARD OF NURSING AND THE COMMISSION ON COLLEGIATE NURSING EDUCATION. FOR EVERY NURSE MISSOURI VALLEY COLLEGE EDUCATES AND GRADUATES, THOUSANDS OF LIVES WILL BE POSITIVELY IMPACTED. IN A STATE FACING NURSING SHORTAGES AND AS A COLLEGE SERVING RURAL COUNTIES, THE BENEFITS TO THE COMMUNITY ARE IMMEASURABLE. AMONG ALL MISSOURI VALLEY COLLEGE NURSING GRADUATES, 79% REMAIN IN MISSOURI TO LIVE, WORK, AND RAISE A FAMILY. THE NEW FACILITY REPRESENTS NOT ONLY AN OPPORTUNITY FOR FUTURE GROWTH IN THE LOCAL AND STATE ECONOMY, BUT THE NEW SITE ALSO WIDENS THE PATH TO WELL-PAYING, PROFESSIONAL CAREERS.    MISSOURI VALLEY COLLEGE

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ORGANIZATION:  SHANDS JACKSONVILLE MEDICAL CENTER, INC.  ORGANIZATION ADDRESS: 655 WEST 8TH ST., JACKSONVILLE, FL. 32209 PROJECT DIRECTOR:  JACK GRIEGO, DIVISION DIRECTOR OF CONSTRUCTION SERVICES CONTACT PHONE: (904) 244-5657 (OFFICE) EMAIL: JACK.GRIEGO@JAX.UFL.EDU   PROJECT:  UF HEALTH JACKSONVILLE FINANCIAL EVALUATION DEPARTMENT RELOCATION PROJECT ADDRESS: PROFESSIONAL OFFICE BUILDING (POB), 1833 BOULEVARD ST., JACKSONVILLE, FL. 32206 PROJECT LOCATION: FIRST FLOOR  PURPOSE OF PROJECT: FUNDING OF $705,000 IS REQUESTED FOR RENOVATIONS TO MOVE THE UF HEALTH JACKSONVILLE FINANCIAL EVALUATION DEPARTMENT (FED) TO A NEW SPACE IN THE PROFESSIONAL OFFICE BUILDING (POB), WHERE THE TOTAL CARE CLINIC AND OTHER NECESSARY SERVICES FOR PATIENTS ARE LOCATED.  REQUESTED FUNDING FOR FY22: $705,000  AGENCY: HEALTH RESOURCES AND SERVICES ADMINISTRATION (HRSA)  ACCOUNT: HEALTH FACILITIES CONSTRUCTION AND EQUIPMENT  PROJECT DESCRIPTION: UF HEALTH JACKSONVILLE HAS A LONG-STANDING COMMITMENT TO CARING FOR UNDERSERVED PATIENTS WHO MAY OTHERWISE NOT GET THE CARE THEY NEED. THAT COMMITMENT IS THE CATALYST FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF CREATIVE MODELS OF CARE WHERE THEY ARE TAKING BOLD STEPS TO PROVIDE ONE-STOP HEALTHCARE RESOURCES FOR THEIR MOST VULNERABLE PATIENTS AT THEIR UF HEALTH TOTAL CARE CLINIC – JACKSONVILLE WHICH ADDRESSES THE NEEDS OF PATIENTS WHOSE CARE IS RENDERED THROUGH THE CITY CONTRACT PROGRAM.    THE CONTRACT WITH THE CITY OF JACKSONVILLE PROVIDES HEALTH CARE FOR A SUBSET OF UNINSURED INDIVIDUALS WHO MET SPECIFIC CRITERIA, SUCH AS RESIDENCY IN DUVAL COUNTY, FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE REQUIREMENTS (I.E., THE FAMILY UNIT MAY NOT EXCEED 200% OF THE FEDERAL POVERTY GUIDELINES), A LACK OF HEALTH INSURANCE AND INELIGIBILITY FOR MEDICAID. ABOUT 7,000 TO 8,000 INDIVIDUALS QUALIFY AT ANY GIVEN TIME WHICH INCLUDES THE CITY AND COUNTY PRISON POPULATION. UF HEALTH JACKSONVILLE RECEIVES $30.27 MILLION IN FUNDING ANNUALLY FROM THE CITY OF JACKSONVILLE, AND EXPERIENCES A COST FOR CARE OF $53.5 MILLION.  A CRITICAL ISSUE IS THE RELOCATION OF THE FINANCIAL EVALUATION DEPARTMENT (FED) WHERE PATIENT’S ELIGIBILITY FOR SERVICES IS DETERMINED.  WITH OVER 20,000 PATIENTS EVALUATED YEARLY, FED HAS NOT ONLY REACHED ITS PHYSICAL LIMITATION BUT LACKS THE ABILITY TO EFFICIENTLY CONNECT WITH THE ONE-STOP CARE MODEL SINCE IT IS CURRENTLY LOCATED IN AN OUTDATED BUILDING AT THE EDGE OF THE CAMPUS. REQUESTED FUNDING OF $705,000 WOULD BE FOR RENOVATIONS TO MOVE THE FINANCIAL EVALUATION DEPARTMENT TO A NEW SPACE IN THE PROFESSIONAL OFFICE BUILDING (POB), WHERE THE TOTAL CARE CLINIC AND OTHER NECESSARY SERVICES FOR OUR PATIENTS ARE LOCATED.   UF HEALTH JACKSONVILLE HAS A LONG-STANDING COMMITMENT TO CARING FOR UNDERSERVED PATIENTS WHO MAY OTHERWISE NOT GET THE CARE THEY NEED. PATIENTS SEEN AT THE TOTAL CARE CLINIC HAVE A PANEL OF DOCTORS, NURSES AND OTHER PROVIDERS DEDICATED TO MAINTAINING AND IMPROVING THEIR HEALTH, AS WELL AS, ASSISTING THEM WITH SPECIALTY CARE. IN COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY-BASED AGENCIES, UF HEALTH TOTAL CARE CLINIC HELPS PATIENTS MEET THEIR SOCIAL NEEDS INCLUDING ACCESS TO OPPORTUNITIES FOR EMPLOYMENT, FOOD, AND HOUSING.  CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES TO RELOCATE THE FINANCIAL EVALUATION DEPARTMENT (FED) WILL INCLUDE THE COMPLETE DEMOLITION OF AN EXISTING VACANT OFFICE SUITE LOCATED ON THE FIRST FLOOR OF THE PROFESSIONAL OFFICE BUILDING (POB), AND DESIGN/CONSTRUCTION OF A NEW SUITE THAT MEETS THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE FINANCIAL EVALUATION DEPARTMENT (FED), INCLUDING FURNITURE, FIXTURES & EQUIPMENT (FF&E).

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - 6051 U S HIGHWAY 49 HATTIESBURG MS 39401-7200 JEFFERY COOK JWCOOK@FORRESTGENERAL.COM REQUESTED FUNDS: $7,565,000  FORREST COUNTY GENERAL HOSPITAL ("FORREST GENERAL") HAS REQUESTED FUNDS TO CONSTRUCT AN MEDICAL OFFICE BUILDING TO PROVIDE OUTPATIENT MENTAL HEALTH AND ADDICTION HEALTH CARE SERVICES TO THE FORREST GENERAL'S 19-COUNTY SERVICE AREA. BY WAY OF BACKGROUND, PINE GROVE BEHAVIORAL HEALTH & ADDICTION SERVICES (“PINE GROVE”), A DIVISION OF FORREST COUNTY GENERAL HOSPITAL, OFFERS A VARIETY OF INPATIENT AND OUTPATIENT BEHAVIORAL HEALTH AND ADDICTION SERVICES TO THE COMMUNITY. PINE GROVE IS THE LARGEST HOSPITAL-ASSOCIATED BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE PROVIDER IN THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI SERVING A 19-COUNTY SERVICE AREA IN SOUTH MISSISSIPPI (ALMOST 25% OF THE STATE).   IN ORDER FOR FORREST GENERAL ’S PINE GROVE TO BEST PROVIDE ACCESS TO MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES IN THE COMMUNITY, IT MUST MODERNIZE AND EXPAND ITS CAMPUS TO OFFER OUTPATIENT SERVICES IN A CENTRALIZED AND EFFICIENT LOCATION TO APPROPRIATELY MEET THE LEVEL OF NEED THAT IS READILY APPARENT IN THE COMMUNITY.  IT WOULD BE A TREMENDOUS COMMUNITY BENEFIT TO OFFER AN OUTPATIENT SETTING THAT IS (1) ON THE EXISTING PINE GROVE CAMPUS, (2) IS DESIGNED FOR AND CONDUCIVE TO THE MENTAL HEALTH THERAPIES OFFERED, (3) AVAILABLE TO PROVIDE EVENING OUTPATIENT SERVICES TO PATIENTS WHO ARE WORKING AND RECEIVING THERAPY AFTER WORK, AND (4) IS OF A QUALITY THAT CAN ATTRACT MENTAL HEALTH CLINICIANS AND THE COMMUNITY CAN BE PROUD OF. THUS, WE ARE REQUESTING FUNDING THROUGH THE CONGRESSIONAL DIRECTED SPENDING (CDS) OPPORTUNITY TO PAY FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF A NEW PINE GROVE OUTPATIENT MEDICAL OFFICE BUILDING.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ATLANTIC HEALTH SYSTEM, INC./NEWTON MEDICAL CENTER 175 HIGH STREET NEWTON, NJ 078 ROBERT PEAKE, JR. TEL: 973-971-4959 ROBERT.PEAKE@ATLANTICHEALTH.ORG  WWW.ATLANTICHEALTH.ORG   NEWTON MEDICAL CENTER OF ATLANTIC HEALTH SYSTEM SERVES THE PEOPLE OF SUSSEX AND WARREN COUNTIES IN THE NORTHWEST REGION OF NEW JERSEY.  NEWTON IS THE ONLY ACUTE CARE HOSPITAL LOCATED IN SUSSEX COUNTY, NJ.  LIKE MOST HOSPITALS AROUND THE COUNTRY, NEWTON MEDICAL CENTER HAS SEEN AN INCREASING NEED IN THE COMMUNITY FOR BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES.  WHILE THE STRESSES OF THE PANDEMIC HAVE CERTAINLY PLAYED A ROLE, THE OVERALL RISE IN THE NEED FOR BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE PREDATES THE CORONAVIRUS OUTBREAK AND WILL CONTINUE TO GROW WHEN A DEGREE OF NORMALCY RESUMES IN THE DAILY LIVES OF OUR PATIENTS.    IN PARTICULAR, THE EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT (ED) HAS SEEN A GROWING NUMBER OF CASES PRESENTING FOR TREATMENT, AND THESE CASES REQUIRE SPECIALIZED TREATMENT AREAS THAT ARE REMOVED FROM THE GENERAL POPULATION OF ED PATIENTS. THE BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PATIENTS BEING SEEN IN THE ED ARE INCREASINGLY ACUTE AND INCLUDE AN INCREASE OF SUBSTANCE ABUSE CASES FROM THE OPIOID EPIDEMIC AND FROM ALCOHOL USE.  THE PATIENTS PRESENTING FOR BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE ALSO INCLUDE ADOLESCENTS, CHILDREN, AND GERIATRIC PATIENTS.   DUE TO THE PAUCITY OF INPATIENT BEDS THROUGHOUT THE STATE, PATIENTS NEEDING HOSPITALIZATION TEND TO STAY IN THE EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT FOR LONGER PERIODS.  THE WAITING PERIOD REQUIRES THE EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT TO DRAW MORE RESOURCES TO TREAT AND SAFELY MAINTAIN THE PATIENTS IN AN ENVIRONMENT NOT INTENDED FOR LONG TERM STAYS.  THE CURRENT CAPACITY IN THE NMC EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT IS TWO SMALL SECURE HOLDING AREAS FOR BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PATIENTS AS THEY UNDERGO EVALUATION AND AWAIT A TRANSFER TO AN INPATIENT BED IF NEEDED.  IF A REMEDY IS NOT IMPLEMENTED, NMC WILL CONTINUE TO OVERFLOW THE EXISTING 2 BEHAVIORAL ROOMS REGULARLY.  TO ADDRESS THIS GROWING DEMAND OF BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES IN THE ED , ATLANTIC HEALTH AND NEWTON MEDICAL CENTER WILL ADD A STATE OF THE SCIENCE EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SUITE THAT WILL INCLUDE 5 LARGE PRIVATE ROOMS IN A SECURE AREA OF THE ED, WITH AN ADJACENT OVERFLOW AREA TO ACCOMMODATE SURGES IN CASES.  THIS CAPITAL INVESTMENT WILL DECREASE THE RISK OF HARM TO EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT PATIENTS BY CREATING A DEDICATED 5-BED BEHAVIORAL ZONE IN THE ED.  AGGREGATING 5 BEHAVIORAL-SAFE ROOMS WILL PROVIDE A BETTER ENVIRONMENT OF CARE FOR THE ACUTE PSYCHIATRIC AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE PATIENTS.  ADDITIONALLY, THE NEW BEHAVIORAL HEALTH ZONE WILL ENSURE A SAFER WORKPLACE ENVIRONMENT FOR TEAM MEMBERS AS THEY TREAT THIS VULNERABLE PATIENT POPULATION.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PROJECT TITLE:  NEW FEDERALSBURG HEALTH CENTER ADDRESS:  301 RANDOLPH STREET, DENTON, MD 21629 PROJECT DIRECTOR:  SARA RICH, CEO PHONE:  410-479-8395  FAX:  410-479-1714 EMAIL:  SRICH@CHOPTANKHEALTH.ORG WEBSITE:  CHOPTANKHEALTH.ORG GRANT PROGRAMS FUNDS REQUESTED:  CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING (CDS):  CONSTRUCTION PROJECT HRSA-22-134  IN ORDER TO SUCCESSFULLY IMPLEMENT THE CCHS STRATEGIC PLAN, AN INVESTMENT MUST BE MADE IN UPDATED AND NEW FACILITIES. TO THAT END, THE CCHS BOARD OF DIRECTORS APPROVED THE REPLACEMENT OF THE CURRENT FEDERALSBURG FACILITY. THE CURRENT FEDERALSBURG MEDICAL AND DENTAL CENTER PROVIDES PRIMARY CARE FOR ADULTS, INFANTS AND CHILDREN; BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES WITH ONE BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SPECIALIST AND GENERAL DENTAL SERVICES.  CCHS IS A SITE FOR NYU LANGONE ADVANCED EDUCATION IN GENERAL DENTISTRY (AEGD) RESIDENCY PROGRAM WHICH IS EXPANDING FROM 2 RESIDENTS TO 4 RESIDENTS IN 2022.  PLANS ARE UNDERWAY TO ADD A PEDIATRIC DENTAL RESIDENCY PROGRAM.  ADDITIONALLY, CCHS IS WORKING WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND SCHOOL OF MEDICINE TO BRING A RURAL RESIDENCY PROGRAM TO THE EASTERN SHORE WITH PLANS TO HOUSE THE PROGRAM AT THE NEW FEDERALSBURG LOCATION.  THIS NEW FACILITY WILL ALLOW FOR THESE EXPANSIONS TO OCCUR WHILE INCREASING ACCESS TO MEDICAL AND DENTAL HEALTH CARE FOR THE COMMUNITY.      CCHS SERVICES ARE AVAILABLE FOR ALL RESIDENTS IN THE SERVICE AREA. SPECIFIC TARGET POPULATIONS INCLUDE LOW-INCOME RESIDENTS, UNINSURED AND UNDERINSURED FAMILIES, AND MIGRANT AND SEASONAL WORKERS. COMPARED TO THE REST OF MARYLAND THE CCHS SERVICE AREA HAS HIGHER LEVELS OF POVERTY, ESPECIALLY FOR CHILDREN; A HIGHER PERCENT OF UNINSURED RESIDENTS; LOWER MEDIAN INCOME; FEWER HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATES; AND A HIGHER UNEMPLOYMENT RATE.   THE REPLACEMENT FACILITY WILL SUPPORT QUALITY CARE DELIVERY AND IMPROVE ACCESS SO THAT ALL CAROLINE COUNTY RESIDENTS CAN GET THE CARE THEY NEED WHEN THEY WANT IT. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE AN UPDATED FACILITY FOR COM MUNITY MEMBERS TO RECEIVE MEDICAL, DENTAL AND EXPANDED BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE. CCHS PROPOSES TO CONSTRUCT A ONE FLOOR, APPROXIMATELY 21,000 SQ. FT. BUILDING TO ADDRESS THE REGION’S INCREASED NEED FOR PREVENTIVE AND COMPREHENSIVE PRIMARY CARE, BEHAVIORAL HEALTH, ORAL HEALTH, AND WOMEN’S HEALTH SERVICES. WHEN FULLY OPERATIONAL, CCHS WILL MODEL A “MEDICAL HOME,” STATE OF THE ART FACILITY UTILIZING THE LATEST TECHNOLOGIES TO PROVIDE AN “EXCEPTIONAL PATIENT EXPERIENCE.” THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE GREATER ACCESS TO MEDICAL, DENTAL AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE TO THE RESIDENTS OF CAROLINE COUNTY THEREBY IMPROVING HEALTH OUTCOMES.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - FUNDING WILL SUPPORT THE $4.0M RENOVATION AND EXPANSION OF THE CASSANO HEALTH CENTER, DAYTON’S LARGEST PROVIDER OF PRIMARY AND SPECIALTY CARE AND WRAP AROUND  SERVICES TO THOUSANDS OF UNDERSERVED PATIENTS ANNUALLY.  THE CLINIC IS APPROACHING 20 YEARS OLD AND IS IN DISREPAIR - A SIGNIFICANT REINVESTMENT NOW IN THIS IMPORTANT COMMUNITY ASSET WILL ENSURE THE HEALTH NEEDS OF OUR COMMUNITY CONTINUE TO BE MET INTO THE NEXT GENERATION.  RENOVATION WILL INCLUDE NEW MEDICAL TESTING EQUIPMENT, DIGITAL X-RAY AND STRUCTURAL IMPROVEMENTS TO INCREASE EFFICIENCY.  THE EXPANSION WILL ADD 7 NEW EXAM ROOMS (BRINGING THE TOTAL TO 28), WHICH WILL ENABLE CASSANO TO SERVE UP TO 25% MORE PATIENTS INTO THE FUTURE.  NEW SERVICES THAT WILL BE OFFERED AFTER THE PROJECT IS COMPLETE INCLUDE BEHAVIORAL HEALTH, TELEPSYCHIATRY, ROUTINE DERMATOLOGICAL CARE INCLUDING SKIN BIOPSIES AND JOINT INJECTIONS FOR PAIN MANAGEMENT.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - STANISLAUS COUNTY BEHAVIORAL HEALTH AND RECOVERY SERVICES, LOCATED IN MODESTO, CALIFORNIA (CA-010) IS SEEKING HRSA CONGRESSIONAL DIRECTED SPENDING (CDS) FUNDING TO PARTNER WITH SAN JOAQUIN COUNTY AND MERCED COUNTY ON A JOINT INITIATIVE TO ADDRESS THE SIGNIFICANT SHORTAGE OF MENTAL HEALTH RESIDENTIAL TREATMENT FACILITIES FOR HOMELESS INDIVIDUALS SUFFERING FROM MENTAL ILLNESS IN THE REGION. THE THREE COUNTIES ARE CURRENTLY CONDUCTING A COMPREHENSIVE NEEDS ASSESSMENT AND ANALYSIS. THIS INCLUDES CONDUCTING A HOUSING NEEDS ASSESSMENT TO IDENTIFY CURRENT CAPACITY AND SYSTEM GAPS, FOCUSING ON NEEDS AROUND THE TRANSITIONAL ENHANCED BOARD AND CARE LEVEL. THIS PROCESS WOULD INCLUDE AN ASSESSMENT AND REVIEW OF EACH COUNTIES' CURRENT BUDGET STRUCTURE, INCLUDING INSTITUTION FOR MENTAL DISEASES (IMD), ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS AND AN ANALYSIS OF OPPORTUNITIES TO REDUCE ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS THROUGH REGIONAL ADMINISTRATIVE INFRASTRUCTURE. STANISLAUS COUNTY IS ASKING FOR SUPPORT TO INITIATE THIS WORK, IDENTIFY POSSIBLE BUILDING LOCATIONS FOR THE ENHANCED BOARD AND CARE FACILITY, CONDUCT SITE SURVEYS AND PROCURE INITIAL ARCHITECTURAL PLANS THAT WILL FACILITATE THE IN DEPTH UNDERSTANDING OF THE COST TO BUILD OUT THIS PROPOSED NEW FACILITY. THE THREE-COUNTY REGION WILL IDENTIFY AND RETAIN CONSULTANTS TO DESIGN A FACILITY THAT PROMOTES CLIENT FOCUSED AND CLIENT DRIVEN RECOVERY PRINCIPLES WHILE USING STATE OF THE ART SAFETY STANDARDS TO REDUCE ONGOING STAFFING COSTS. THIS WORK WILL CONCLUDE WITH THE BUILDING OF A FACILITY THAT WILL BE SHARED BY THE THREE PARTICIPATING COUNTIES.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PROJECT ABSTRACT APPLICANT:  SIERRA NEVADA MEMORIAL HOSPITAL FOUNDATION P.O. BOX 1810 GRASS VALLEY, CA 95945  SIERRA NEVADA MEMORIAL HOSPITAL 155 GLASSON WAY GRASS VALLEY, CA 95945   PROJECT DIRECTOR: IDA ARNE, DIRECTOR OF BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT  IDA.ARNE@DIGNITYHEALTH.ORG 530-274-6000 WWW.SUPPORTSIERRANEVADA.ORG WWW.SNMH.ORG  FUNDS AWARDED: $750,000  PROGRAM TITLE: RURAL PRIMARY CARE CLINIC AND HEALTHCARE WORKFORCE EXPANSION INITIATIVE  IN RESPONSE TO THE TREMENDOUS NEED FOR ACCESS TO PRIMARY AND URGENT CARE IN RURAL COMMUNITIES, SIERRA NEVADA MEMORIAL HOSPITAL (SNMH) IS CONSTRUCTING AND EQUIPPING A NEW RURAL PRIMARY CARE CLINIC. THROUGH THE ESTABLISHMENT OF THIS CLINIC, SNMH IS TAKING A MULTI-DISCIPLINARY APPROACH TO ENSURING ACCESS TO APPROPRIATE HEALTH CARE AND TO ENSURING THE CONTINUITY OF CARE FOR THIS AGING AND UNDERSERVED POPULATION.   THE CLINIC WILL BE LOCATED IN WHAT IS LOCALLY REFERRED TO AS HIGGINS CORNER, LOCATED 12.5 MILES SOUTH OF GRASS VALLEY. THIS IS AN UNINCORPORATED COMMUNITY IN NEVADA COUNTY, CALIFORNIA, AND IS LOCATED ON THE BORDER OF THE GRASS VALLEY ZIP CODE OF 95949 AND THE AUBURN ZIP CODE OF 95602 ZIP CODES. THIS CLINIC WILL DRAW HEAVILY FROM THOSE ZIP CODES THAT SUPPORT A POPULATION OF 37,000. THE CLINIC WILL BE 3,200 SQUARE FEET AND PROVIDE SPACE FOR FOUR PHYSICIANS TOTAL WITH THREE PRACTICING IN HOUSE EACH BUSINESS DAY. FOUR TO FIVE ADDITIONAL SUPPORT STAFF JOBS WILL BE CREATED TO SUPPORT THE CLINIC OPERATIONS. IT IS ESTIMATED THAT ONE PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIAN IN RURAL COMMUNITIES CARRIES A PATIENT LOAD OF 2,500. THIS CLINIC WILL ADD THE CAPACITY TO PROVIDE A MEDICAL HOME TO 10,000 RESIDENTS.    TODAY'S RURAL HEALTHCARE SYSTEM IS EXTREMELY FRAGILE, AND OPERATING MARGINS ARE THIN, ESPECIALLY IN RURAL COMMUNITIES. THE SIERRA FOOTHILLS REGION IS HOME TO HIGH UTILIZERS OF HEALTHCARE, PRIMARILY MEDICARE OR MEDI-CAL (MEDICAID) PAYORS, WHERE REIMBURSEMENT DOES NOT COVER THE COST OF CARE.  THE SERVICE AREA OF SNMH INCLUDES 75,000 RURAL RESIDENTS IN WESTERN NEVADA COUNTY. OTHER RURAL CITIES THAT ARE PART OF THE PRIMARY SERVICE AREA INCLUDE: NEVADA CITY (POPULATION 3,068),  PENN VALLEY (POPULATION 1,621), NORTH SAN JUAN (POPULATION 269) AND THE TOWN OF WASHINGTON (POPULATION 97).   NEVADA COUNTY IS HOME TO ONE OF THE OLDEST POPULATIONS IN CALIFORNIA, WITH 26% OVER THE AGE OF 65.  ADDITIONALLY: 18.1% ARE 0-17 YEARS OF AGE; 49.3% ARE 18- 54; AND, 32.6%  (1 IN 3) ARE 55 YEARS AND OLDER.  THE MAJORITY OF PERSONS IN NEVADA COUNTY ARE CAUCASIAN (87.9%). HISPANIC PERSONS REPRESENT 7.5% OF THE POPULATION. THERE ARE A COMPARABLE NUMBER OF MALES (49.6%) AND FEMALES (50.4%) IN THE COUNTY. THE OVERALL POVERTY RATE (LIVING 100% BELOW THE FEDERAL POVERTY RATE) IS 12.9%. THE MEDICAID POPULATION IS 25% (NOT INCLUDING THOSE DUALLY ELIGIBLE FOR MEDICAID AND MEDICARE). THE COUNTY'S MEDIAN INCOME IS $55,724, AND THE UNINSURED RATE IS CURRENTLY AT 6.1%.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - WEAVE SERVES VICTIMS OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE, SEXUAL ASSAULT, AND SEX TRAFFICKING THROUGH AN ARRAY OF SERVICES, INCLUDING A COMPREHENSIVE RESIDENTIAL SERVICES PROGRAM SERVING SURVIVORS AND THEIR CHILDREN. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, WEAVE WILL COMPLETE A SERIES OF FACILITY IMPROVEMENTS ON ITS CONFIDENTIAL THREE-ACRE RESIDENTIAL CAMPUS WHICH IS HOME TO A LARGE SAFEHOUSE THAT CAN ACCOMODATE18 FAMILIES AT A TIME WITH EMERGENCY SHELTER FOR UP TO SIX MONTHS, SIX TRANSITIONAL HOUSING COTTAGES WHERE FAMILIES CAN STAY FOR UP TO 24 MONTHS, AND A CHILDREN’S CENTER OFFERING AN ONSITE CHARTER SCHOOL, PLAY CARE AND COUNSELING FOR THE CHILDREN OF SURVIVORS. DUE TO THE NATURE OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE RELATIONSHIPS, A SECURE CAMPUS IS ESSENTIAL TO THE SAFETY OF THE FAMILIES STAYING AT WEAVE AND THE AGENCY EMPLOYEES AND VOLUNTEERS WHO STAFF THE FACILITY 24 HOURS PER DAY. FUNDING WILL BE USED TO ADDRESS IDENTIFIED VULNERABILITIES AND INCREASE THE SECURITY OF THE PROPERTY. IMPROVEMENTS TO INCREASE FACILITY SAFETY WILL INCLUDE INSTALLATION OF CRASH RATED BOLLARDS AT THE ENTRYWAY AND SIDEWALKS LEADING TO HOUSING UNITS; INSTALLATION OF A SALLY PORT (CAR TRAP) AT THE ENTRANCE; REPLACEMENT OF CHAIN-LINK PERIMETER FENCING AND GATES WITH 6 TO 8 FEET TALL, GALVANIZED WIRE MESH ANTI-CLIMB/ANTI-CUT FENCING; AND INSTALLATION OF POLYPROPYLENE SPIKES ON TOP OF THE FENCING. FUNDS WILL PAY FOR STAFF SALARIES FOR PROJECT MANAGEMENT AS WELL AS THE PURCHASE OF MATERIALS AND LABOR FOR INSTALLATION TO COMPLETE THE IMPROVEMENTS. THE WORK IS EXPECTED TO BE COMPLETED BETWEEN OCTOBER 1, 2022, AND SEPTEMBER 30, 2024.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ADDRESS: 1301 PUNCHBOWL STREET, HONOLULU, HAWAII 96813 PROJECT DIRECTORS: JACCE MIKULANEC AND JAMES GOMES CONTACT PHONE NUMBERS: 808-691-7994 AND 808-691-5905 EMAIL: JMIKULANEC@QUEENS.ORG AND JAMGOMES@QUEENS.ORG WEBSITE: HTTPS://WWW.QUEENS.ORG/  THE FUNDING REQUEST FOR THE QUEEN’S MEDICAL CENTER WILL BE USED TO PURCHASE A MODERNIZED AIR HANDLING SYSTEM FOR THE CATH LABS AND ELECTROPHYSIOLOGY LABS TO PROVIDE THE SAFEST ENVIRONMENT FOR PATIENTS AND CAREGIVERS, HELP FURTHER PREVENT THE SPREAD OF INFECTIOUS DISEASE, AND BETTER CONTROL ANY RISK OF AIRBORNE INFECTION.  CORONARY HEART DISEASE IS THE MOST COMMON TYPE OF CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE AND IS THE LEADING CAUSE OF DEATH IN THE U.S., HAWAII – AND ESPECIALLY AMONG NATIVE HAWAIIANS AND PACIFIC ISLANDERS.   AND FEW DISEASES HAVE IMPACTED THE FIELD OF CARDIOLOGY MORE THAN ATRIAL FIBRILLATION. IT IS BY FAR THE MOST COMMON HEART RHYTHM DISORDER IN ADULTS AND IS LARGELY RELATED TO AGING. AN INCREASING ELDERLY POPULATION IS EXPECTED TO IMPACT ATRIAL FIBRILLATION PREVALENCE FURTHER.   TO MEET THE DEMAND FOR ELECTROPHYSIOLOGY, THE QUEEN’S MEDICAL CENTER HAS SIGNIFICANTLY EXPANDED ITS TEAM AND IS PROVIDING CUTTING-EDGE DISEASE MANAGEMENT USING THE LATEST TECHNOLOGY TO ENSURE THE DELIVERY OF THE BEST CARE FOR PATIENTS WITH HEART RHYTHM DISORDERS. INITIATIVES THAT ARE BEING IMPLEMENTED INCLUDE: THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A LEAD MANAGEMENT PROGRAM THAT WILL INCLUDE LEAD EXTRACTION, THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A COMPREHENSIVE ATRIAL FIBRILLATION CLINIC, THE OPENING OF TWO STATE-OF-THE-ART EP LABS, AND THE EXPANSION OF ELECTROPHYSIOLOGY SERVICE IN OTHER AREAS OF THE STATE.   ONCE COMPLETED, THE QUEEN’S MEDICAL CENTER WILL HAVE STATE-OF-THE-ART CATH LABS AND ELECTROPHYSIOLOGY LABS TO SERVE ALL PEOPLE IN HAWAII. SERVICES PROVIDED IN THESE LABS INCLUDE: CORONARY, ELECTROPHYSIOLOGY, STRUCTURAL HEART, AND ENDOVASCULAR PROCEDURES. THE EXPECTATION IS TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF PATIENTS SERVED FROM APPROXIMATELY 3700 TO ABOUT 4300.   S TATE-OF-THE-ART INFECTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING THE AIR HANDLING SYSTEMS, WILL ALLOW BETTER CONTROL OVER THE POTENTIAL OF AIRBORNE INFECTION AND PROVIDE ESSENTIAL THERMAL COMFORT TO THE OCCUPANTS OF THE BUILDING. IT WILL ALSO MAINTAIN REGULATORY HOSPITAL STANDARDS FOR TEMPERATURE, HUMIDITY, FRESH AIR FILTRATION, AND AIR PRESSURE REQUIREMENTS FOR USES OF EACH ROOM AND SPACE – ESPECIALLY IN PROCEDURE AND OPERATING ROOMS.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - MOUNTAIN PARK HEALTH CENTER (MOUNTAIN PARK) WILL USE FUNDS FROM THE HRSA CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING CONSTRUCTION PROJECT FOR A NEW PRIMARY CARE CLINIC TO SERVE LOW-INCOME AND UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS IN THE HIGH NEEDS AREA OF GLENDALE, ARIZONA. THIS CITY IS PART OF THE EVER-GROWING PHOENIX METROPOLITAN AREA AND IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY NINE MILES NORTHWEST OF DOWNTOWN PHOENIX.  THE NEW CLINIC WILL BE THE TENTH PERMANENT LOCATION FOR MOUNTAIN PARK AND WILL PROVIDE INTEGRATED PRIMARY HEALTH CARE TO RESIDENTS OF ALL AGES.   THE NEW 27,500 SQUARE FOOT CLINIC WILL BE BUILT ON LAND PURCHASED BY MOUNTAIN PARK IN 2017. THE CLINIC WILL HAVE 36 EXAM ROOMS TO ACCOMMODATE MEDICAL (FAMILY MEDICINE, PEDIATRICS AND WOMEN’S HEALTH), BEHAVIORAL HEALTH, ORAL HEALTH, AND NUTRITION PROVIDERS. OTHER CLINICAL SPACES WILL INCLUDE AN ON-SITE LABORATORY FOR CLIA-WAIVED TESTING, PHLEBOTOMY, AND COVID-19 TESTING, TELEHEALTH SOUND-PROOF WORKSPACES, AND SEPARATE SICK AND WELL VISIT WAITING ROOMS. NON-CLINICAL SPACE WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR SUPPORT SERVICES SUCH AS WIC, ELIGIBILITY SCREENING AND ENROLLMENT, AND A MEDICAL LEGAL PARTNERSHIP. IN ADDITION, THERE WILL BE FOUR PROVIDER WORKROOMS, SIX CARE TEAM WORKSTATIONS, AND ONE LARGE COMMUNITY EDUCATION/CONFERENCE ROOM. EXTERIOR SPACES AVAILABLE WILL INCLUDE APPROXIMATELY 103,865 SQ. FT. OF SURFACE PARKING, AND AN OUTDOOR COMMUNITY SPACE DESIGNED TO INCLUDE A PLAYGROUND, FITNESS PATH AND/OR COMMUNITY GARDEN.   GROUNDBREAKING FOR THE CLINIC SITE OCCURRED ON MAY 3, 2022, AND CONSTRUCTION IS UNDERWAY. AT FULL CAPACITY, THE NEW CLINIC WILL BE THE MEDICAL HOME TO APPROXIMATELY 10,000 AREA RESIDENTS, WITH AN ESTIMATED 40,000 ENCOUNTERS ANNUALLY. THE NEW GLENDALE CLINIC IS EXPECTED TO BE COMPLETE AND READY TO WELCOME PATIENTS BY THE END OF 2023.   SINCE 1980, MOUNTAIN PARK HAS DELIVERED HIGH QUALITY, CULTURALLY COMPETENT HEALTH CARE TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN THE PHOENIX METROPOLITAN AREA. PREVENTION, WELLNESS, ACUTE CARE, AND CHRONIC CARE SERVICES ARE PROVIDED DIRECTLY AT ONE OR MORE OF NINE CLINIC LOCATIONS. THIS INCLUDES MEDICAL CARE FOR ADULTS; PEDIATRIC CARE FOR INFANTS, CHILDREN, AND ADOLESCENTS; OBSTETRICAL AND GYNECOLOGICAL CARE; AND INTEGRATED BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE AND NUTRITION SERVICES FOR ALL PATIENTS. MOUNTAIN PARK ALSO HAS FULL DENTAL CLINICS AT THREE SITES, WITH INTEGRATED PEDIATRIC DENTAL SCREENINGS AND CLEANINGS AT ALL SITES. TWO CLINICS HAVE FULL-SERVICE PHARMACIES, AND REDUCED PHARMACY PRICES ARE AVAILABLE TO ALL PATIENTS THROUGH HRSA’S 340B PROGRAM.  MOUNTAIN PARK IS THE PERMANENT MEDICAL HOME TO APPROXIMATELY 92,000 PATIENTS, WITH NEARLY 110,000 PEOPLE ACCESSING CARE IN 2021 WHEN INCLUDING COVID-19 TESTING AND VACCINES. MOUNTAIN PARK PROVIDES APPROXIMATELY 400,000 VISITS ANNUALLY. APPROXIMATELY 90% OF PATIENTS HAVE INCOMES BELOW 200% OF THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL, 64% ARE ENROLLED IN MEDICAID, AND 15% ARE UNINSURED. MOST PATIENTS (87%) REPRESENT MINORITY GROUPS, WITH 68% IDENTIFIED AS HISPANIC AND 17% AFRICAN AMERICAN. OVER 36% HAVE LIMITED ENGLISH SKILLS AND ARE BEST SERVED IN A LANGUAGE OTHER THAN ENGLISH. MORE THAN HALF (51%) OF PATIENTS SERVED ARE AGE18 OR YOUNGER.

OUR NICU IS ONE OF THE LARGEST IN CALIFORNIA. COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ADDRESS: 3555 WILLIAMSBURG COUNTY HWY, CADES, SC 29518  PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: GEORGIA KEITH  EMAIL ADDRESS: KEITHG@MUSC.EDU  WEBSITE ADDRESS: HTTPS://MUSCHEALTH.ORG/PATIENTS-VISITORS/ABOUT-US/GROWTH/NEW-LOCATIONS/BLACK-RIVER-MEDICAL-CENTER CONSTRUCTION & EQUIPMENT REQUEST  PROJECT ABSTRACT: MEDICAL UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL AUTHORITY (“MUHA”), AN AFFILIATE OF THE MEDICAL UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA, HAS ENTERED INTO AN AGREEMENT WITH LAKE CITY COMMUNITY HOSPITAL (“LCCH”) AND WILLIAMSBURG REGIONAL HOSPITAL (“WRH”) THAT AUTHORIZES MUHA TO CONSTRUCT, OWN, AND OPERATE A NEW HOSPITAL THAT WILL SERVE THE REGION OF NORTHERN WILLIAMSBURG AND LOWER FLORENCE COUNTIES. THE NEW HOSPITAL WILL ASSUME CARING FOR PATIENTS PRESENTLY SERVED BY WRH AND LCCH, BOTH OF WHICH WILL CEASE PROVIDING MEDICAL SERVICES UPON OPENING OF THE NEW HOSPITAL.  MUHA AND ITS CLINICAL AFFILIATES (KNOWN COLLECTIVELY AS “MUSC HEALTH”) WILL OFFER A BROAD SPECTRUM OF BOTH HOSPITAL AND AMBULATORY CARE TO THE REGION.  A REPLACEMENT HOSPITAL IS DESPERATELY NEEDED IN WILLIAMSBURG COUNTY DUE TO THE OCTOBER 2015 THOUSAND-YEAR FLOODS IN KINGSTREE, S.C., THE COUNTY SEAT OF WILLIAMSBURG AND LOCATION OF WILLIAMSBURG REGIONAL HOSPITAL. MORE THAN FIVE YEARS AGO, 31 INCHES OF RAINFALL CAUSED MASSIVE FLOODING THROUGHOUT THE AREA. TORRENTS OF WATER INSIDE THE HOSPITAL BUILDING, MULTIPLIED BY STANDING WATER AND BLACK MOLD, DAMAGED THE WILLIAMSBURG REGIONAL HOSPITAL BUILDING BEYOND REPAIR, RENDERING THE STRUCTURE UNSAFE AND UNUSABLE. DETERMINED NOT TO ABANDON THE CITIZENS OF WILLIAMSBURG COUNTY AND THE SURROUNDING AREA, THE LEADERSHIP AND PROVIDERS OF WILLIAMSBURG REGIONAL HOSPITAL HAVE BEEN OPERATING A TEMPORARY HOSPITAL TO SERVE PATIENTS SINCE APRIL 2016. MODULAR HOUSING UNITS SERVE AS EMERGENCY, EXAM AND OTHER PATIENT CARE ROOMS; HOWEVER, A LONG-TERM SOLUTION HAD TO BE FOUND.  LIKE MANY OTHER RURAL HEALTH CARE FACILITIES, LAKE CITY COMMUNITY HOSPITAL HAS ALSO EXPERIENCED FINANCIAL CHALLENGES. ITS LEAD ERS ARE WORKING DILIGENTLY TO BALANCE THE UNCERTAINTIES OF THE FUTURE WITH THE NEED TO EXPAND ACCESS TO HEALTH CARE FOR ITS CITIZENS. FOR SMALL COMMUNITY HOSPITALS, THE THREATS TO LONG-TERM VIABILITY ARE ALL TOO REAL DUE TO SIGNIFICANT DECLINES IN BOTH RURAL POPULATIONS AND HOSPITAL ADMISSIONS.  WITH THE OPENING OF THIS NEW FACILITY, MUSC HEALTH WILL BE ASSURING CONTINUED ACCESS TO HIGH QUALITY HEALTHCARE IN LOWER FLORENCE COUNTY AND WILLIAMSBURG COUNTY. IN WILLIAMSBURG COUNTY’S 2020 COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT, ACCESS TO HEALTHCARE, CHRONIC DISEASE, AND BEHAVIORAL / MENTAL HEALTH WERE LISTED AS THE REGION’S HEALTH PRIORITIES. THE NEW HOSPITAL WILL NOT ONLY ADDRESS THESE NEEDS BUT WILL ALSO OFFER THE COMMUNITIES A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO PRESERVE CONTINUITY OF CARE WITH LOCAL, TRUSTED PHYSICIANS WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY EXPANDING ACCESS TO A HIGH QUALITY, AFFORDABLE AND SUSTAINABLE HEALTH CARE DELIVERY SYSTEM.   MUHA BROKE GROUND IN EARLY JANUARY 2021 AND PLANS TO SEE PATIENTS IN THE NEW HOSPITAL IN 2023. THE HOSPITAL IS BEING BUILT ON A DONATED 40-ACRE TRACT OFF WILLIAMSBURG COUNTY HWY. ONCE COMPLETE, THE HOSPITAL WILL BE A 64,000SQ/FT, ONE-STORY BUILDING THAT IS FULLY FURNISHED AND EQUIPPED. THE NEW HOSPITAL WILL CONSIST OF 25 INPATIENT ROOMS, A FULL SERVICE PERIOP SUITE, AN EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT WITH 16 EXAM ROOMS, TRAUMA BAY, OBSERVATION ROOMS, AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH ROOMS. THE HOSPITAL ALSO INCLUDES A RADIOLOGY SUITE (CT, MRI, NUCLEAR MEDICINE, 3D MAMMOGRAPHY, ULTRASOUND), PHARMACY, LAB, PHYSICAL THERAPY GYM, CAFETERIA, AND SPACE FOR SUPPORT FUNCTIONS.
