COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ST. LOUIS CENTER 16195 W OLD US HWY 12, CHELSEA, MI 48118 PHONE 734-475-8430  FAX 734-475-0310 MAIL@STLOUISCENTER.ORG HTTPS://STLOUISCENTER.ORG FUNDING REQUEST $500,000.00 ST. LOUIS CENTER IS A NONPROFIT RESIDENTIAL FACILITY FOR 55 PEOPLE WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES. THE NUMBER OF RESIDENTS, AS WELL AS THEIR NEED FOR SPECIALIZED MEALS AND FOOD PREPARATION, HAVE GROWN FAR BEYOND THE CAPACITY OF THE FACILITY'S 61-YEAR-OLD KITCHEN AND A COMPLETE RENOVATION IS REQUIRED. BECAUSE THOSE WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES (I/DD) EXPERIENCE THE EFFECTS OF AGING FAR EARLIER THAN THE NEUROTYPICAL POPULATION, THE RESIDENTS AT THE CENTER REPRESENT A HIGHLY VULNERABLE POPULATION WITH MANY PHYSICAL CHALLENGES. AT THE PRESENT TIME, 85% OF THE CENTER’S RESIDENTS REQUIRE SOME FORM OF NUTRITION INTERVENTION IN ORDER TO SUPPORT THEIR HEALTH. THIS IS DUE TO METABOLIC DISORDERS, POOR FEEDING SKILLS, MEDICATIONS, AND A NEED FOR INCREASED PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. IN ADDITION, DIET MODIFICATIONS FOR CALORIES, SODIUM, AND PROTEIN ARE NECESSARY TO ADDRESS CHRONIC CONDITIONS SUCH AS ALLERGIES, MICRONUTRIENT DEFICIENCIES, DIABETES, HYPERTENSION, OBESITY, AND CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE. SOME RESIDENTS ALSO HAVE SWALLOWING ISSUES, REQUIRING THEIR FOOD TO BE PROCESSED IN VARIOUS WAYS. THERE IS AN URGENT NEED TO RENOVATE THE KITCHEN TO PROVIDE ADEQUATE PREPARATION SPACE, AS WELL AS EQUIPMENT TO EFFICIENTLY PREPARE THE QUANTITY OF SPECIALIZED MEALS REQUIRED BY THE RESIDENTS. THIS RENOVATION WILL SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE THE CAPACITY OF THE KITCHEN STAFF TO ADDRESS THEIR HEALTH AND NUTRITION NEEDS. IT WILL BRING THE KITCHEN INTO COMPLIANCE WITH CURRENT REGULATORY CODES, BEYOND THE OLDER CODE REQUIREMENTS UNDER WHICH IT IS CURRENTLY GRANDFATHERED. A NEW KITCHEN WILL PROVIDE ADEQUATE SPACE FOR FOOD PREPARATION AND THE ABILITY TO MEET CURRENT HEALTH DEPARTMENT CODES. THE PROJECT INCLUDES DEMOLITION, EXCAVATION FOR THE INSTALLATION OF GREASE MANAGEMENT SYST EMS, THE ADDITION OF VENTILATION AND ELECTRICAL SYSTEM UPGRADES. NEW EQUIPMENT TO FACILITATE SPECIALIZED MEAL PREPARATION WILL ALSO BE INSTALLED. FOOD MAY NEED TO BE PROVIDED BY AN OUTSIDE SUPPLIER DURING CONSTRUCTION. THE PROJECT DURATION INCLUDING ALL PHASES IS EXPECTED TO LAST 18-36 MONTHS.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ST. JOSEPH’S UNIVERSITY MEDICAL CENTER, INC. (SJUMC) IS THE FLAGSHIP MEDICAL CENTER OF ST. JOSEPH’S HEALTH, A NEW JERSEY-BASED HEALTHCARE SYSTEM. SJUMC IS THE NEW JERSEY DIVISION OF MENTAL HEALTH AND ADDICTION SERVICES-DESIGNATED SCREENING CENTER FOR PASSAIC COUNTY, NJ FOR PSYCHIATRIC EMERGENCIES, CRISIS INTERVENTION SERVICES, INFORMATION AND REFERRAL. THE $1,000,000 FUNDING ALLOCATED THROUGH HRSA’S CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING (CDS):  CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS FOR OUR EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT (ED) PSYCHIATRIC SCREENING CENTER WILL BE USED TO COMPLETELY RENOVATE APPROXIMATELY 3,000 SQUARE FEET OF EXISTING PHYSICAL STRUCTURE.  IT WILL ALLOW ST. JOSEPH’S HEALTH TO RELOCATE AND EXPAND THE TREATMENT/HOLDING SPACE FOR PSYCHIATRIC PATIENTS IN THE ST. JOSEPH’S UNIVERSITY MEDICAL CENTER ED IN ORDER TO ENHANCE ACCESS TO SERVICES AND PROVIDE BETTER HEALTH OUTCOMES.  THE NEW ED PSYCHIATRIC SCREENING CENTER WILL BE RELOCATED TO A LARGER SPACE AND ACCOMMODATE ADDITIONAL PSYCHIATRIC ED BEDS THAT WILL ALLOW FOR BETTER CARE, ASSESSMENT AND TREATMENT PRIOR TO PATIENTS ACCESSING THE NEXT LEVEL OF SERVICE THEY NEED. THE LARGER SPACE WILL ALSO ALLOW FOR THE CREATION OF A CENTRALIZED NURSES’ STATION AND A SINGLE SUITE CALL CENTER, RESULTING IN THE CO-LOCATION OF STAFF IN THE ED.  IN ADDITION, THE SPACE THAT WAS PREVIOUSLY OCCUPIED BY THE PSYCHIATRIC SCREENING CENTER WILL BE FULLY RENOVATED FOR OCCUPANCY TO SUPPORT THE TREATMENT OF OUR GERIATRIC PATIENT POPULATION ADMITTED INTO THE ED.  THE RENOVATION AND REDESIGN OF THIS SPACE WILL ALLOW FOR A SAFER AND MORE COMFORTABLE PATIENT ENVIRONMENT AND INCREASED STAFF COLLABORATION, RESULTING IN BETTER CARE AND TREATMENT OF OUR PATIENTS.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - FOR NEARLY A CENTURY, THE ST. JOHN’S UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF PHARMACY AND HEALTH SCIENCES HAS BEEN THE LARGEST EDUCATOR OF HEALTH CARE PERSONNEL IN THE NEW YORK METROPOLITAN AREA. ESTABLISHING A BACHELOR OF SCIENCE IN NURSING PROGRAM, AND CONSTRUCTING A STATE-OF-THE-ART MEDICAL AND EDUCATIONAL FACILITY ON OUR MAIN CAMPUS IN THE NEW YORK CITY BOROUGH OF QUEENS, WILL ALLOW US TO EDUCATE THE NEXT GENERATION OF HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS IN A MODEL THAT EMBRACES THE UNIVERSITY’S MISSION OF PROVIDING A QUALITY EDUCATION IN AN ENVIRONMENT THAT IS CATHOLIC, VINCENTIAN, AND METROPOLITAN.  ACCORDING TO THE U.S. BUREAU OF LABOR STATISTICS, EMPLOYMENT OF REGISTERED NURSES IS PROJECTED TO GROW 9 PERCENT FROM 2020 TO 20301, OUTPACING THE AVERAGE OF NEARLY ALL OTHER OCCUPATIONS. GROWTH WILL OCCUR FOR A NUMBER OF REASONS, INCLUDING AN INCREASED EMPHASIS ON PREVENTIVE CARE; GROWING RATES OF CHRONIC CONDITIONS SUCH AS DIABETES AND OBESITY; AND DEMAND FOR HEALTHCARE SERVICES FROM THE BABY-BOOM POPULATION AS THEY LIVE LONGER AND MORE ACTIVE LIVES. NEW YORK STATE HAS THE THIRD HIGHEST EMPLOYMENT LEVEL FOR REGISTERED NURSES IN THE UNITED STATES, RANKING BEHIND ONLY CALIFORNIA AND TEXAS2. THE NEW YORK CITY METROPOLITAN AREA – THE UNIVERSITY’S HOME SINCE 1929 – EMPLOYS THE MOST REGISTERED NURSES IN THE ENTIRE COUNTRY3. ADDING A BACHELOR OF SCIENCE IN NURSING TO THE UNIVERSITY’S EXISTING SUITE OF COMPREHENSIVE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOR THE HEALTH CARE INDUSTRY IS A NATURAL PROGRESSION.  GRADUATES OF OUR PROPOSED BACHELOR OF SCIENCE IN NURSING PROGRAM WILL BE ABLE TO ENTER METROPOLITAN, UNDERSERVED, AND UNDERDEVELOPED COMMUNITIES LOCALLY AND INTERNATIONALLY WITH THE KNOWLEDGE OF NURSING AND COMPETENCIES IN LIBERAL ARTS AND SCIENCES. THE PROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO DEVELOP STUDENTS INTO VERSATILE GRADUATES WHO CAN CONTRIBUTE TO A COMPLEX MODERN SOCIETY UNDERSCORED WITH THE VINCENTIAN VALUES LEARNED DURING THEIR COURSE OF STUDY AT THE UNIVERSITY. THIS NEW PROGRAM WILL PREPARE STUDENTS  TO SEAMLESSLY TRANSITION INTO THE HEALTHCARE INDUSTRY AS REGISTERED NURSES – KEY MEMBERS OF THE CLINICAL TEAM. THE PROPOSED SCOPE OF WORK INCLUDES CLASSROOMS, LABORATORIES, OFFICE SPACE, STUDENT SERVICES, COLLABORATIVE SPACES AND LARGE AUDITORIUM ON FLOORS 1 THROUGH 4 (A TOTAL OF 90,000 SQ. FT.). THE PROPOSED NEW HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER IS ESTIMATED TO COST $106 MILLION. THIS COST EXCLUDES ALL PERSONNEL EXPENSES, CLINICAL SUPPLIES, LABORATORY SUPPLIES, AND INSTRUCTIONAL SUPPLIES. THE WORK HAS BEGUN STARTING FOURTH QUARTER OF 2021 AND IS EXPECTED TO BE COMPLETED BY THE SECOND QUARTER 2024. WE PROJECT THE BUILDING TO BE READY FOR OCCUPANCY AND AVAILABLE FOR STUDENTS AND CLASSES BY FALL 2024. THE HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER WILL PROMOTE INTERPROFESSIONAL EDUCATION AMONGST ALL THE HEALTH SCIENCE PROGRAMS AND REQUIRE ALL STUDENTS TO LEARN TOGETHER AND WORK AS A TEAM, SIMILAR TO THE REAL-WORLD SITUATION AT ANY CLINICAL SETTING. ADDITIONALLY, THE HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER WILL HOUSE STATE-OF-THE-ART SIMULATION FACILITIES WHERE STUDENTS CAN LEARN AND BENEFIT FROM SIMULATION LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES PRIOR TO THEIR REQUIRED EXPERIENTIAL EDUCATION (COMPLETING THEIR CLINICAL ROTATION REQUIREMENTS AT A CLINICAL SETTING).

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - FUNDING WILL BE USED TO RENOVATE SPURWINK’S INTERMEDIATE CARE FACILITY (ICF) FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY IN LEWISTON, ONE OF ONLY FIFTEEN FACILITIES IN THE STATE OF MAINE THAT PROVIDE A CRUCIAL SERVICE AS A HEALTH CARE FACILITY FOR PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE FOURTH PHASE OF THE RURAL HEALTH & WELLNESS SCIENCE COMPLEX, THE OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY BUILDING PROJECT, INVOLVES THE RENOVATION OF UNIVERSITY’S FORMER BOILER HOUSE AND ST. JOSEPH'S HALL/ ART GARAGE AS THE NEW HOME FOR THE OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY DEPARTMENT. THE NEW FACILITY WILL PROVIDE DEDICATED CLASSROOMS AND LABORATORIES FOR PEDIATRICS, HAND THERAPY, INDUSTRIAL MEDICINE, AND AN ACUTE CARE SUITE THAT WOULD SIMULATE HOSPITAL-BASED CARE. THESE LEARNING SPACES PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH THE OPPORTUNITY TO REFINE THEIR CLINICAL PRACTICE, CRITICAL REASONING AND SAFETY SKILLS, AND MAKE MISTAKES IN A SAFE ENVIRONMENT. THE NEW ACTIVITIES OF DAILY LIVING LAB WILL PROVIDE ADDITIONAL SPACE FOR FLEXIBLE LEARNING THAT WILL BOAST CONTEMPORARY, STATE OF THE ART EQUIPMENT WHILE ALSO ALLOWING THE STUDENTS TO LEARN THE HANDS-ON CARE SO CRITICAL TO QUALITY AND COMPASSIONATE PATIENT CARE IN REHABILITATION. THE CONSTRUCTION OF A SECOND CLASSROOM WILL ADDRESS STUDENT OVERFLOW FROM BOTH THE PHYSICIAN ASSISTANT AND OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY PROGRAMS.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE CITY OF ROCHESTER’S DEPARTMENT OF RECREATION AND HUMAN SERVICES CRISIS INTERVENTION UNIT RESPECTFULLY REQUESTS $225,000 TO PURCHASE AN EMERGENCY RESPONSE OUTREACH VEHICLE.  THE CRISIS INTERVENTION SERVICES UNIT IS LOCATED AT 57 ST. PAUL STREET, ROCHESTER, NY 14604 AND PROVIDES SERVICES TO RESIDENTS THROUGHOUT THE CITY OF ROCHESTER.  SPECIFICALLY, THE GOAL OF THE UNIT IS TO CREATE A COMPREHENSIVE, COMMUNITY-BASED RESPONSE TO SUPPORT VICTIMS OF VIOLENCE AND FAMILIES DEALING WITH HOMICIDES, MENTAL HEALTH, DOMESTIC VIOLENCE, AND OTHER RELATED CRISES BY MEANS OF TRAINED MENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONALS AS FIRST RESPONDERS AND CO-RESPONDERS WITH LAW ENFORCEMENT AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES.  FOR MORE INFORMATION ABOUT THE UNIT, PLEASE VISIT CITYOFROCHESTER.GOV/CRISISINTERVENTION.  THE REQUESTED GRANT WILL FUND THE ONE-TIME PURCHASE OF AN EMERGENCY RESPONSE OUTREACH VEHICLE, A BUS FOR USE BY THE UNIT WHEN RESPONDING TO EMERGENCIES AND PROVIDING DIRECT SERVICES TO VICTIMS OF CRIMES, PEOPLE IN CRISIS, AND THEIR FAMILIES.  OFTEN TIMES, FAMILIES OF HOMICIDE VICTIMS, VICTIMS OF VIOLENCE, AND PEOPLE IN CRISIS NEED A SAFE PLACE, AWAY FROM THE ELEMENTS, MEDIA, AND/OR OTHERS, TO MOURN AND PROCESS THEIR GRIEF.  THIS MOBILE UNIT WILL ALLOW FOR THIS SPACE, ESPECIALLY WITH IT BEING MOBILE, IT CAN BE AT SCENES THROUGHOUT THE CITY OF ROCHESTER TO MEET RESIDENTS WHERE THEY ARE LOCATED.  FOR MORE INFORMATION ABOUT THE PARTICULAR PROJECT, PLEASE REACH OUT TO THE PROJECT DIRECTOR SARAH FLETCHER, DEPUTY COMMISSIONER OF THE DEPARTMENT OF RECREATION AND HUMAN SERVICES, AT 585-428-6338 (OFFICE), 585-428-6021 (FAX), OR SARAH.FLETCHER@CITYOFROCHESTER.GOV.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - OVER THE PAST FEW YEARS, FEARS RELATED TO IMMIGRATION STATUS (ICE RAIDS, PUBLIC CHARGE), THE DISMANTLING OF THE AFFORDABLE CARE ACT (ACA) AND COVID-19 HAS CAUSED COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO STOP SEEKING ESSENTIAL PREVENTIVE AND CHRONIC DISEASE SERVICES (MEDICAL, DENTAL AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH). DISENROLLMENT FROM HEALTH PLANS AND SAFETY NET PROGRAMS HAS INCREASED THROUGHOUT CA-35 (INLAND EMPIRE AND POMONA VALLEY) AND ACCESS TO CARE HAS SIGNIFICANTLY DECREASED. GAINS IN OUTCOMES AND HEALTH EQUITY MADE BECAUSE OF THE ACA HAVE FALLEN. TO RETURN TO A POST-PANDEMIC HEALTHCARE ENVIRONMENT, PARKTREE WILL UTILIZE A MOBILE VAN PROGRAM TO RE-ENGAGE PEOPLE IN NEED OF HEALTHCARE SERVICES, ASSIST WITH ENROLLMENT IN PAYOR PROGRAMS AND PROVIDE NECESSARY MEDICAL, DENTAL AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTHCARE TO ADULTS AND CHILDREN. PARKTREE WILL “DRIVE” THROUGHOUT THE COMMUNITY, WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH SCHOOLS, COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS, HOMELESS SHELTERS, RELIGIOUS AND SPIRITUAL GROUPS AND CIVIC LEADERS TO REEDUCATE THE COMMUNITY ON HEALTHCARE ACCESS, UTILIZATION AND TO PROVIDE DIRECT CARE SERVICES.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - OSU CENTER FOR HEALTH SCIENCES (OSU-CHS) IS A LEADER IN TRAINING AMERICAN INDIAN PHYSICIANS AND IN INDIGENOUS HEALTH RESEARCH. EACH YEAR, 14-16% OF ITS GRADUATING MEDICAL SCHOOL CLASS HAS BEEN COMPRISED OF AMERICAN INDIAN GRADUATES. OSU-CHS ALSO COLLABORATES WITH TRIBAL NATIONS ON MEDICAL EDUCATION, RESIDENCY TRAINING AND HEALTH EQUITY RESEARCH. OSU MEDICAL STUDENTS ROTATE THROUGH TRIBAL HEALTHCARE FACILITIES. OSU-CHS ALSO HAS RESIDENCY TRAINING PROGRAMS WITH THE CHEROKEE, CHICKASAW AND CHOCTAW NATIONS. MOST RECENTLY, OSU-CHS OPENED THE NATION'S FIRST TRIBALLY AFFILIATED MEDICAL SCHOOL, THE OSU COLLEGE OF OSTEOPATHIC MEDICINE AT THE CHEROKEE NATION, WELCOMING 54 FIRST-YEAR MEDICAL STUDENTS, 20% OF WHOM ARE AMERICAN INDIAN. OSU-CHS IS ALSO HOME TO THE CENTER FOR INDIGENOUS HEALTH RESEARCH AND POLICY WHICH PROMOTES RESEARCH FOCUSED ON ELIMINATING HEALTH DISPARITIES IN INDIGENOUS POPULATIONS. OSU-CHS SEEKS $2 MILLION TO ESTABLISH THE CENTER FOR INDIGENOUS HEALTH EQUITY, BIOINFORMATICS AND INNOVATION. THIS NEW CENTER WILL BE LOCATED AT OSU-CHS' NEW MEDICAL SCHOOL IN TAHLEQUAH, OKLAHOMA AND WILL FOCUS ON UNDERSTANDING STRUCTURAL INEQUITIES THAT IMPEDE NATIVE POPULATIONS FROM LIVING HEALTHIER LIVES, ACCESSING HEALTHCARE AND PURSUING MEDICINE AS A CAREER. GOALS 1. ESTABLISH CENTER FOR INDIGENOUS HEALTH EQUITY, BIOINFORMATICS AND INNOVATION 2. HIRE FACULTY SPECIALIZING IN BIOSTATISTICS, EPIDEMIOLOGY, POPULATION HEALTH, PUBLIC HEALTH AND MEDICAL EDUCATION 3. DEVELOP THE COMPUTATIONAL INFRASTRUCTURE TO CONDUCT LARGE-SCALE DATA ANALYTICS TO PREDICT HEALTH TRENDS AND PREVENT DISEASE 4. PRODUCE ACTIONABLE POLICY RECOMMENDATIONS TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF NATIVE POPULATIONS AND STRENGTHEN THE AMERICAN INDIAN PHYSICIAN PIPELINE IMPACT BETTER HEALTH OUTCOMES FOR NATIVE POPULATIONS. BY UNDERSTANDING THE STRUCTURAL INEQUITIES THAT CONTRIBUTE TO NATIVE POPULATIONS HAVING POORER HEALTH OUTCOMES THAN THE GENERAL POPULATION IN THE U.S., OSU-CHS WILL BE ABLE T O MAKE POLICY RECOMMENDATIONS WILL HELP REMOVE THESE INEQUITIES AND HELP NATIVE POPULATION LIVE HEALTHIER AND LONGER LIVES. AUGMENT THE AMERICAN INDIAN PHYSICIAN WORKFORCE PIPELINE. INCREASING THE NUMBER OF AMERICAN INDIAN PHYSICIANS WILL PRODUCE PHYSICIANS WHO HAVE THE CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL CONTEXT TO TREAT AND GAIN THE TRUST OF NATIVE POPULATIONS, LEADING TO BETTER PATIENT HEALTH OUTCOMES. FUNDING REQUEST OSU-CHS SEEKS $2 MILLION TO ESTABLISH THE CENTER FOR INDIGENOUS HEALTH EQUITY, BIOINFORMATICS AND INNOVATION. BILL: LABOR/HHS/ED; AGENCY: HHS

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE NEUGARTEN FAMILY BIRTH CENTER AT NORTHERN DUTCHESS HOSPITAL WAS FOUNDED IN 1985 TO PROVIDE WOMEN WITH A FAMILY-CENTERED CHILDBIRTH ENVIRONMENT THAT COMBINES NATURAL CHILDBIRTH OPTIONS WITH ACCESS TO EMERGENCY MEDICAL CARE.  WHEN THE NEXT NEAREST HOSPITAL CLOSED ITS MATERNITY UNIT IN 2019, THE NEUGARTEN BIRTH CENTER BECAME THE ONLY BIRTHING OPTION EAST OF THE RIVER BETWEEN THE CITIES OF POUGHKEEPSIE AND ALBANY.  INCREASED DEMAND AT THE BIRTH CENTER HAS MAGNIFIED THE NEED FOR THE BIRTH CENTER TO REPLACE AND UPDATE EQUIPMENT TO ENSURE SAFE AND HEALTHY OUTCOMES FOR MOTHERS AND BABIES.  IN THE FY 2022 CONSOLIDATED APPROPRIATIONS ACT (P.L. 117-103), CONGRESS AWARDED $300,000 FROM THE HRSA HEALTH FACILITIES CONSTRUCTION AND EQUIPMENT ACCOUNT TO REPLACE OUTDATED PATIENT SAFETY AND MONITORING EQUIPMENT IN ITS NEUGARTEN BIRTH CENTER.  THIS FUNDING WILL ALLOW THE HOSPITAL TO:  -	REPLACE EQUIPMENT RELATED TO PATIENT SAFETY: LABOR BEDS, POSTPARTUM BEDS, ROCKING CHAIRS, CARDIAC MONITORS, INFANT SECURITY SYSTEM, RECLINER BEDS. -	REPLACE OUTDATED WORKFLOW EQUIPMENT AND ENSURE SUFFICIENT EQUIPMENT FOR ALL LABOR ROOMS: COMPUTER UNITS, LABOR CARTS, FETAL MONITORS -	UPDATE PATIENT EXPERIENCE ITEMS THAT ARE WORN, RIPPED, OR OUTDATED:  FURNITURE AND PERMANENT FIXTURES USED BY PATIENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES.  NORTHERN DUTCHESS HOSPITAL OF NUVANCE HEALTH IS GRATEFUL AND PLEASED THAT SENATOR SCHUMER, SENATOR GILLIBRAND, AND REPRESENTATIVE DELGADO SUPPORTED OUR FUNDING REQUEST FOR THIS PROJECT.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - NORTH SHORE COMMUNITY HEALTH’S (NSCH) HAS BEEN THE PRIMARY SOURCE OF HEALTHCARE FOR A DIVERSE POPULATION OF LOW-INCOME, MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED, UNINSURED, AND UNDER-INSURED SERVICE AREA RESIDENTS.  MORE THAN 90% OF PATIENTS LIVE AT OR BELOW 200% OF THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL.  OVER 42% OF PATIENTS IDENTIFIED AS BELONGING TO A RACIAL AND/OR ETHNIC MINORITY, 33.4% OF THOSE BEING HISPANIC/LATINO. NSCH HAS 10 SERVICE SITES LOCATED IN THREE COMMUNITIES: SALEM, PEABODY AND GLOUCESTER OF WHICH 6 SITES ARE SCHOOL-BASED AND ARE THE TEEN HEALTH CENTER AT SALEM HIGH SCHOOL, THE STUDENT HEALTH CENTER AT PEABODY VETERANS MEMORIAL HIGH SCHOOL, AND FIVE BEHAVIORAL HEALTH-ONLY SITES AT ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS.  NSCH HAS PURCHASES A NEW LOCATION TO MOVE AND EXPAND THE SALEM FAMILY HEALTH CENTER (SFHC) FACILITY WHERE IT WILL CONTINUE TO OFFER PRIMARILY LOW-INCOME POPULATIONS MEDICAL, DENTAL, MENTAL, AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES, PUBLIC HEALTH ADVOCACY, PHARMACY AND FOR THE FIRST TIME, URGENT CARE, IN A LARGER, STATE OF THE ART FACILITY. THIS WILL REPLACE THE CURRENT LEASED FACILITIES WHICH ARE INEFFICIENT, DATED, DILAPIDATED, AND WHICH THE SFHC OUTGREW MANY YEARS AGO. GIVEN THE ONGOING LACK OF SAME DAY APPOINTMENT ACCESS, HEALTH CENTER STAFF KNOW THE NEED IS GREAT FOR MORE PRIMARY CARE ACCESS, INCLUDING DENTAL AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH, EXPANDING THE PHARMACY AND STAFF MEETING SPACE, AND THE ADDITION OF NEW URGENT CARE SERVICES.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - FOUNDED IN 1971, TRUCKEE MEADOWS COMMUNITY COLLEGE (TMCC) IS A PART OF THE NEVADA SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION, SERVING RESIDENTS OF WASHOE COUNTY, AND THE CITIES OF RENO AND SPARKS, NEVADA.  IN THE SPRING OF 2022, TMCC PROVIDED 9,785 STUDENTS WITH A VARIETY OF CERTIFICATE AND DEGREE PROGRAMS (ASSOCIATE AND BACHELOR) ADDRESSING THE ACADEMIC AND WORKFORCE NEEDS OF NORTHERN NEVADA.  THE MAXINE S. JACOBS NURSING PROGRAM IS IN ITS 42ND YEAR OF OPERATION, AND IN THE SUMMER OF 2021 BEGAN OFFERING AN RN-BACHELOR OF SCIENCE DEGREE PROGRAM IN ADDITION TO ITS ADN PROGRAM.  REGIONAL DEMAND FOR MORE NURSES HAS INCREASED THE NEED TO TRAIN AND GRADUATE MORE STUDENTS TO ENTER THE NURSING FIELD.   TMCC IS PROPOSING AN EXPANSION/RENOVATION OF THE TMCC WILLIAM N. PENNINGTON HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER, TO ACCOMMODATE THE NEED FOR MORE SPACE TO ENHANCE LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES AND INCREASE THE NUMBER OF NURSING STUDENTS THAT CAN BE SERVED EACH SEMESTER (FROM 80 TO 112 EACH YEAR). THE EXPANSION/RENOVATION INCLUDES THE CONSTRUCTION OF THREE NEW CLASSROOMS; CONSTRUCTION OF 12 OFFICES FOR NURSING AND ALLIED HEALTH FACULTY AND STAFF; CONSTRUCTION OF AN OUTDOOR INSTRUCTIONAL AND MEETING SPACE; CONSTRUCTION OF AN EXPANDED NURSING LAB; AND, MODIFICATION OF EXISTING SPACE TO INCLUDE A SMALL WAITING AREA, SMALL COMMON AREA, AND CORRIDOR.  THE TOTAL PROJECT COST IS $6,000,000.  HRSA CDS FUNDING IS REQUESTED TO COVER $2,000,000 IN CONSTRUCTION COSTS, ASSOCIATED WITH THE PROJECT.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - CO-DEVELOPERS WELLINGTON DEVELOPMENT AND NATIVE AMERICAN COMMUNITY CLINIC (NACC) BUILDING A NEW STATE-OF-THE-ART, CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE CLINIC PLUS AFFORDABLE HOUSING. THIS PROJECT WILL CREATE A CULTURALLY BASED, BEAUTIFUL AND INSPIRING PHYSICAL STRUCTURE THAT WILL REFLECT POSITIVELY ON THE COMMUNITY AND REVITALIZE THE SITE. THIS MIXED-USE PROJECT WILL FEATURE TRANSIT-ORIENTED DESIGN PRINCIPALS, INCREASE DENSITY AT THE SITE, AND CREATE OPPORTUNITIES AND PROVIDE SERVICES FOR OUR NATIVE AMERICAN RELATIVES, COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND NEIGHBORHOOD RESIDENTS. NACC IS A FEDERALLY QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTER (FQHC) AND 501(C)(3) CLINIC OPENED IN 2003 TO ADDRESS THE HEALTH DISPARITIES EXPERIENCED BY TWIN CITIES NATIVE AMERICANS. THEY CURRENTLY SERVE OVER 5,000 PATIENTS ANNUALLY. NACC OFFERS A FULL RANGE OF CULTURALLY CENTERED HEALTHCARE SERVICES INCLUDING MEDICAL, BEHAVIORAL HEALTH, DENTAL, AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE PROGRAMS, REGARDLESS OF ABILITY TO PAY.   THIS PROJECT INCLUDES AN EXPANDED CLINIC COMBINED WITH AFFORDABLE HOUSING. NACC’S EXISTING 20,000 SQUARE FEET OF SPACE IS SPREAD BETWEEN FOUR LOCATIONS. THE NEW 25,000 SQUARE FOOT CLINIC WILL INTEGRATE NACC’S PHYSICAL, MENTAL, AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES AND ADMINISTRATIVE SPACE UNDER ONE ROOF IN RESPONSE TO THE INCREASED DEMAND FOR SERVICES. THE SITE IS SITUATED AT THE FURTHEST WESTERN BLOCK OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN CULTURAL CORRIDOR, ON FRANKLIN AVENUE IN SOUTH MINNEAPOLIS. AN ESTIMATED 26,000 NATIVE AMERICANS LIVE IN THE METRO AREA; OF THOSE, APPROXIMATELY 20,655 ARE LOCATED IN THE CLINIC’S SERVICE AREA. THE FIRST FLOOR OF THE NEW DEVELOPMENT WILL BE DEDICATED TO NACC'S CLINIC WITH EIGHTEEN MEDICAL EXAM ROOMS, EIGHT DENTAL EXAM ROOMS, OFFICE/PATIENT AREAS, AND DEDICATED SPACE FOR MENTAL AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH. THIS EXPANDED CLINIC WILL ALLOW NACC TO SERVE AN ADDITIONAL 2,000 PATIENTS EACH YEAR. AFFORDABLE HOUSING IS A CRITICAL COMPONENT OF OUR VISION. CHRONIC HOMELESSNESS PLAGUES THE NATIVE AMERICAN COMMUN ITY, WHICH DIRECTLY LEADS TO POOR HEALTH OUTCOMES AND IMPACTS NACC’S ABILITY TO OFFER EFFECTIVE CARE. POSITIONED ABOVE THE CLINIC, FLOORS TWO THROUGH SIX WILL HOST 98 AFFORDABLE EFFICIENCY, ONE-, TWO-, THREE- AND FOUR-BEDROOM RENTAL UNITS AFFORDABLE TO INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES AT OR BELOW 30%, 50%, AND 60% OF THE AREA MEDIAN INCOME. FIVE EFFICIENCIES WILL BE SET ASIDE AS SUPPORTIVE HOUSING FOR INDIVIDUALS EXPERIENCING HOMELESSNESS. ELEVEN UNITS (FIVE TWO-BEDROOM AND SIX THREE-BEDROOM) WILL BE SET ASIDE FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES; WE HAVE REQUESTED MN HOUSING SECTION 811 RENTAL ASSISTANCE FOR THESE UNITS. AN ADDITIONAL 14 UNITS (NINE THREE-BEDROOM AND FIVE FOUR-BEDROOM) ARE FOR HOUSEHOLDS EARNING 30% OR LESS OF THE AREA MEDIAN INCOME; WE WILL SECURE PROJECT-BASED SECTION 8 RENTAL ASSISTANCE FOR THESE UNITS.   IN ADDITION TO SERVING AN ADDITIONAL PATIENTS EACH YEAR AND ADDRESSING THE CHRONIC HOMELESSNESS THAT IS LINKED TO NEGATIVE HEALTH OUTCOMES WITHIN THE NATIVE COMMUNITY, THIS PROJECT WILL: -            EXPAND CHEMICAL HEALTH AND INFECTIOUS DISEASE SERVICES; -            CREATE AN INTEGRATED PEDIATRIC CARE CLINIC AND BROADEN SCHOOL-BASED PROGRAMS; -            OFFER HOUSING SUPPORT SERVICES FOR UNSHELTERED; -            IMPLEMENT TELEHEALTH TO SUPPORT PATIENTS BOTH LOCALLY AND ON RESERVATIONS; -            EXPAND LABORATORY AND DIAGNOSTIC SERVICES;

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - 801 MIDDLEFORD ROAD, SEAFORD, DE 19973  DR. KATHRYN FIDDLER  410-912-4923  KATHRYN.FIDDLER@TIDALHEALTH.ORG  GRANT PROGRAM FUNDS REQUESTED: $341,000   THE WELLNESS MOBILE HEALTH CLINIC OF TIDALHEALTH WILL SUPPORT THE PURCHASE OF EQUIPMENT AND SUPPORTIVE TECHNOLOGIES AND MATERIALS TO FULLY OUTFIT A MOBILE HEALTH VAN, THAT TIDALHEALTH NANTICOKE ALREADY OWNS, AND PURCHASE A SECOND UPGRADED VAN TO PROVIDE HEALTH SCREENINGS, MULTIDISCIPLINARY HEALTH SERVICES, TELEMEDICINE, SOCIAL DETERMINANT OF HEALTH SCREENING AND ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH IN COMMUNITY-BASED SETTINGS. THE CLINIC VAN AND ITS MULTIDISCIPLINARY TEAM WILL CONNECT MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES WITH OUTREACH, SCREENINGS, CONNECTIONS TO PRIMARY CARE, AS WELL AS PREVENTATIVE HEALTH AND WELLNESS RESOURCES.     TIDALHEALTH NANTICOKE IS A HOSPITAL LOCATED IN SEAFORD, DELAWARE. THE MOBILE HEALTH VAN THAT IS OUTFITTED THROUGH THIS FUNDING WILL SERVE THE COMMUNITIES LOCATED IN THE PRIMARY SERVICE AREA AND WILL SUPPORT BOTH WELLNESS CHECKS AND HEALTH CARE SERVICES IN WITHIN WESTERN SUSSEX COUNTY FOCUSED ON GEORGETOWN, MILLSBORO, SELBYVILLE, LAUREL, SEAFORD, DELMAR, BLADES, BETHEL AND BRIDGEVILLE. THE VAN WILL ADDITIONALLY SERVE THREE SCHOOL-BASED WELLNESS CENTERS IN LAUREL, SEAFORD AND DELMAR IN COLLABORATION WITH THE SCHOOL SYSTEMS, AND WORK WITH LOCAL EMPLOYERS TO PROVIDE LARGE SCALE SCREENINGS FOR EMPLOYEES ONSITE.  THE VAN WILL BE STAFFED BY A COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKER AND REGISTERED NURSE AND/OR NURSE PRACTITIONER AND WORK TO LINK INDIVIDUALS TO A COORDINATED COMMUNITY WELLNESS TEAM THAT INCLUDES ADDITIONAL COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS, SOCIAL WORKER, AND HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS INCLUDING PRIMARY CARE AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS.     THE INTEGRATED HEALTH CARE SYSTEM IS A REGIONAL CHAMPION OF POPULATION HEALTH AND THE ROLE THAT POPULATION HEALTH PLAYS IN REDUCING HEALTHCARE DISPARITIES AND INEQUITY. THE MOBILE HEALTH UNIT WILL IMPROVE HEALTHCARE ACCESS THROUGH DEPLOYMENT OF RESOURCES FOR RURAL, UNDERSERVED NEIGHBORHOODS AND COMMUNITIES.  THIS WILL BE DONE BY OPTIMIZING DATA ANALYTICS TO PINPOINT HIGH RISK COMMUNITIES, WITH SPECIAL ATTENTION AND FOCUS ON ZIP CODES/NEIGHBORHOODS WITH HIGH RATES OF HEALTH DISPARITIES AND POOR HEALTH OUTCOMES.  THE PROJECT, IN CONJUNCTION WITH ALIGNED INITIATIVES, WILL CONTRIBUTE TO ACHIEVING A REDUCTION IN ED VISITS, HOSPITAL ADMISSIONS AND READMISSIONS AND POTENTIALLY AVOIDABLE UTILIZATION, AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF PRIMARY CARE/WELLNESS VISITS, AS WELL A REDUCTION IN HEALTHCARE DISPARITIES IN IDENTIFIED VULNERABLE AND HIGH-RISK COMMUNITIES.   THIS IS A DISCREET ONE-TIME REQUEST TO FUND THE EQUIPMENT AND STARTUP COSTS OF A MOBILE VAN WITHIN SUSSEX COUNTY, WITH MOST EQUIPMENT BEING PURCHASED BY OCTOBER 1, 2022.  ALL FUNDING WILL BE USED WITHIN 3 YEARS OF BEING AWARDED.  THERE IS NO PLAN FOR FUTURE REQUESTS FOR THIS PROGRAM AND OPERATING FUNDS WILL COME FROM OTHER SOURCES.

THE FUNDING OF THIS PHASE 2 OF THE PROJECT WILL ASSURE THE CONTINUITY OF HEALTH CARE SERVICES AT KUAKINI'S LONG TERM CARE FACILITIES AND MAINTAINING A SAFE ENVIRONMENT FOR THE LONG TERM CARE RESIDENTS DURING DISASTERS AND EMERGENCIES.

AS OF THIS APPLICATION ON MAY 31, 2022, ALL THE PLANNING, DESIGN, AND PLANNING BOARD PRESENTATION TO THE CITY OF GARFIELD HAVE ALL BEEN COMPLETED.  THERE ARE NO FEDERAL ENVIRONMENTAL, NOR HISTORIC PERSEVERATION REQUIREMENTS.  THE REST OF THE TIMELINE IS AS FOLLOWS: - JULY 2022 AND AUGUST 2022 OBTAINING REQUIRED PERMITS. - AUGUST 2022 DEMOLITION OF THE HOUSE AT THE FRONT OF THE PROPERTY; ELECTRICAL AND PLUMBING WORK ON THE COMMUNITY FOODBANK OF NJ CUSTOMER CHOICE PANTRY. - SEPTEMBER 2022 RENOVATION OF THE CBH CARE SPACE. - SEPTEMBER 2022 APPLICATIONS SUBMITTED TO NJ DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH FOR THE BVMI CLINICAL SPACE APPROVALS. - MAJOR CONSTRUCTION OF THE RAW SPACE BEGINS IN OCTOBER 2022 AND CONCLUDES IN JUNE 2023.  THE ENTIRE PROJECT WILL BE COMPLETED BY JUNE 2023.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - FAMILY SERVICES INC., A 501 (C)(3) NON-PROFIT, HAS EMBARKED ON A $9.1M CAPITAL PROJECT IN ORDER TO INCREASE THE SAFETY, ACCESSIBILITY, AND LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF THE FAMILY PARTNERSHIP CENTER (FPC). THIS FUNDING WILL BE DIRECTED TOWARD THE FRONT ENTRYWAY PROJECT. THE FPC HOUSES FAMILY SERVICES’ HUMAN SERVICES PROGRAMS AS WELL AS THE SERVICES AND PROGRAMS OF 22 COMPLEMENTARY NONPROFITS MANY OF WHICH PROVIDE BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES. EXAMPLES INCLUDE SUN RIVER HEALTH, DUTCHESS COUNTY HEALTHY FAMILIES, DUTCHESS BEHAVIORAL AND COMMUNITY HEALTH CLINIC, FINISH STRONG WELLNESS CENTER, AND FAMILY SERVICES' TRAUMA THERAPY AND COUNSELING, SNUG SOCIAL WORK AND CASE MANAGEMENT AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICES. THE FPC SERVES AN ESTIMATED 70,000 INDIVIDUALS A YEAR WITH WELL OVER 110,000 SERVICE INTERACTIONS. WHILE MANY IN-PERSON REVITALIZATION EFFORTS WERE POSTPONED OR CANCELED OVER THE PAST TWO YEARS DUE TO THE PANDEMIC, THE FPC REMAINED OPEN AND THRIVING, THOUGH ADAPTED AND RESPONSIVE TO COVID-19.  BEHAVIORAL HEALTH DISORDERS AFFECT NEARLY ONE IN FIVE AMERICANS AND THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC INCREASED DEMAND FOR BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES. A RECENT POLL BY THE KAISER FAMILY FOUNDATION FOUND THAT ALMOST 50 PERCENT OF PEOPLE REPORTED THAT CORONAVIRUS HAD A NEGATIVE EFFECT ON THEIR MENTAL HEALTH. THE IMPACT OF UNTREATED BEHAVIORAL HEALTH NEEDS ON AN INDIVIDUALS’ LIFE AND PHYSICAL HEALTH INCREASES IN CHRONIC HEALTH CONDITIONS, GREATER LIKELIHOOD OF EMERGENCY ROOM TREATMENT OR HOSPITALIZATION, AND DECREASED LIFE EXPECTANCY. IN 2021, FAMILY SERVICES IMPACTED THE LIVES OF 5,931 INDIVIDUALS WHO RECEIVED BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES.   ACCESS TO BEHAVIORAL HEALTHCARE WHEN THERE IS A REDUCTION IN SOCIAL CONNECTEDNESS LIKE WE HAVE SEEN THROUGHOUT THE PANDEMIC IS KEY. THROUGH A CLIENT SURVEY, FAMILY SERVICES FOUND THAT 89% OF CLIENTS FELT CONNECTED WITH THEIR COUNSELING OR MEDICAL STAFF DURING TELEHEALTH SESSIONS AND 77% FELT AS IF THEY WERE MAKI NG PROGRESS ON TREATMENT GOALS THROUGH TELEHEALTH. HOWEVER, CLIENTS ALSO EXPRESSED EAGERNESS TO RETURN TO AN IN-PERSON MODEL, PARTICULARLY RELEVANT, DUE TO THE FPC’S CO-LOCATION OF COMPLEMENTARY PROGRAMS AND SERVICES AS NOTED ABOVE. THE FPC’S MODEL SUPPORTS A “WARM HAND OFF” BETWEEN RELATED BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES, RATHER THAN “COLD REFERRALS,” A MODEL THAT SUPPORTS BETTER PARTICIPATION RATES.  THE FPC IS ALSO HOST TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS WHICH ADDRESS SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH (SDOH) THAT HAVE DIRECT BEARING ON THE MENTAL AND PHYSICAL HEALTH OF INDIVIDUALS IN THE COMMUNITY. THESE SDOH ARE ADDRESSED BY FPC PARTNER TENANTS THROUGH SUPPORT FOR VICTIMS OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE AND SEXUAL ASSAULT; GUN VIOLENCE PREVENTION; MINIMIZING HUNGER AND POVERTY; SERVICES TO MARGINALIZED YOUTH; AND OTHER PROGRAMS AND SERVICES.  IN 2019, FAMILY SERVICES (OWNER AND MANAGER OF THE FPC) COMPLETED A MASTER CAPITAL PLAN. LAST YEAR, IT WAS AWARDED PARTIAL FUNDING FROM NYS’S OFFICE OF COMMUNITY RENEWAL TOWARD COMPLETE RENOVATION OF THE ENTRYWAY’S DETERIORATING STRUCTURAL COMPONENTS, WHICH WILL PROVIDE A STRUCTURALLY SAFE AND SOUND FRONT ENTRANCE; TRUE AND EQUITABLE ACCESSIBILITY FOR THOSE WITH LIMITED MOBILITY; AND A BRIGHT WELCOMING PATH, WITH ADDITIONAL PROGRAM SPACE FOR THOSE SEEKING THE SERVICES AND RESOURCES THAT CAN HELP THEM TOWARD HEALING AND SUCCESS. A TRAUMA-INFORMED ORGANIZATION IS ONE IN WHICH ALL COMPONENTS HAVE BEEN RECONSIDERED AND EVALUATED IN LIGHT OF A BASIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE ROLE TRAUMA PLAYS IN THE LIVES OF MANY. THESE CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS WILL REFLECT A DESIGN THAT REPRESENT FAMILY SERVICES’ COMMITMENT TO OUR CLIENTS BY ENSURING THAT THEY FEEL SAFE AND COMFORTABLE AND THAT OUR ENVIRONMENT IS WELCOMING, HEALING, AND EMPOWERING. OVERALL, THE PROJECT COMPONENTS ARE GEARED TOWARDS MAKING THE FPC MORE ACCESSIBLE AND SUSTAINABLE, AS WELL AS PHYSICALLY APPROPRIATE TO ITS CLIENTS, AND ENABLING IT TO CONTINUE OFFERING LI

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - CONCORD UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF PROFESSIONAL NURSING WITH AN EMPHASIS ON RURAL HEALTH SOLUTIONS (CONSTRUCTION)  PROJECT DIRECTOR: DANIEL OWEN FITZPATRICK  CONTACT PHONE NUMBERS: V (304) 384 5276 FAX (304) 384 5178  EMAIL ADDRESS: DFITZPATRICK@CONCORD.EDU HTTPS://WWW.CONCORD.EDU/  GRANT FUNDS REQUESTED: $1,600,000  CONCORD UNIVERSITY, ATHENS, WEST VIRGINIA, WILL USE THE HRSA-22-134 GRANT AWARD FOR A FACILITY MODERNIZATION PROJECT WITH EQUIPMENT FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE CONCORD UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF PROFESSIONAL NURSING WITH AN EMPHASIS ON RURAL HEALTH SOLUTIONS. CONCORD IS ESTABLISHING A PROFESSIONAL NURSING PROGRAM AT THE BACCALAUREATE LEVEL WITH AN EMPHASIS IN RURAL HEALTH SOLUTIONS, WHICH WILL BE HOUSED, IN PART, IN THE MODERNIZED SPACE. THE EXISTING SPACE IS VACANT AND AVAILABLE BUT IN NEED OF MODERNIZATION TO BRING IT BACK INTO SERVICE. THE PRIMARY SERVICE AREA INCLUDES THE POPULATIONS OF THE THIRD CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT IN SOUTHERN WEST VIRGINIA. THE SCOPE OF THE CONCORD UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF PROFESSIONAL NURSING WITH AN EMPHASIS ON RURAL HEALTH SOLUTIONS (CONSTRUCTION) PROJECT INCLUDES, BUT IS NOT LIMITED TO, IMPROVEMENT AND/OR RECONFIGURATION OF THE INTERIOR ARRANGEMENTS OF AN EXISTING WHOLLY-OWNED FACILITY; PURCHASE OF EQUIPMENT; INSTALLATION OF PERMANENTLY AFFIXED EQUIPMENT; MODIFICATIONS TO THE BUILDING’S EXTERIOR TO ADDRESS ADA ACCESSIBILITY ISSUES; HEATING, VENTILATION, AND AIR-CONDITIONING (HVAC) MODIFICATIONS; AND, ELECTRICAL AND PLUMBING UPGRADES. THE MODERNIZATI ON AND PURCHASE OF CERTAIN EQUIPMENT WILL BE SUBJECT TO BID OR RFP AS PREPROPERATE. USE OF A THIRD-PARTY CONSTRUCTION MANAGER IS ANTICIPATED.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - RUTLAND COUNTY IS HOME TO THE ONE OF THE LARGEST POPULATIONS OF RESIDENTS 85+ IN VERMONT. IN THIS LARGELY RURAL AREA, PORTIONS OF WHICH ARE MEDICALLY-UNDERSERVED AREAS/POPULATIONS, SENIORS FACE CHALLENGES IN ACCESSING HEALTH CARE, INCLUDING TRANSPORTATION, LACK OF SPECIALTY SERVICES, AND LACK OF SUPPORTS FOR MANAGING CHRONIC CONDITIONS. WITH A SHORTAGE OF PROVIDERS AND SERVICES THAT ARE GEOGRAPHICALLY AND ECONOMICALLY WITHIN REACH, ELDERS MISS DOCTORS APPOINTMENTS, SKIP MEDICATIONS, AND EXPERIENCE UNNECESSARY DECLINE IN HEALTH CONDITIONS.  CHRONIC DISEASES (INCLUDING COPD, DIABETES, CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE, AND CANCER) CLAIM THE LIVES OF MORE THAN 59% OF COUNTY RESIDENTS EACH YEAR. IN ADDITION, CHRONIC ILLNESSES ARE ASSOCIATED WITH SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASED RISK OF HAVING OR DEVELOPING A MENTAL HEALTH CONDITION. EXPANDED SPECIALTY CARE SERVICES ARE NEEDED FOR THOSE WITH MEMORY AND EARLY DEMENTIA DIAGNOSES IN ORDER TO ADDRESS HIGH RATES OF ALZHEIMER’S DISEASE DEATHS PER YEAR IN RUTLAND COUNTY.  THIS PROJECT WILL CREATE A NEW GERIATRIC SERVICES CLINIC IN RUTLAND TO PROVIDE SPECIALTY SERVICES FOR ELDERS IN THE REGION. THIS EXPANSION OF COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTERS OF THE RUTLAND REGION (CHCRR) CURRENT GERIATRIC SERVICES PROGRAM WILL DOUBLE THE NUMBER OF CURRENT PROVIDERS AND INCREASE ACCESS TO SERVICES THAT MEET THE COMPLEX NEEDS OF OLDER ADULTS, INCLUDING CHRONIC DISEASE TREATMENT AND MANAGEMENT, MEMORY CARE, MENTAL HEALTH CARE, AND PHYSICAL REHABILITATION.  THE PROJECT IS THE SECOND PHASE OF A TWO-PHASE RENOVATION AND MODIFICATION OF COMMUNITY HEALTH NORTH MAIN, A 17,972 SQUARE FOOT BUILDING ON 1.6 ACRES, LOCATED AT 231 NORTH MAIN STREET, RUTLAND. BUILT IN 1983, IT WAS PURCHASED IN SEPTEMBER 2021 BY CHCRR. THE BUILDING SERVED FROM 1993 TO 2021 AS ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICES FOR THE U.S. FORESTRY SERVICE. CHCRR IS ADAPTING THE SITE TO MEET EXPANDING ADMINISTRATIVE AND CLINICAL NEEDS, INCLUDING THE CREATION OF A NEW GERIATRIC SERVICES CLINIC.   THE PROJECT WIL L: 1) INCREASE ACCESS TO SPECIALTY SERVICES FOR ELDERS, IMPROVING QUALITY OF CARE AND OUTCOMES; 2) IMPROVE ACCESS TO CHRONIC AND PREVENTIVE CARE, REDUCING COSTLY RELIANCE ON EMERGENCY DEPARTMENTS, HOSPITAL BEDS, AND NURSING HOMES; AND 3) MAKE A SOUND INVESTMENT IN ENSURING THAT CARE IS ACCESSIBLE FOR THE PROJECTED DOUBLING OF THE 65-AND-OVER POPULATION IN THE NEXT THREE DECADES.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ADDRESS: 1969 MINER STREET, IDAHO SPRINGS, CO 80452 PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: BETH LUTHER CONTACT INFORMATION:  	OFFICE: 303-679-2312 FAX: 303-679-2440 EMAIL: BLUTHER@CLEARCREEKCOUNTY.US WEBSITE ADDRESS: WWW.CLEARCREEKCOUNTY.US  CLEAR CREEK COUNTY RESIDENTS HAVE HAD ACCESS TO PRIMARY CARE CHALLENGES FOR MORE THAN TEN YEARS. FOR A LONG TIME, IT WAS COMMON FOR RESIDENTS TO CALL 911 FOR AMBULANCE SERVICE TO AN EMERGENCY ROOM JUST TO RECEIVE BASIC HEALTH CARE. FOR MANY IN CLEAR CREEK COUNTY, COST OF GASOLINE, LACK OF A RELIABLE VEHICLE, AND LIMITED AT BEST PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION OPTIONS OUT OF THE COUNTY, THE JOURNEY TO HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS COULD PROVE NEARLY IMPOSSIBLE AT TIMES.   CLEAR CREEK COUNTY IS SEEKING FUNDING FOR A NEWLY CONSTRUCTED ONE-STOP “COLLABORATIVE CARE CENTER”. COMPLETED IN JULY OF 2021, THE 12,000 SQ. FT. FACILITY, NAMED THE CLEAR CREEK COUNTY HEALTH & WELLNESS CENTER HOUSES PRIMARY CARE, STATE AND FEDERAL ELIGIBILITY PROGRAMS, MENTAL AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PROVIDERS ACCEPTING MEDICAID, CLEAR CREEK COUNTY PUBLIC HEALTH PROVIDING IMMUNIZATIONS FOR CHILDREN AND ADULTS, WIC, AND OTHER CDPHE CORE SERVICES. COMBINING THESE SERVICES IN ONE LOCATION MAKES EACH ONE MORE EFFECTIVE AND SUSTAINABLE.  WE ARE ON THE ROAD TOWARD INCREASING PRIMARY CARE VISITS FROM OUR CURRENT STANDING WELL BELOW THE STATE AVERAGE, BEHAVIORAL HEALTH REFERRAL FOLLOW-UP, AND OUR IMMUNIZATION RATES THROUGH THIS SINGLE PROJECT.  THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF CLEAR CREEK COUNTY RESIDENTS AND OUR NEIGHBORS BY ENABLING US TO FINALLY ADDRESS HEALTH EQUITY ISSUES THAT HAVE BEEN PRESENT FOR YEARS.  IT IS PROJECTED TO GENERATE EXCESS REVENUES WHICH CAN FURTHER SUPPORT THE HEALTH OF THE COMMUNITY.  THIS ALL-IN APPROACH TO COLLABORATIVE CARE COULD BECOME THE MODEL FOR RURAL HEALTH CARE DELIVERY, WHICH IS WHY MANY OF OUR FUNDERS AROUND THE STATE SEE THIS PROJECT AS AN INVESTMENT IN RURAL HEALTH EVERYWHERE.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ADDRESS - CHILDRENS NATIONAL HOSPITAL, 111 MICHIGAN AVENUE NW, WASHINGTON, DC 20010  PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME - DR. MICHAEL BELL  CONTACT PHONE NUMBER (VOICE) - 202-476-2037 EMAIL ADDRESS -  MBELL@CHILDRENSNATIONAL.ORG WEBSITE ADDRESS - WWW.CHILDRENSNATIONAL.ORG   FOUNDED IN 1870, CHILDREN'S NATIONAL HOSPITAL (CNH) IS A NATIONALLY RANKED, FREESTANDING, 323-BED, PEDIATRIC ACUTE CARE CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL LOCATED IN WASHINGTON D.C. THE HOSPITAL FEATURES AN ACS VERIFIED LEVEL I PEDIATRIC TRAUMA CENTER, THE ONLY IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA. ITS REGIONAL PEDIATRIC INTENSIVE-CARE UNIT AND NEONATAL INTENSIVE CARE UNITS SERVE THE REGION. CNH’S PEDIATRIC INTENSIVE CARE UNIT IS A KEY ELEMENT OF FOR THE RECOVERY FROM TRAUMATIC INJURIES AND FOR THE CARE OF ESPECIALLY SICK CHILDREN REQUIRING ACTIVE LIFE SAVING CARE. THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW CNH TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF AIRBORNE ISOLATION ROOMS TO BETTER MANAGE INFECTIOUS DISEASE CARE, INCLUDING FLU AND COVID INFECTIONS.   IN ADDITION, CNH WILL ADD PROTECTIVE ISOLATION ROOMS WHICH ALLOWS FOR  THE CARE OF IMMUNO-SUPPRESSED PATIENTS.  PATIENT AND FAMILY SUPPORT WITHIN THE UNIT WILL INCLUDE SERVICE SPACES SUCH AS FAMILY WAITING AND RESPITE ROOMS, TEAM WORK AREAS, MATERIAL AND EQUIPMENT STORAGE.  THE TOTAL RENOVATION AREA IS APPROXIMATELY 24,000 SQUARE FEET, AND WILL RESULT IN AN ALL-PRIVATE ROOM UNIT FOR INPATIENT CARE AS REQUIRED BY CONTEMPORARY HOSPITAL PLANNING STANDARDS.    WITH THE CONVERSION OF OFFICE SPACE TO INPATIENT CARE, MAJOR RENOVATIONS AND ALTERATIONS TO THE MECHANICAL AND ELECTRICAL SYSTEMS SERVING THE AREA ARE REQUIRED.  HEATING, VENTILATION AND AIR CONDITIONING UPGRADES FOR PATIENT CARE INCLUDE THE REPLACEMENT OF THE CENTRAL AIR HANDLERS SERVING THE UNIT, AND THE ADDITION OF NEW EXHAUST FANS.  MEDICAL GAS SYSTEMS INCLUDING OXYGEN, MEDICAL AIR AND VACUUM WILL BE PROVIDED AT EACH PATIENT ROOM.  PATIENT ROOMS WILL INCLUDE A PRIVATE TOILET WITH HAND SINKS. RIDGEWOOD AVENUE, PARAMUS, NJ 07432, SAW A STEEP INCREASE IN ED VOLUME DURING THE COVID CRISIS. THE INCREASING MEDICAL VOLUME COUPLED WITH THE NEED TO ISOLATE COVID-19, AND OTHER INFECTIOUS PATIENTS FROM THIS VULNERABLE POPULATION IS CRITICAL IN ENSURING HEALTH AND WELL-BEING IN THE GREATER BERGEN COUNTY AREA. COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PROJECT ADDRESS: 10 E BRUNEAU AVE, KENNEWICK, WA 99336 PROJECT DIRECTOR: MATTHEW RASMUSSEN, DEPUTY COUNTY ADMINISTRATOR CONTACT PHONE: 509-786-5600 EXT. 5646 EMAIL: MATT.RASMUSSEN@CO.BENTON.WA.US GRANT PROGRAM FUNDS REQUESTED: $2,000,000 THE THREE RIVERS BEHAVIORAL HEALTH RECOVERY CENTER WILL BE A COMPREHENSIVE BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CENTER TO SERVE PERSONS IN MENTAL HEALTH CRISIS OR SUFFERING FROM SUBSTANCE USE DISORDER WITH OR WITHOUT CO-OCCURRING MENTAL HEALTH DISORDERS. THE FACILITY WILL OPERATE ON A “NO WRONG DOOR” MODEL PROVIDING 24 HOUR A DAY, 365 DAY A YEAR SERVICES OFFERED AS AN ALTERNATIVE TO ARREST AND INCARCERATION IN THE COUNTY JAIL OR BEING BROUGHT TO HOSPITAL EMERGENCY ROOMS. WORKING IN CONJUNCTION WITH LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT PERSONS IN CRISIS CAN BE BROUGHT TO THE FACILITY AND BE ADMITTED FOR CARE WITHIN 10 MINUTES. DESIGNATED CRISIS RESPONDERS WILL BE ON SITE TO MEET WITH INDIVIDUALS EXPERIENCING A BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CRISIS AS AN ENTRY POINT INTO THE HEALTH CARE SYSTEM. THE FACILITY WILL PROVIDE ON-DEMAND ASSESSMENT SERVICES, ALONG WITH MEDICAL WITHDRAWAL MANAGEMENT SERVICES AT THE SECURE AND NON-SECURE LEVELS BASED ON THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF ADDICTION MEDICINE GUIDELINES.  THIS PROJECT FILLS A MAJOR UNMET NEED IN SOUTHEASTERN WASHINGTON STATE. THE TRI-CITIES AND THE SURROUNDING REGION BOASTS A POPULATION OF OVER 500,000 RESIDENTS AND CONSISTS OF 8 COUNTIES WITH OF A LAND AREA OF 10,500 SQUARE MILES, THE SIZE OF THE STATE OF MASSACHUSETTS. WHILE MASSACHUSETTS IS HOME TO 25 DETOX FACILITIES AND 68 RESIDENTIAL TREATMENT FACILITIES OUR REGION HAS NONE. THE RATIO OF MENTAL HEALTH PROVIDERS PER 100,000 CITIZENS IS ROUGHLY 60% LESS THAN THE RATE FOUND IN THE SEATTLE METRO AREA (191.1 PER 100,000 VERSUS 303.8 PER 100,000). THE MOST RECENT COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENTS AND COMMUNITY HEALTH IMPROVEMENT PLANS COMPLETED BY THE BENTON-FRANKLIN HEALTH DISTRICT AND KADLEC HOSPITAL BOTH CONCLUDED THAT BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CHALLENGES, SUCH AS MENTAL  HEALTH, SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND SUICIDE, CONSTITUTE THE GREATEST UNMET NEEDS IN BENTON AND FRANKLIN COUNTIES.  BOTH THE HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT AND HEALTH IMPROVEMENT PLANS CALL FOR INCREASED ACCESS FOR SERVICES AND STRONGLY SUPPORT A COMMUNITY-WIDE EFFORT TO IMPROVE ACCESS TO SERVICES FOR DETOX, RECOVERY, AND SUBSTANCE USE DISORDER TREATMENT WITHIN THE REGION.  THE PROJECT WILL REMODEL AN EXISTING BUILDING INTO A 32-BED BEHAVIORAL HEALTH FACILITY. THE FACILITY WILL HOUSE A CRISIS STABILIZATION UNIT, PROVIDING A ONE STOP SHOP FOR PERSONS SUFFERING FROM MENTAL HEALTH OR SUBSTANCE USE RELATED CRISIS. THE FACILITY WILL OPERATE AS AN INVOLUNTARY CRISIS STABILIZATION UNIT WITH AN ATTACHED SECURE WITHDRAWAL MANAGEMENT FACILITY. PEOPLE ADMITTED TO THE FACILITY WILL GO TO A COMMON AREA FOR EVALUATION, OPERATING WITH A “RECLINER MODEL”, WHERE THEY WILL STAY FOR LESS THAN 24 HOURS TO EITHER BE STABILIZED OR MOVED TO THE OVER NIGHT MENTAL HEALTH AREA OR THE SECURE WITHDRAWAL MANAGEMENT AREA. ONCE PEOPLE ARE STABILIZED THEY WILL RECEIVE A FULL CONTINUATION OF CARE PLAN AND BE REFERRED OUT TO OTHER SERVICES IN EITHER AN OUTPATIENT OR RESIDENTIAL DETOX FACILITY. THE PROJECT IS LOCATED AT 10 E BRUNEAU AVE, KENNEWICK, WASHINGTON AND IS ONE OF SEVERAL BUILDING ON THAT SITE. THE CURRENT OWNER DESIRES TO LEASE THE BUILDING TO THE COUNTY FOR AN INITIAL TERM OF 25 YEARS. THE COUNTY WILL RESERVE A FIRST RIGHT OF REFUSAL TO PURCHASE THE BUILDING SHOULD THE OWNER ELECT TO SELL IT DURING THE LEASE PERIOD. PRELIMINARY WORK FOR THE PROJECT BEGAN IN 2020 BY DEVELOPING A GOAL FOR THE PROJECT AND SEEKING FUNDING. BY 2022 THE COUNTY HAD SECURED SUFFICIENT FUNDING TO MOVE FORWARD WITH FINDING A LOCATION FOR THE FACILITY. AFTER UNSUCCESSFUL NEGOTIATION FOR ITS FIRST CHOICE LOCATION THE COUNTY LOCATED THE SITE IN EASTERN KENNEWICK. CONSTRUCTION IS EXPECTED TO BEGIN IN 2023 WITH AN ANTICIPATED OPENING DATE IN THE END OF 2024.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - BANJ HEALTH CENTER, INC. (BANJ) HAS BEEN AN APPROVED, LICENSED COMMUNITY CLINIC FOR OVER 20 YEARS. FOUNDED BY MARIE LAMOTHE, CEO, THE CLINIC HAS BEEN GUIDED AND DIRECTED BY AN ACTIVE BOARD OF DIRECTORS COMPRISED OF COMMUNITY RESIDENTS, AS WELL AS BUSINESS AND PROFESSIONAL MEMBERS. THE CLINIC AND ITS TWO SATELLITE FACILITIES SERVE AS A MEDICAL HOME TO MORE THAN 3,000 REGISTERED PATIENTS. BANJ WAS CREATED TO SERVE THE LOW INCOME, UNINSURED AND MARGINALLY INSURED INDIVIDUALS RESIDING WITHIN THE CITY OF COMPTON AND SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES. THE CLINIC PROVIDES A FULL RANGE OF ADULT AND PEDIATRIC PRIMARY CARE SERVICES INCLUDING FAMILY PLANNING, HIV TESTING AND COUNSELING, PRE-NATAL SERVICES INCLUDING REFERRALS TO OB-GYN SPECIALTY PROVIDERS AT THE APPROPRIATE TIME OF CARE. THE CLINIC IS CONTRACTED TO TREAT MANAGED CARE PATIENTS WITH MULTIPLE HEALTH PLANS AND MEDICAL GROUPS. BANJ UTILIZES A SLIDING FEE SCHEDULE TO TREAT UNINSURED PATIENTS. THE SCHEDULE IS BASED UPON THE MOST RECENT FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL GUIDELINES AND IS UPDATED YEARLY AND APPROVED BY THE CLINIC’S BOARD OF DIRECTORS.  BANJ’S PRIMARY CARE SERVICE AREA IS HOME TO MORE THAN 825,000 INDIVIDUALS, BASED UPON THE MOST RECENT U.S. CENSUS. TWO THIRDS, (62. %) OF THIS POPULATION LIVE BELOW 200% OF THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL (FPG) GUIDELINES. 29% LIVE BELOW 100% OF THE FPG. NEARLY 80% OF THE AREA RESIDENTS IDENTIFY AS HISPANIC/LATINO WITH ANOTHER 15% IDENTIFIED AS BLACK, AFRICAN AMERICAN. THESE FIGURES EMPHASIZE THE NEED FOR CULTURALLY AND ETHNICALLY SENSITIVE APPROACH TO PROVIDING PRIMARY CARE SERVICES. THIS SERVICE AREA IS ALSO FAIRLY YOUNG, WITH 29% OF ITS RESIDENTS BETWEEN THE AGES OF 25 – 44. MORE THAN 1 IN 5 (22.3%) ARE CHILDREN AGES 5 – 17. NEARLY 80% OF THE SERVICE ARE POPULATION LACK A COLLEGE EDUCATION AND MORE THAN 45% OF THE SERVICE AREA ADULTS ARE WITHOUT A HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMA. THE SERVICE AREA’S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE REMAINS CHRONICALLY HIGH AND DESPITE THE RECENT UPTURN IN THE ECONOMY, I T REMAINS AT 14% BASED UPON THE MOST RECENT BUREAU OF LABOR STATISTICS. THESE POVERTY INDICATORS SERVE AS YET ANOTHER BARRIER PREVENTING MANY RESIDENTS FROM ACCESSING BASIC HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES SO DESPERATELY NEEDED.   BANJ IS REQUESTING A $50,000 GRANT TO SUPPORT THE PURCHASE OF A MORE COMPREHENSIVE IMMUNOASSAY SYSTEM FOR ITS LABORATORY IN COMPTON. THE SIEMENS ADVIA CENTAUR CP IMMUNOASSAY SYSTEM IS A COMPREHENSIVE DIAGNOSTIC TESTING COVERS SCREENING, DIAGNOSIS, RISK ASSESSMENT AND MONITORING WITH A CAPACITY OF 30 ONBOARD REAGENTS TO MAXIMIZE TEST CAPACITY. BANJ WILL BE ALLOCATING $17,000 OF ITS OWN OPERATING FUNDS, TO COVER THE REMAINING COST OF THE $67,000 PIECE OF MOVEABLE EQUIPMENT DESCRIBED ABOVE. THIS PIECE OF EQUIPMENT WILL BENEFIT PATIENTS AT ALL THREE CLINICAL LOCATIONS. THE PROJECT ALSO BENEFITTING OUR MOST VULNERABLE LOW INCOME, UNINSURED PATIENTS SINCE BANJ WILL NOW BE IN A BETTER FINANCIAL POSITION TO PROVIDE COMPREHENSIVE  OUTPATIENT LAB DIAGNOSTIC TESTING FOR THOSE INDIVIDUALS LEAST ABLE TO AFFORD SUCH LABORATORY SERVICES AS PART OF THEIR MEDICAL CARE.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - WILL-GRUNDY MEDICAL CLINIC IS RENOVATING OUR FACILITY IN ORDER TO EXPAND AND IMPROVE SERVICES. THIS PROJECT WILL RENOVATE A 120-YEAR OLD FACILITY IN ORDER TO IMPROVE SERVICES AND EXPAND OUR NEWEST PROGRAM, HOUSING, HEALTHCARE AND HOPE (HHH).

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - WHITESIDE COUNTY COMMUNITY HEALTH CLINIC (WCCHC) HAS BEEN SERVING THE NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITY SINCE 2006.  PROVIDING AFFORDABLE HEALTH CARE THAT MEETS THE COMMUNITY’S NEEDS THROUGH A MULTIDISCIPLINARY APPROACH, WCCHC IS A TRADITIONAL HEALTH DEPARTMENT, WITH AN FQHC WITHIN PROVIDING  PRIMARY MEDICAL, DENTAL, AND BH CLINICS AS WELL AS A MEDICATED ASSISTED TREATMENT (MAT) PROGRAM. THIS UNIQUE MODEL ALLOWS A HOLISTIC AND COLLABORATIVE APPROACH TO COMMUNITY HEALTH CARE. THE COMMUNITY HEALTH CLINIC SERVES PATIENTS BOTH WITHIN WHITESIDE COUNTY AS WELL AS SURROUNDING AREAS.  APPROXIMATELY 50% OF THE PATIENTS HAVE MEDICAID AND APPROXIMATELY 19% HAVE NO INSURANCE AT ALL.  WCCHC ALSO SERVES THE MAJORITY OF THE HISPANIC POPULATION IN OUR AREA AS WCCHC PROVIDES CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE SERVICES AND IS THE “GO-TO “IN THE HISPANIC COMMUNITY.     WCCHC RECOGNIZES THE INCREASED NEED, PERHAPS NOW MORE THAN EVER, FOR ACCESSIBLE HEALTHCARE FOR A MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED POPULATION. WCCHC HAS CONTINUED TO EXPAND SINCE ITS INCEPTION.   THIS YEAR WCCHC EXPANDED ITS MAT PROGRAM TO THE NEIGHBORING COUNTY TO ASSIST IN COMBATING THE ONGOING OPIOID CRISIS.  PAST EXPANSIONS HAVE INCLUDED A BEHAVIORAL HEALTH ADDITION, ADDITIONAL DENTAL SUITES INCLUDING A HANDICAP ACCESSIBLE SUITE AND ADDITIONAL WAITING AND REGISTRATION AREAS, AND A LARGER BILLING AND CODING SUITE.    WCCHC WILL USE THIS FUNDING TO CONSTRUCT A 1,880 SQUARE FOOT ADDITION TO OUR MAIN LOCATION.   THIS SPACE WILL ALLOW US TO INTRODUCE NEW AND MUCH NEEDED SERVICES TO OUR COMMUNITY.  THE AMERICAN OPTOMETRIC ASSOCIATION STATED THAT LESS THAN 3% OF AMERICANS WHO UTILIZE FQHC’S WERE ABLE TO ACCESS EYE/VISION HEALTH CARE IN A 2019 SURVEY.   WCCHC WOULD LIKE TO ADDRESS THE SIGNIFICANT BARRIERS MANY PATIENTS FACE WHEN SEEKING VISION/EYE HEALTH CARE.  LIKE MANY COMMUNITIES ACROSS AMERICA, WHITESIDE COUNTY HAS ONLY A FEW OPTIONS FOR VISION CARE AND MOST DO NOT ACCEPT MEDICAID OR HAVE SLIDING FEE SCALE PROGRAMS FOR THE UNINSURED.   THE UNDERSERVED POPULATION OF WHITESIDE COUNTY SEEKS SERVICES AT OUR CLINIC FOR THEIR OTHER HEALTH CARE NEEDS.   ADDING THIS ADDITIONAL SERVICE WILL EXPAND OUR ABILITY TO MEET OUR PATIENT NEEDS ESPECIALLY THE 13% OF OUR PATIENTS WHO HAVE A DIAGNOSES OF DIABETES FOR WHOM REGULAR EYE HEALTH CARE IS IMPERATIVE.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PROJECT ADDRESS: 606 E. HALLIBURTON, KIRKSVILLE, MO 63501 PROJECT DIRECTOR: LORI SHOOK, AUID CONTACT PHONE:  660.785.7226 E-MAIL ADDRESS: LSHOOK@TRUMAN.EDU  FUNDING REQUEST: $3,420,000  THIS PROJECT INVOLVES RENOVATION OF THE GREENWOOD BUILDING, A FORMER ELEMENTARY SCHOOL THAT SITS ADJACENT TO THE TRUMAN STATE UNIVERSITY CAMPUS AND WAS PURCHASED BY THE UNIVERSITY IN 1998.   GREENWOOD ELEMENTARY SCHOOL WAS COMPLETED IN 1935 AND NAMED FOR JAMES GREENWOOD, A NOTED MISSOURI EDUCATOR IN THE LATE 1800’S. THE ARCHITECTS FOR THE SCHOOL WERE BONSACK AND PEARCE OF ST. LOUIS. THEY DESIGNED MANY EDUCATIONAL FACILITIES IN MISSOURI INCLUDING SEVERAL ON TRUMAN’S CAMPUS. THIS PROJECT PRESERVES A LANDMARK BUILDING WHICH PLAYED A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN EDUCATING CHILDREN IN KIRKSVILLE.  THE GREENWOOD PROJECT REPURPOSES A FORMER EXISTING ELEMENTARY SCHOOL BUILDING OF ABOUT 26,700 TOTAL SQUARE FEET. A STATE-FUNDED CONSTRUCTION PROJECT IS UNDERWAY TO RENOVATE THE FIRST FLOOR AND ADD A SMALL ENTRY ADDITION WITH AN ELEVATOR. THE PROPOSED WORK FOR THIS FEDERALLY-FUNDED PROJECT WILL CONSIST PRIMARILY OF INTERIOR CONSTRUCTION; ASSOCIATED PLUMBING, MECHANICAL AND ELECTRICAL; FIXTURES AND FURNITURE FOR THE CLINIC SPACES; AND ROOFING REPLACEMENT. THE INTERIOR SPACES IMPACTED BY THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE GYMNASIUM, GYMNASIUM STAGE AND SECOND FLOOR AND TOTAL ABOUT 12,300 SQUARE FEET. THE EXTERIOR IMPROVEMENTS WILL BE LIMITED TO THE REPLACEMENT OF THE EXISTING ASPHALT SHINGLE ROOF, ANY NEEDED REPAIRS TO THE SHEATHING OR TRIM AND MINIMAL LANDSCAPING.    IN THE EXISTING GYM, THE STAGE AND BLEACHER SEATING WILL BE REMOVED IN THEIR ENTIRETY TO PROVIDE THE MAXIMUM AVAILABLE FLOOR SPACE TO CREATE A MULTI-USE SPACE, INCLUDING AN INDOOR THERAPY PLAYGROUND. THIS SPACE WILL BE FINISHED WITH A MULTI-PURPOSE FLOORING SURFACE, APPROPRIATE FOR ITS VARIOUS INTENDED USES. THE SOUTHWEST VESTIBULE WILL BE RECONFIGURED TO ENSURE ADA ACCESS TO EXTERIOR AND INTERIOR DOORS. THE EXISTING CEILING WILL BE  REMOVED TO ACCOMMODATE NEW ACOUSTICAL CEILING PANELS, LED LIGHTING, AND SUPPORTING STRUCTURES FOR A VARIETY OF SUSPENDED THERAPY EQUIPMENT.   THE RECONFIGURED SECOND FLOOR WILL INCLUDE AN OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY ROOM WITH KITCHEN EQUIPMENT, A MUSIC THERAPY ROOM WITH STORAGE, GRADUATE STUDENT OFFICE SPACE DESIGNED TO HOUSE MULTIPLE PEOPLE, A GRADUATE STUDENT SEMINAR ROOM, AND A PATIENT EXAMINATION POD. TWO STAIRWELL AREAS WILL BE RENOVATED TO PROVIDE ADDED SECURITY BETWEEN THE FLOOR LEVELS.  ONCE COMPLETE, THIS FACILITY, THE GREENWOOD INTERPROFESSIONAL AUTISM CENTER, WILL PROVIDE IN-DEPTH, INTERDISCIPLINARY ASSESSMENT AND INTERVENTION FOR CHILDREN WITH AUTISM OR SUSPECTED AUTISM AS WELL AS OTHER NEURO-DEVELOPMENTAL DISORDERS. THE COMPREHENSIVE HEALTH SERVICES CLINIC WILL BE STAFFED WITH LICENSED PROFESSIONALS, IN ADDITION TO SUPERVISED GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS ENROLLED IN HEALTH RELATED, ACADEMIC PROGRAMS. THE CLINIC WILL PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY FOR ENHANCED EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM OFFERINGS WHILE MEETING A MAJOR HEALTH NEED IN NORTHEAST MISSOURI. THIS PROJECT ALSO FACILITATES PUBLIC/PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS FOR ACADEMIC PROGRAMS AT TRUMAN STATE UNIVERSITY AND A.T. STILL UNIVERSITY, A PRIVATE HEALTH SCIENCES INSTITUTION IN KIRKSVILLE.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - CAPSTONE RURAL HEALTH CENTER  PRIMARY LOCATION: 5947 HIGHWAY 269, PARRISH, ALABAMA 35580 EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR: DR. F. DAVID JONES  205-832-8515 (P); 205-265-2994 (F) WWW.CAPSTONECLINIC.ORG AMOUNT REQUESTED: $725,000   CAPSTONE RURAL HEALTH CENTER IS REQUESTING FUNDS FOR A REPLACEMENT CLINIC IN NAUVOO, ALABAMA. THE CURRENTLY LEASED CLINIC IS INSUFFICIENT FOR SPACE AND ACCESSIBILITY. THE NEW REPLACEMENT CLINIC WILL HAVE THE ADDITIONAL SQUARE FOOTAGE FOR ADDITIONAL PROVIDERS, EXAM SPACE, AND BETTER PHARMACY SPACE. CAPSTONE RURAL HEALTH CENTER, A FEDERALLY QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTER, HAS SERVED IN THIS AREA SINCE 2015 AND TREATS PATIENTS FROM A WIDE GEOGRAPHICAL REACH. THIS CLINIC WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE MEDICAL CARE, PHARMACY SERVICES, COUNSELING SERVICES, AND TRANSPORTATION IN THE SERVICE AREA. WHILE THE CLINIC SERVES RESIDENTS WITH VARIOUS INSURANCE INCLUDING MEDICARE AND MEDICAID IT IS UNIQUELY POSITIONED TO SERVE THE POOR AND UNINSURED ON A SLIDING FEE BASED UPON INCOME. THE COMMUNITY IS PROUD OF ITS CLINIC AND WILL BE ENERGIZED BY THE NEW FACILITY.  THE CAPSTONE PHARMACY-NAUVOO WILL ALSO BE RELOCATED TO THE NEW FACILITY.  THE CAPSTONE PHARMACY-NAUVOO FILLS MORE THAN 2400 PRESCRIPTIONS EACH MONTH.  AS A PARTICIPANT IN HRSA’S 340B DRUG PRICING PROGRAM, THE PHARMACY REDUCES THE BURDEN OF MEDICATION COSTS FOR OUR UNINSURED PATIENTS.   THE PHARMACY IS CURRENTLY  LOCATED ON THE SECOND FLOOR OF THE CLINIC.  ALTHOUGH CAPSTONE ENSURES THAT ALL SERVICES ARE ACCESSIBLE TO EVERYONE, THIS LOCATION PRESENTS CHALLENGES.  THE NEW FACILITY WILL BE A SINGLE-LEVEL STRUCTURE AND WILL INCLUDE A 500-SQUARE-FOOT PHARMACY TO ADEQUATELY PROVIDE SPACE FOR 1 PHARMACIST AND 2 PHARMACY TECHNICIANS.      THE NEW CAPSTONE-NAUVOO WILL HAVE THE CAPACITY TO LOWER THE UNMET NEEDS OF THE LOW-INCOME POPULATION BY CONTINUING PROGRESS TO PROVIDE INTEGRATED CARE AT THE NAUVOO FACILITY.  MORE IMPORTANTLY, CAPSTONE RURAL HEALTH CENTER WILL HAVE THE INFRASTRUCTURE TO SERVE NAUVOO AND NORTH ERN WALKER COUNTY FOR YEARS TO COME.    BY RELOCATING THE CURRENT SERVICE SITE, CAPSTONE RURAL HEALTH CENTER IS ABLE TO CONTINUE TO BE A RESOURCE FOR THIS COMMUNITY TO BETTER SERVE THIS ISOLATED SECTION OF WALKER COUNTY.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - ST. JOHN’S RIVERSIDE HOSPITAL (SJRH) IN YONKERS, NY SEEKS $990,000 IN FEDERAL CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING (CDS) FROM THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES (DHHS) TO SUPPORT A COMMUNITY-DRIVEN EFFORT TO ADDRESS RACIAL INEQUITIES IN HEALTH OUTCOMES IN OUR MATERNITY DEPARTMENT. THIS GRANT FUNDING WILL BE USED TO CREATE SAFE AND CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE LABOR AND DELIVERY SPACES SUPPORTING BLACK MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH. SPECIFICALLY, THIS GRANT WILL FUND RENOVATIONS TO OUR EXISTING LABOR AND DELIVERY SPACE TO ENHANCE AND SUPPORT CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE CARE FOR BLACK BIRTHING WOMEN.  THE ADDITIONAL LABOR AND DELIVERY (L&D) ROOM WILL SUPPORT NATURAL, PHYSIOLOGIC BIRTH THROUGH INCORPORATION OF EQUIPMENT THAT WILL ALLOW MOVEMENT FOR THE BIRTHING PERSON, HAVE A BIRTHING BAR, BALLS, AND PEANUTS.  THIS NEWLY RENOVATED, CULTURALLY RELEVANT BIRTHING SPACE WILL SERVE AS THE CORNERSTONE OF SJRH’S COMMITMENT TO DISPELLING RACIAL INEQUITIES IN TREATMENT WITHIN OUR FACILITY.  THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED AND CONDUCTED IN COLLABORATION WITH BLACK COMMUNITY MEMBERS WITH EXPERTISE IN BLACK MATERNAL HEALTH AND WILL RAISE THE VOICES OF BLACK BIRTHING PEOPLE TO ADDRESS POTENTIAL INEQUITIES IN PROJECT DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION.  THIS PROJECT WILL FULLY RENOVATE APPROXIMATELY 1,305 TOTAL SQUARE FEET OF SPACE TO CREATE SAFE AND CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE LABOR AND BIRTHING AREAS SUPPORTING BLACK MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH.  THIS WILL INCLUDE RENOVATION TO ADD ONE ADDITIONAL LABOR & DELIVERY SUITE (INCLUDING BATHROOM) OUTFITTED TO PROVIDE NEGATIVE PRESSURE TO ASSURE THAT BIRTHING PEOPLE WITH COVID CAN DELIVER SAFELY, A NEW RECOVERY ROOM, EXPANSION OF THE EXISTING NURSES’ STATION TO ASSURE THAT THE MULTIDISCIPLINARY TREATMENT TEAM CAN WORK TOGETHER AND BE CLOSE TO THE AREA WHERE BIRTHING PEOPLE ARE DELIVERING, AND A NEW BREAK ROOM FOR STAFF. IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL ‘REFRESH’ 1,100 FEET OF CORRIDOR SPACE ADJACENT TO THIS AREA TO ASSURE IT IS WELCOMING TO OUR  BLACK BIRTHING PEOPLE AND THEIR FAMILIES AND COMMUNITY SUPPORTERS. SJRH IS THE ONLY MATERNITY SERVICES PROVIDER IN YONKERS, NY’S 3RD LARGEST CITY.  SJRH IS A NEW YORK STATE-RECOGNIZED DIPROPIONATE SHARE PROVIDER AND A FINANCIALLY DISTRESSED HOSPITAL.  WE PROVIDE MILLIONS OF DOLLARS ANNUALLY IN UNCOMPENSATED CARE AND 67% OF OUR MATERNITY SERVICES ARE DELIVERED TO WOMEN ON MEDICAID OR MEDICAID MANAGED CARE.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE RHODE ISLAND PUBLIC HEALTH FOUNDATION DOES BUSINESS AS THE RHODE ISLAND PUBLIC HEALTH INSTITUTE (RIPHI). RIPHI’S MISSION IS TO ELIMINATE HEALTH DISPARITIES IN RHODE ISLAND AND BEYOND. RIPHI DEVELOPS INNOVATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAMS, CONDUCTS TRANSLATIONAL RESEARCH, AND TRAINS STUDENTS AND PUBLIC HEALTH PRACTITIONERS. IN MARCH 2020, RIPHI OPENED OPEN DOOR HEALTH, RHODE ISLAND’S ONLY LGBTQ CLINIC. LOCATED ON THE WEST SIDE OF PROVIDENCE, OPEN DOOR HEALTH PROVIDES PRIMARY, SEXUAL AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH SERVICES TO RHODE ISLAND’S DIVERSE COMMUNITY. RIPHI OVERSEES MANY OTHER PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAMS, INCLUDING ONE OF THE LARGEST MOBILE PRODUCE MARKETS IN THE COUNTRY CALLED FOOD ON THE MOVE. RIPHI ALSO PARTNERS WITH OVER 200 FAITH-BASED ORGANIZATIONS ACROSS THE UNITED STATES TO FIGHT HIV STIGMA THROUGH FAITH IN ACTION. THE NUMBER OF PATIENTS AND CLIENTS RIPHI SERVES HAVE GROWN EXPONENTIALLY OVER THE LAST TWO YEARS, AS HAVE OUR BUDGET AND NUMBER OF EMPLOYEES. THERE IS INSUFFICIENT CLINICAL AND OFFICE SPACE TO ACCOMMODATE OUR GROWING STAFF AND SUITE OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND CLINICAL SERVICES. THIS APPROPRIATION WILL ALLOW RIPHI TO DEVELOP ADMINISTRATIVE HEADQUARTERS AS WELL AS EXPANDED MEDICAL OFFICE SPACE IN RESPONSE TO GROWING CLIENT VOLUME AND DEMAND FOR SERVICES. THIS EXPANSION WILL BETTER INTEGRATE ADMINISTRATIVE AND CLINICAL OPERATIONS AND ENHANCE PROGRAMMATIC COORDINATION ACROSS RIPHI INITIATIVES. ADDITIONAL SPACE WILL ALLOW RIPHI TO MORE THAN QUADRUPLE THE NUMBER OF PEOPLE THE ORGANIZATION SERVES EACH YEAR.

MAIN STREET; SPRING VALLEY, NEW YORK 10977 PROJECT DIRECTOR: CHANIE STERNBERG, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR PROJECT DIRECTOR PHONE: 845-354-9300 X. 1205 (VOICE); 845-354-9448 (FAX) EMAIL: CSTERNBERG@REFUAHHEALTH.ORG   WEBSITE: WWW.REFUAHHEALTH.ORG FUNDING REQUESTED: $2,000,000, AL/CFDS #: 93.439  DESCRIPTION: REFUAHHEALTH REQUESTS $2,000,000 IN COMMUNITY DIRECTED SPENDING TO CONSTRUCT THE CENTER OF EXCELLENCE FOR WOMEN'S HEALTH. THE STATE-OF-THE-ART FACILITY WILL BE DEDICATED TO THE PROVISION OF ACCESSIBLE, HIGH-QUALITY, AFFORDABLE HEALTHCARE FOR WOMEN. THE CENTER, TO BE LOCATED AT REFUAHHEALTH, A FEDERALLY QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTER (FQHC) THAT PROVIDES COMPREHENSIVE HEALTHCARE SERVICES TO LOW-INCOME POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT ROCKLAND COUNTY AND THE LOWER HUDSON VALLEY IN NEW YORK, WILL FOCUS ON FERTILITY SERVICES, OFFERING WOMEN TREATMENT AND COUNSELING IN A LOCAL, CARING, AND COMPREHENSIVE ENVIRONMENT. CONSISTENT WITH ITS MISSION AS AN FQHC, SERVICES AT THE CENTER WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO ALL WOMEN, REGARDLESS OF ABILITY TO PAY.   FUNDING WILL CONSTRUCT AN APPROX. 10,000 SQUARE FOOT FACILITY CONSISTING OF EXAM/CONSULT ROOMS, MAMMOGRAPHY, OUTPATIENT SURGICAL SPACE, AND AN EXPANDED MIDWIFERY-LED BIRTHING CENTER. KEEPING IN MIND THE DEEP EMOTIONAL ISSUES THAT CAN RESULT FROM INFERTILITY AND PREGNANCY LOSS, THE CENTER WILL BE DESIGNED WITH HOLISTIC DESIGN PRINCIPLES THAT WILL PROVIDE A SOOTHING AND PATIENT-FOCUSED EXPERIENCE.   NEED: ACCORDING TO AMERICAN COMMUNITY SURVEY DATA, APPROXIMATELY 15% OF ROCKLAND COUNTY WOMEN WILL FACE INFERTILITY. CURRENTLY, THERE ARE VIRTUALLY NO LOCAL OPTIONS FOR FERTILITY SERVICES IN ROCKLAND COUNTY. EVEN THOUGH NEW YORK IS ONE OF THE MOST EXPANSIVE STATES FOR FERTILITY HEALTH INSURANCE COVERAGE - AND THE ONLY STATE WHICH OFFERS COVERAGE THROUGH MEDICAID - THE LACK OF A  LOCAL OPTION MAKES IT DIFFICULT TO ACCESS TREATMENT. FERTILITY TREATMENT IS OFTEN A TIME-CONSUMING PROCESS, WITH CAREFULLY TIMED TREATMENTS BEING REQUIRED DAILY FOR SUSTAINED PERIODS OF TIMES. THE COST OF TRANSPORTATION AND THE NEED TO TAKE TIME OFF FROM WORK AND ARRANGE FAMILY CARE CAN MAKE TRAVEL TO OUT-OF-COUNTY PROVIDERS PROHIBITIVELY EXPENSIVE AND PRACTICALLY IMPOSSIBLE. THIS IS ALL IN ADDITION TO THE EMOTIONAL BURDEN FERTILITY PLACES ON WOMEN AND THEIR FAMILIES.   SERVICES: THE CENTER WILL PROVIDE ACCESSIBLE FERTILITY CARE, HOUSE AN EXPANDED MIDWIFERY LED BIRTHING CENTER, AND OFFER COMPREHENSIVE WOMEN'S HEALTH SERVICES, MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES, MAMMOGRAPHY, AND GYN OUT-PATIENT SURGERY. BRINGING ALL OF THESE SERVICES TOGETHER UNDER ONE ROOF, IN A PATIENT-CENTERED LOCATION, WILL ENHANCE REFUAH'S EXISTING CAPABILITIES AS AN FQHC AND ALLOW THE CENTER TO REACH THE UNDERSERVED WOMEN OF ROCKLAND COUNTY.   POPULATION GROUP(S) TO BE SERVED: REFUAHHEALTH IS A FEDERALLY-QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTER (FQHC) SERVING LOW INCOME FAMILIES, LIVING AT OR BELOW 200% OF FPG. AS AN FQHC, IT IS ACCESSIBLE TO PATIENTS REGARDLESS OF ABILITY TO PAY. IT IS ONE OF THE LARGEST PROVIDERS OF OUTPATIENT WOMEN'S HEALTH SERVICES IN ROCKLAND COUNTY. OVER 80% OF ITS PATIENTS ARE COVERED BY MEDICAID. REFUAH OFFERS UNINSURED PATIENTS CARE ON A SLIDING-FEE SCALE, WITH PATIENTS BELOW 100% OF THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL PAYING ONLY A NOMINAL FEE. NO PATIENT IS EVER TURNED AWAY BECAUSE THEY CANNOT AFFORD CARE.  IN PARTICULAR, WOMEN OF COLOR AND WOMEN OF LOWER SOCIO-ECONOMIC STATUS ARE DISPARATELY IMPACTED BY THE LACK OF LOCAL  FERTILITY AND COMPREHENSIVE WOMEN’S HEALTH OPTIONS. HISTORICALLY MARGINALIZED POPULATIONS, INCLUDING BIPOC AND LGBTQ COMMUNITIES, IN PARTICULAR, HAVE FACED HEIGHTENED BARRIERS TO ACCESSING FERTILITY TREATMENT. THESE WOMEN, WHO ALREADY FACE OTHER BARRIERS TO ACCESSING HEALTHCARE, WOULD ESPECIALLY BENEFIT FROM A LOCAL, AFFORDABLE OPTION

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - EDDY COUNTY, LOCATED IN THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE STATE, IS A MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED AREA (MUA) AND HEALTH PROFESSIONAL SHORTAGE AREA (HPSA). PRESBYTERIAN MEDICAL SERVICES (PMS) HAS BEEN PROVIDING PRIMARY HEALTHCARE IN THE CITY OF CARLSBAD FOR 30 YEARS. PMS CARLSBAD FAMILY HEALTH CENTER (FHC) HAS EXPERIENCED DOUBLE-DIGIT INCREASES IN PATIENT VISITS SINCE 2016, AND THERE IS A CONTINUING NEED FOR ADDITIONAL PRIMARY CARE SERVICES IN THE COMMUNITY. THE EXPANSION OF CARLSBAD FHC WILL ADD 8 EXAM ROOMS, CAPACITY TO ADD BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES, AND CREATE A MORE EFFICIENT MEDICAL SUPPORT WORKSTATION.  THE ADDITIONAL CLINICAL SPACE WILL IMPROVE PATIENT FLOW AND PROVIDER EFFICIENCY. THE EXPANDED CLINIC WILL HAVE SPACE TO ADD 2 MEDICAL PROVIDERS AND 1 BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PROVIDER TO ITS CLINICAL TEAM AND OPEN ACCESS TO CARE FOR 3200 ADDITIONAL PATIENTS.   PMS WILL USE CONGRESSIONALLY DESIGNATED SPENDING (CDS) FUNDS TO EXPAND THE EXISTING FOOTPRINT OF THE CARLSBAD FHC FACILITY FROM ITS CURRENT 9,088 SQUARE FEET TO 12,688 SQUARE FEET - AN INCREASE OF 3,600 SQUARE FEET. THE EXPANSION WILL INCLUDE AN ADDITIONAL EIGHT (8) EXAM ROOMS, BEHAVIORAL HEALTH OFFICE AND GROUP ROOM, MEDICAL ASSISTANT WORKSTATION, EXPANDED PHARMACY SPACE WITH ADMIN OFFICE, NEW RESTROOMS, AND AN EXTENDED FILE ROOM. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO RECONFIGURE APPROXIMATELY 740 SQUARE FEET OF THE EXISTING FACILITY TO PROVIDE AN EXPANDED LAB SPACE AND REVAMPED SPACE FOR A PROVIDER WORK ROOM.  THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE UNMET NEED FOR SERVICES IN EDDY COUNTY BY IMPROVING ACCESS TO PRIMARY CARE, ESPECIALLY THOSE WHO HAVE EXPERIENCED DIFFICULTY FINDING A MEDICAL HOME DUE TO COSTS, LACK OF TRANSPORTATION, DISTANCE BARRIERS AND ABILITY TO PAY. PMS IS THE ONLY PRIMARY CARE PROVIDER THAT OFFERS A SLIDING FEE SCALE IN EDDY COUNTY.  PMS HAS DEVELOPED PARTNERSHIPS WITH LOCAL HOSPITALS, PUBLIC HEALTH DEPARTMENTS, CITY AND COUNTY GOVERNMENTS AND LOCAL PROVIDERS TO OFFER COMPLETE WRAP-AROUND SERVICES TO PATIENTS .  THE CITY OF CARLSBAD LOOKS TO PMS TO PROVIDE CRITICAL SERVICES TO THE UNINSURED AND UNDERSERVED. THE COMMUNITY EXPECTS THE HEALTH CENTER TO BE ABLE TO MEET HEALTH CARE NEEDS AS THEY CONTINUE TO GROW AND CHANGE.  THROUGHOUT THE CONSTRUCTION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROJECT, PMS WILL BOOST EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES AND FINANCIAL RESOURCES INTO THE COMMUNITY. THE ADDITIONAL SERVICES CREATED FROM THE EXPANSION WILL IMPROVE THE LIVES OF PATIENTS AND THE OVERALL HEALTH OF THE COMMUNITY.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - PACE ORGANIZATION OF RHODE ISLAND (PACE-RI) 10 TRIPPS LANE, EAST PROVIDENCE, RI 02915-3014  TOM BOUCHER 401-654-4644 (VOICE) TBOUCHER@PACE-RI.ORG PACE-RI.ORG  CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - $300,000 FOR FACILITIES AND CONSTRUCTION… PACE-RI IS REQUESTING $300,000 TO REPLACE THE ROOF AT OUR EAST PROVIDENCE HEALTH CLINIC AND ADULT DAY CENTER FOR FRAIL ELDERS WITH CHRONIC HEALTH NEEDS. PACE BECOMES THEIR HEALTH INSURER AND MEDICAL PROVIDER AND ALSO DELIVERS A RANGE OF SOCIAL SERVICES INCLUDING TRANSPORTATION, MEALS, DAY CENTER SERVICES, AND MORE. COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - THE PROJECT BEING PROPOSED IS TO BUILD A SCHOOL BASED HEALTH CLINIC AT GLENBROOK SOUTH HIGH SCHOOL, LOCATED IN GLENVIEW ILLINOIS. THE CLINIC WILL PRIMARILY SERVE STUDENTS IN THE HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT.   A SBHC IS A WALK-IN, FULL-SERVICE CLINIC ENVIRONMENT FOR STUDENTS OFFERING A RANGE OF AGE-APPROPRIATE HEALTH CARE SERVICES REGARDLESS OF THE ABILITY TO PAY.  THROUGH A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN A SCHOOL DISTRICT AND A COMMUNITY HEALTH ORGANIZATION, A SCHOOL-BASED HEALTH CENTER IS A POWERFUL TOOL FOR ACHIEVING HEALTH EQUITY AMONG STUDENTS BY OFFERING: PRIMARY MEDICAL CARE (ATHLETIC AND SCHOOL PHYSICALS, IMMUNIZATIONS, DIAGNOSTIC TESTING); MENTAL/BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE; HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION; SUBSTANCE ABUSE COUNSELING; AND NUTRITION EDUCATION.  STUDENTS CAN BE TREATED FOR ACUTE ILLNESSES, SUCH AS FLU OR STREP THROAT, AND CHRONIC CONDITIONS, INCLUDING ASTHMA AND DIABETES.  THEY CAN ALSO BE SCREENED FOR DENTAL, VISION, AND HEARING PROBLEMS.  WITH AN EMPHASIS ON PREVENTION, EARLY INTERVENTION, AND RISK REDUCTION, SCHOOL-BASED HEALTH CENTERS SEEK TO IMPROVE STUDENTS' OVERALL PHYSICAL AND EMOTIONAL HEALTH REGARDLESS OF THE ABILITY TO PAY.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - MANET COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTER, INC. (MANET) IS A 501(C)(3) NON-PROFIT, FQHC OPERATING SIX PRIMARY CARE PRACTICE SITES, FOUR IN QUINCY, ONE IN TAUNTON, AND A NEW SITE IN ATTLEBORO SERVING THE COMMUNITIES OF SOUTHEASTERN MA. MANET ATTLEBORO OPENED LATE JULY 2021, AT 8 NORTH MAIN STREET, IN DOWNTOWN ATTLEBORO WITHIN LEASED SPACE AT THE BRONSON BUILDING. FOR MORE THAN 40 YEARS WITHOUT INTERRUPTION, MANET HAS PROVIDED QUALITY, COMPASSIONATE HEALTH CARE TO ALL, REGARDLESS OF ABILITY TO PAY AND ENSURING THAT NO PATIENT IS LEFT BEHIND. MANET HAS BEEN CONSISTENTLY ACCREDITED BY THE JOINT COMMISSION SINCE 1999 WITH THE MOST ACCREDITATION IN OCTOBER 2022.    WITH THE HIGH RATE OF DISPARITIES AMONG THEM, MANET HAS CHOSEN TO FOCUS IN THE ATTLEBORO REGION ON LOW-INCOME SENIOR AND ELDERS, FAMILIES, NEW ARRIVALS, RESIDENTS OF PUBLIC HOUSING, AND PATIENTS THAT HAVE GONE WITHOUT ACCESS TO CONTINUITY CARE, AND A PRIMARY CARE ACCESS POINT, AND HOUSING UNSTABLE AND HOMELESS. APPROXIMATELY 53% OF MANET’S PATIENTS ARE COVERED BY PUBLICLY FUNDED PROGRAMS, AND 75.3% OF PATIENTS HAVE INCOMES AT OR BELOW 200% FPL.   MANET DELIVERS COMPASSIONATE, CULTURALLY, LINGUISTICALLY SENSITIVE PROGRAMS AND SERVICES FOR ALL AGES, INCLUDING ACUTE AND PREVENTIVE CARE, MEDICAL NUTRITION THERAPY, CHRONIC DISEASE MANAGEMENT, INFECTIOUS DISEASE CARE, SPECIALTY ACCESS, DIAGNOSTIC LABORATORY, HIV/STI PREVENTION AND RISK ASSESSMENT, CASE MANAGEMENT, OB/GYN CARE, LGBTQ CARE, OPIOID OVERDOSE PREVENTION/NALOXONE TRAINING AND DISTRIBUTION, HEALTH INSURANCE NAVIGATION, BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES, TREATMENT FOR SUBSTANCE USE DISORDERS, TELEMEDICINE SERVICES AND COVID-19 SERVICES FOR REGISTERED PATIENTS AND THE COMMUNITY.   AS NOTED, IN JULY 2021, MANET CHC OPENED ITS NEWEST SITE IN ATTLEBORO. CURRENTLY THE SITE, (PHASE I) COMPRISED OF 2900 SQ FT HAS FOUR EXAM ROOMS AND A WAITING AREA AND HAS RECEIVE OVER 1000 PATIENTS SINCE ITS OPENING. THE CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING (CDS) FOR CONSTRUCTION, H RSA 22-134 MAKES POSSIBLE THIS NEEDED EXPANSION TO ADD AND REALIZE: NEW MAIN ENTRANCE, SIX (6) NEW EXAMS ROOMS, TWO (CONSULT) SPACES, A GROUP PROVIDER OFFICE AND LARGER WAITING ROOM TO ENSURE COMPREHENSIVE, LOW-BARRIER, ACCESSIBLE, EQUITABLE AND INTEGRATED CARE.   THE 8 N. MAIN STREET SITE HAS 6,200 TOTAL SQUARE FEET OF SPACE WITH THE EXPANDED SPACE AT 3588 SQ FT IS READILY ACCESSIBLE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION AND IS PROXIMAL TO THE PUBLIC HOUSING COMMUNITY. THE PRACTICE IS NEAR STURDY MEMORIAL HOSPITAL WHERE MANET HAS AN EXISTING REFERRAL ARRANGEMENT. THE SITE IS WALKING DISTANCE FROM THE SENIOR CENTER, BRISTOL COUNTY COMMUNITY COLLEGE, COMMUNITY COUNSELING OF BRISTOL COUNTY, AND THE ATTLEBORO YMCA. ACCESS TO CARE REMAINS HAMPERED BY THE SCARCITY OF PRIMARY CARE PROVIDERS AVAILABLE TO AREA RESIDENTS. THE PCP RATIO IN BRISTOL COUNTY IS 1,830:1, AND WITH THIS TOP OF MIND, MANET EXPECTS TO BEGIN THE EXPANSION (PHASE II) IN AUGUST 2022.  MANET’S PRIMARY CARE PROVIDERS, SUPPORT STAFF, NUTRITIONIST, AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH TEAM WILL SERVE AN ADDITIONAL 1,300 PATIENTS IN YR 1 WITH THE COMPLETION OF THE EXPANSION AT 8 NORTH MAIN ST.

COMMUNITY PROJECT FUNDING/CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING - CONSTRUCTION - LGBT LIFE CENTER HAS BEEN PROVIDING HIV AND LGBTQ SERVICES SINCE 1989 AND IS THE ONLY NONPROFIT IN THIS REGION OF VIRGINIA PROVIDING LGBTQ CLINICAL AND SUPPORT SERVICES. THE ORGANIZATION'S MISSION TO PROVIDE HIV TESTING AND TREATMENT IS A MUCH-NEEDED SERVICE IN HAMPTON AND NEWPORT NEWS. THE CENTER IS THE LONGEST OPERATING HIV/AIDS COMMUNITY BASED PROVIDER IN THE ENTIRE EASTERN REGION. IT SERVES THOUSANDS OF INDIVIDUALS THROUGH EXISTING FOUR SERVICE CENTERS, INCLUDING THEIR LGBTQ PRIMARY CARE AND HIV SPECIALTY CARE MEDICAL CLINIC IN NORFOLK.   WHEN THE LGBTQ PRIMARY CARE AND HIV SPECIALTY CARE CLINIC WAS OPENED IN NORFOLK IN JANUARY 2019, PROJECTIONS WERE TO SERVE 110 PEOPLE IN THE FIRST YEAR. MORE THAN 500 PEOPLE HAVE BEEN SERVED BY THE END OF THE SECOND YEAR.   THE CENTER HAS PURCHASED A BUILDING IN HAMPTON AND ARE REQUESTING $1.8M IN FUNDING TO SUPPORT THE RENOVATIONS AND THE BUILDOUT OF A BUILDING THEY OWN FOR A MEDICAL CLINIC, CLINICAL BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES AND A VARIETY OF OTHER SUPPORT SERVICES WHICH ARE GEARED TO PROVIDING LGBTQ AFFIRMING AND CULTURALLY SENSITIVE SERVICES FOR THE PENINSULA COMMUNITIES.  THIS COMMUNITY CENTER WILL SERVE ALL INDIVIDUALS WITHOUT DISCRIMINATION AND JUDGEMENT, ENSURING THEIR ABILITY TO REMAIN ENGAGED IN CARE.  THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND ACCESS TO MEDICAL AND MENTAL HEALTH CLINICAL CARE BY PROVIDING LGBTQ AFFIRMING CARE TO A VERY VULNERABLE COMMUNITY THAT HAS DIFFICULTY ACCESSING SERVICES IN MAINSTREAM VENUES. THE RENOVATED BUILDING WILL BE A SAFE SPACE FOR LGBTQ YOUTH AND ADULTS TO SEEK SUPPORT AND RESOURCES. THE CENTER WILL WORK WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES TO PROVIDE SEXUAL HEALTH EDUCATION, YOUTH AND ADULT SERVICES, COMMUNITY GATHERINGS AND CULTURAL COMPETENCY TRAININGS. THIS COMMUNITY CENTER WILL SERVE THE ENTIRE PENINSULA. TRANSPORTATION SERVICES WILL BE OFFERED TO LOCAL RESIDENTS AND IS LOCATED AT A BUS STOP.
